PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Guide
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.We are opposed to the sex guide endorsed by Ms Lawrence, Minister for Health in the Keating Government, and published in the December issue of Cleo.
2.We believe that the sex guide encourages dangerous sexual practices which could have serious medical and moral effects.

PARA.TAB: We request the Senate to call on Ms Lawrence to withdraw her endorsement of this sex guide and for the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to indicate his disapproval.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Herron (from 885 citizens) and Senators Abetz and (from 885 citizens) and Herron (from 2,799 citizens).

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned humbly request that the Senate honours the obligations of the Commonwealth of Australia to protect its territory that has received World Heritage status according to the World Heritage Convention of which Australia is a signatory.

Significant areas of marine and mangrove ecosystems of Australia's World Heritage Great Barrier Reef Marine Park are directly threatened with destruction by the adjacent construction of Australia's largest tourist resort and marina complex at Oyster Point near Cardwell North Queensland (opposite Hinchinbrook Island).

We implore the Senate to use its powers immediately to permanently halt the construction of the marina and access channel in the World Heritage "Buffer Zone" as recommended by the Valentine Report made to his Department in October 1994.
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned urges the Government to press for a total ban internationally on the production, stockpiling, trade and use of anti-personnel devices;
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate urge the Government to provide financial aid for the de-mining of countries such as Cambodia.

PETITION.TITLE: Women: Pension Age
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned strongly opposes the increase in the Pension age for women from 60 to 65.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate take action to reverse this decision.

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Chamarette moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely a motion to give precedence to a motion of censure of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) in relation to the use of Land Fund money.

SPEECH.PARA: Speaking to the contingency of that, I believe that it does need to be debated. It probably needed to be debated earlier this week, but I felt that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins, in particular should have an opportunity to retract his statement and, similarly, so should the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans).

PARA.TAB: It was convenient to be able to give people some time to think about that. And it is very urgent that this be debated because it is a question of misleading the Senate and the people of Australia. It deserves an urgent and a very serious response. So I urge my colleagues in the chamber to give this matter the due consideration it deserves and allow the full time for debate on it. I do not intend to say any more about its urgency now.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government, of course, opposes the suspension of standing orders to deal with this issue. I do not know whether there has been a communication breakdown here, but the reason that I am in the chamber is that I was advised that this morning Senator Chamarette would be raising her notice of motion on a return to order for documents.
—I will do that after this.

—Will you? All I am saying is that I fairly acted on the advice that I was given. I was given absolutely no suggestion that this was going to happen in here this morning. In fact, I was advised yesterday, clearly wrongly, that Senator Chamarette was proposing to do this at 5 o'clock this afternoon.
—No, those documents are needed for 5 o'clock this afternoon.

—Senator Chamarette, all I am telling you and the chamber is that I acted on the advice that I was given. Whether there has been a communication breakdown or not I do not know. I will certainly find out in the next short while what was to happen in here this morning.

PARA.TAB: I was advised that the matter raised here this morning was the entirely unreasonable return to order, I might add, in the time made available to produce documents. I was prepared to provide an offer from the government in respect of those documents.

The government's position on the documents, Senator Chamarette, which I checked on yesterday, having seen your return to order, is there is an absolute raft of documents required to be produced in 48 hours, which is just utterly unreasonable. It would require a major diversion of staff resources to produce this fishing expedition raft of documents.

We were prepared to suggest to you, had you given us the opportunity to do so, that a more clearly defined set of documents would be achieved—for example, a handleable set of documents similar to those that Senator Bell indicated this morning that he would be requesting on a return to order. So if there has been a breakdown, I apologise, Senator Chamarette.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: it may assist things if the minister were to debate the actual motion, which is for the suspension of standing orders. At the moment the minister is dealing with another matter—that is, the return to order matter.
—Is that going to be dealt with, Senator Chamarette?
—After this one.
—To be quite frank, I do not know. All I am saying is that, to assist me and others, I would suggest that the minister discuss the motion that is before us.
—I took it that the minister was giving his reasons for not supporting the suspension.
—That is correct. That is exactly what I was doing. We oppose the motion.
—I indicate that the coalition will support the motion for the suspension of standing orders.
—Of course.

—It will be no surprise to the minister. The reason for our support is that this chamber spent an enormous amount of time debating this legislation. As Senator Collins and the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) would remember, I think it was the second or third longest debate in the history of this parliament. The issues that are contained in the motion moved by the Greens (WA), and Senator Chamarette in particular, were issues that were canvassed by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration hearings when the bill was first introduced here. They were then debated during the lengthy committee stage and second reading debate on the bill. They were then debated and discussed during the hearings around Australia of the Senate Select Committee on the Land Fund Bill which I chaired.

PARA.TAB: Concerns were raised about these issues and the government defended its scheme for creating two land funds instead of one as a transitional measure. They were warned by a range of Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal witnesses and lobbyists throughout that lengthy debate, which ranged from about October until March this year, that just what has occurred would occur. It is therefore a matter that the Senate needs to deal with as a matter of urgency. Therefore, the motion for the suspension of standing orders will be very happily supported by coalition senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion for the suspension of standing orders is to enable Senator Chamarette to move a motion censuring the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins). I listened carefully to what Senator Collins said. His opposition to this motion appeared to be based on his concern about the ability of the government to meet the terms of the return to order. That is another issue altogether. Quite frankly, I do not see, on the face of it, why the government, with its army of public servants, cannot observe the obligations that are imposed upon it by the parliament to produce those documents in the public interest. But that is another issue altogether. It has nothing to do with this motion.

PARA.TAB: I would be concerned if Senator Collins did not know that there was a censure motion coming forward. But, as has been indicated by Senator Campbell, this matter has been discussed both in committees and in the Senate chamber. It would concern me if the minister did not know that he was going to face a censure motion because, to me, that would be a question of natural justice. The minister knew some two weeks ago that there would be a censure motion. In fact, everybody else seemed to know. I hope Senator Collins was not implying that he did not know. That is how it seemed to come over but I suppose one will have to look at the Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't know this morning.
—He knew it was coming and he knew, presumably, that it would have to be this week. He knew the matter was a very important matter.
—Today is our only full sitting day.
—As Senator Patterson reminds me, today is the only full sitting day. Tomorrow is for estimates committees.

PARA.TAB: The minister ought to check with his whip as to whether his whip knew that it was likely to come on today. I was given an indication last night, not by Senator Chamarette but from another governmental source, that this matter was going to come on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I said that. I was told 5 o'clock this afternoon. I was obviously wrongly advised. It is not a problem. The thing will get carried, so let's carry it.
—I was very concerned that you should have natural justice.
—It is in the Hansard. I was told 5 o'clock this afternoon.
—If everybody has agreed that the suspension go ahead, why am I talking?

—I want to indicate very briefly my support for the motion as well. Senator Harradine is quite right: anyone with a modicum of intelligence would have realised it was coming up today. It is absolutely essential that any suggestion of misleading the Senate be dealt with promptly by the Senate. A censure for misleading the Senate is the gravest allegation that can be made against any minister in this parliament.
—Not in the Senate.

—It is treated very seriously by every senator, other than obviously Senator Collins. For that reason the motion should be dealt with forthwith. As I say, there is no more serious an allegation that can be made in this parliament.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Chamarette) agreed to:

That a motion to censure the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) in relation to the use of Land Fund money may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business this day till determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate censures the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) for misleading the Senate and the people of Australia over the use of Land Fund money available through the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) when:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)on 11 May 1995, Senator Bob Collins said that Senator Campbell was wrong to say that $20 million out of $24 million had been allocated for land acquisition in the Northern Territory and asserted that `the principal issue is that $42 million is available to ATSIC for land acquisition, Senator, not $21 million',thereby seeking to represent ATSIC's decision in a better, but inaccurate, light;

(b)on 9 November 1994 Senator Gareth Evans stated that `the Government has agreed with the Northern Territory government that the allocation of new moneys to the land fund should not lead to an increase in the amount of land claimed under the Land Rights Act. . . ', when the decision by ATSIC will cause a dramatic increase in the amount of land claimed under the Native Title Act; and

(c)an ATSIC Board Briefing Paper now reveals that an agreement had been struck between the Prime Minister, ATSIC and a group of `indigenous Land Fund Bill negotiators' about singling out the Northern Territory for special treatment over the next 2 years for land acquisitions from ATSIC's land acquisition and land maintenance program.

On 11 May 1995, in answer to my question without notice about the decision by ATSIC to allocate $20 million to the Northern Territory for land acquisition, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, said:

I am very surprised that the dynamics did not work out in order to provide for more equitable distribution. I think that is a ground for concern. Senator Collins said he was concerned about that news. I certainly say that I am concerned about it and I will certainly be seeking some further information.

That was nearly three weeks ago. Since then, despite the fact that we are into the third sitting day following the fine words of Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Bob Collins, neither has felt any compulsion to return to this chamber and provide a fuller explanation of the ATSIC decision. Senator Collins needs to more fully explain the statements he made in vitriolic fashion on 11 May, when he said:
The fact is that less than half of the money available to ATSIC for land acquisition has been used for that purpose.

Senator Collins knew that it was $20 million out of the possible $24 million available to ATSIC for land acquisition that was to be used for purchasing land in the Northern Territory. The Leader of the Government in the Senate does need to explain what he meant on 9 November last year when he said:

The government has agreed with the Northern Territory government that the allocation of new moneys to the land fund should not lead to an increase in the amount of land claimed under the land rights act . . .

He did say `agreed'. If you read the debate at that time, you would know that that statement was made in response to concerns about how much land would be able to be purchased in the territory prior to the Northern Territory land rights cut-off coming into action. It is very clear what the leader meant.

PARA.TAB: I might add that our criticisms in the debate were in the context that, if there really was a billion dollar land fund, if there really was an adequate amount available for land purchases throughout Australia for those Aboriginal people who have been dispossessed by the 200 years of settlement, there could be no quibble with this particular allocation. What we must remember is that the ATSIC land acquisition and management funding is only half of the total indigenous land fund, or the so-called billion dollar fund, that is available for administration, acquisition and management. When this section of it is so largely used in the Northern Territory, it is clearly inequitable to the rest of Australia.

As I said, that is clearly what Senator Collins and the Leader of the Government meant when they were speaking. They knew that that was inaccurate information. Here we are, three weeks since the issue was raised in this place, and the government has done nothing to fully explain the circumstances of the ATSIC decision.

If this is not enough reason to bring on the censure motion today, let us look at why the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) should also be censured and, in his turn, the Leader of the Government, again, for misleading the Senate, for hiding from the Senate that there was a secret agreement between a small favoured group of Aboriginal people, ATSIC and the government about giving special treatment to the Northern Territory for the next two years.

This secret agreement was vehemently denied in this place by Senator Collins and Senator Evans. Yet now we have the ATSIC briefing paper that was circulated to all of the commissioners in preparation for them to make their decision on the distribution of land fund money riddled with references to agreements with indigenous Land Fund Bill negotiators and in line with discussions with government.

To add insult to injury, last Friday during estimates we had ATSIC, with the help of the duty minister and the chair of the committee, attempting to block questioning about the decision and about the briefing paper. Mr Morony from ATSIC said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am not sure that it is appropriate that I discuss a confidential board paper and the recommendations contained in it.

At the time I stated that it was a very valuable time to answer those questions when all the departmental advisers were there. However, that opportunity was not taken. That also lay beneath the request for appropriate documentation. That will be part of a call to order later on, not as part of this debate. It is the deadline for that that has possibly confused the minister because it is at 5 o'clock today that those documents are requested. We will deal with the matter of changes to that during the debate to deal with the call to order, but I thank my colleagues for realising the seriousness and urgency of this motion.

PARA.TAB: As the motion says, on 9 November 1994, Senator Evans stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The government has agreed with the Northern Territory government that the allocation of new moneys to the land fund should not lead to an increase in the amount of land claimed under the land rights act . . .

Now, six months later, we are here debating the decision by ATSIC to provide over 80 per cent of all the money it is setting aside for land acquisition for the next two years to purchases in the Northern Territory. This will cause a dramatic increase in the amount of land claimed under the land rights act. Yet the Leader of the Government, when challenged about this decision by me two weeks ago, did not apologise to the Senate, and since then he has made no attempt to return to this place and fully explain the circumstances of the ATSIC decision. In fact, all he did was protest that he thought it does call for an explanation from ATSIC. It certainly does, and it calls for an explanation from the government. He also said:
I did not know whether there are any other understandings or agreements lying behind this.

Yet Senator Evans then bravely went on to argue that his expectation was that the distribution of land fund moneys would take a relatively even pattern of distribution of the funding rather than it all being concentrated in the Northern Territory. He said:
I do not think it is a matter of formal undertaking. I cannot recall—
that is a very familiar phrase in Western Australia—
any such agreements or undertakings being entered into, but it was certainly a matter of expectation.

How can that be? ATSIC's expectation would appear to be quite the opposite. Throughout the briefing paper that was written by the ATSIC bureaucracy to provide options to the ATSIC commissioners for the decision on the distribution of ATSIC land fund moneys for the next two years, the core assumption is that there be:
special treatment for the Northern Territory with respect to land acquisitions from ATSIC's
land acquisition and management program
in line with discussions with the government and the restrictions of the bill.
Two pages later, when arguing against option 3, he said:

This option contains the greatest difficulties for the parallel programs in that if ATSIC were to prioritise land management, the Northern Territory would have very little access to historical levels of land acquisition funding. The rationale for having parallel programs is therefore lost, which is the basis of the Prime Minister's agreement with indigenous land fund bill negotiators.

I do not know how many people were aware that there were land fund bill negotiators. We knew there were for the Native Title Bill but the understanding was that the land fund bill was receiving widespread consultation throughout Australia—in fact, the most widespread consultation, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs said.

PARA.TAB: In arguing for option 1, the author of this briefing document states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Northern Territory traditional owners would lose rights resulting from the rest of indigenous people gaining access to land acquisition.

That is a very strange statement, which I am still to fully comprehend. However, in the light of these statements, the government therefore needs to answer some very serious questions. I do not particularly care who answers them; it might be that the Leader of the Government might like to provide the answers or Senator Collins or perhaps ATSIC during the supplementary estimates hearings.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans.

—Yes, the Leader of the Government might be the most appropriate person. It is certainly time for answers to be given—answers to questions such as: was an agreement struck between the government, ATSIC and a group of indigenous land fund bill negotiators? If so, when, who and what were the terms of the agreement? Did the Leader of the Government in the Senate lie to the Senate? Did the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy lie to the Senate? Or were they just misinformed like the rest of Australia? Did the deal include agreements about appointments to the ILC board, special attention being given to the Northern Territory over and above other Aboriginal people? If all of the above is wrong, what is meant by the statements that are contained in the ATSIC briefing paper?

PARA.TAB: These are the reasons I am moving this censure motion today. It is a very serious censure because what underlies it is potentially nearly two years of deceit, dishonesty and possibly many years of manipulation of Aboriginal organisations by this government through ATSIC.

I did not come into this parliament concerned about ATSIC and the role that it plays in Aboriginal affairs. That is something I had to learn. However, through my experiences during the native title debate, and then more recently through the land fund saga, I have almost lost all faith in ATSIC's ability to do the right thing by its constituency. Please remember its constituency; it is Aboriginal people right throughout Australia, people who are supposedly represented at a regional level and at a community level and for whom the ATSIC board is expected to make decisions in all their interests, not in selective interests and not to work for a government agenda.

It is a very sufficient reason to look at why the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Government should also be censured because there have clearly been deals and secret agreements going on that give special favoured treatment to those people who are prepared to support government legislation and to succeed in manipulating decisions in order to assist the government in that direction.

I am not being critical here of many regional councillors, regional councils, bureaucrats or even many commissioners. What I am concerned about is the way ATSIC is used to silence the critics of this government's policies. I also want to point out that I do not even begrudge Northern Territory Aboriginal people any piece of land or any funding they can get, except when this is gained at the expense of Aboriginal people elsewhere in Australia.

The decision by ATSIC provides Northern Territory Aboriginal people with at least double the percentage of funding they would normally receive for land acquisition. Normally the Northern Territory would get around 14 per cent of all funds available for land. The ATSIC proposal for the next two years will give the Northern Territory over 30 per cent of all land fund money, either through ATSIC or the new ILC, if the current ratio of land acquisition to management is maintained.

I would stress that in this place we have just passed a land fund bill which for the next two years splits the money equally between the Indigenous Land Corporation and the ATSIC land acquisition and management program which has already been in existence. The Indigenous Land Corporation gained $24 million a year; the ATSIC land management program continued to receive $21 million a year. By the decision of the ATSIC board, the Northern Territory has received $20 million of the $24 million available for land acquisition funding from ATSIC over the next two years.

I have not received a satisfactory answer from Senator Gareth Evans as to what percentage of the management funding—that is, $18 million of the ATSIC land fund—is going to the Northern Territory in addition to that. Even if it is a small proportion of management funding—which I doubt because I understand that landholdings in the Northern Territory are considerable in comparison with the rest of the country—there is no doubt whatsoever that $20 million of $24 million for land acquisition in the Northern Territory will produce exceedingly strong demands on any management funding available through the Indigenous Land Corporation in future years.

It may well be—and it is certainly stated in information we have received about the ATSIC board meeting, which includes a statement by its chair—that the ATSIC board has recommended that the Northern Territory not receive any Indigenous Land Corporation funding for the next two years. I should not be sarcastic and say that that is generous, but I do think it is a debatable point. It does show that the board knew that there was an inequity when it made the decision and that it had to balance it by saying that the Northern Territory should not be a beneficiary of Indigenous Land Corporation funding for acquisition. The board said nothing about how it would, of necessity, have to be a beneficiary of the management component of the Indigenous Land Corporation funds, not just in the next two years but for the conceivable future.

In summary, I wish to highlight how serious this matter is. It needs to be dealt with to the fullest possible extent. There are very serious questions that deserve to be answered by the Leader of the Government and by Senator Bob Collins. If those answers are not satisfactory, they certainly warrant the highest censure possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, might I respond initially to Senator Chamarette's censure motion by saying it is utterly without substance or justification for reasons that I will explain at the outset and Senator Bob Collins will no doubt want to add further to. Let us go back for a start to what was actually said during the debate on the land fund bill.

PARA.TAB: It was a matter of public record at that time—no ifs, buts or maybes—that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) had given a commitment to the then Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Perron, that the allocation of `new moneys' should not be used on the purchase of leases in the Northern Territory which could be converted to inalienable freehold under the Northern Territory land rights act. That fact was freely acknowledged by both Senator Collins and me during the debate. Indeed, Senator Chamarette's censure motion includes that specific quote, or part of it, from me.

It was also freely acknowledged in the debate that by including section 121U in the bill the government had not given any undertaking, nor had it intended—notwithstanding what Mr Perron might have wanted—that the 1997 cut-off in the land rights act would, in effect, be brought forward by preventing or limiting the amount of land that ATSIC could acquire in the Northern Territory before that time. Purchases in the Northern Territory by ATSIC during the phasing-out period were clearly contemplated and the possibility of them occurring was clearly acknowledged by all those involved in the debate. Mr Perron was under no illusions whatsoever about the government's position in that respect.

Without wanting to go into the semantics of all this, I point out that the claim that ATSIC is now giving 80 per cent of the money available for land purchases for this purpose misrepresents the situation. The fact is that, as I have already said in answer to a question from Senator Chamarette, ATSIC had $42 million available to it over the next two years for land acquisition and land management combined from the land fund.

It has always been the case, and will be over the next two years, that it is a matter for the board of ATSIC to determine what the split should be between acquisition on the one hand and management on the other. The fact is that the board has decided to spend: $18 million on land management all over Australia; $20 million—less than 50 per cent of the total $42 million—on land acquisition in the Northern Territory; and $4 million in land acquisition elsewhere. In that respect, I can only repeat what I said on 21 March during the debate on the bill: ATSIC is an independent authority; it makes its own decisions about how it spends its land acquisition and its management funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you tell the Senate something different?

—I said that I anticipated that the dynamics at work within ATSIC, within that organisation, would result in a rather different distribution of the funds simply because of the geographical composition of the board members. I did not say—
—You led the Senate to believe a different situation.

—I did not say anything of the kind. Let me conclude the point I was making. It is obvious that for the government to direct the commission in this matter, either in relation to the original decision or to do so now, would deny the principles of self-determination which underlie its establishment and would deny ATSIC's representative nature.

PARA.TAB: If anyone wants to track back over the record as to exactly what I did say on this particular subject, the simplest thing for me to do is seek to incorporate in Hansard the two relevant extracts from the statements that I made. The first statement was made on Wednesday, 9 November 1994 and can be found at pages 2810 to 2811 of Hansard. The second statement occurred on 21 March this year and appears at pages 1828 to 1829 of Hansard. The latter was an answer that I gave in response to a question from Senator Ellison. I seek leave to incorporate those passages in the record so that anyone reading this debate can see precisely the context of my answer and precisely what I said.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?
—No. I would like to hear it and make up my mind about it.
—What I said on 9 November in response to a particular amendment was this:

SPEECH.PARA: The government opposes this amendment. I think the background to it is well known. The government has agreed with the Northern Territory government that the allocation of new monies to the land fund should not lead to an increase in the amount of land claimed under the land rights act, although pastoral leases purchased by the corporation will be eligible for conversion to native title under section 47 of the Native Title Act. There are no barriers to land acquired by ATSIC being claimed under the land rights act prior to the cut-off date for claims, which is 1997. This is just a matter of getting a responsible balance between the competing claims and interests here. We are not prepared to allow the potential for open slather on conversions to inalienable freehold prior to the cut-off for claims. On that basis we oppose this amendment.

PARA.TAB: It needs to be remembered that already nearly 40 per cent of land in the Northern Territory is held by Aboriginal people under inalienable title under the provisions of the land rights act in the Northern Territory. It is against that background and in that context that this particular limitation has been introduced. It is obviously a reasonably sensitive issue, not only as between the Commonwealth and the territory government but also with the Aboriginal people themselves. It is one of those provisions that have been seen to be a reasonable compromise between the competing claims and interests that are involved. Accordingly, we recommend the clause to the Senate in its present form and oppose the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: That is what I said in November, and that is the full context of the statement that is quoted today by Senator Chamarette. We can see clearly what it is about. What I said on 21 March was this:

It is not our expectation that ATSIC will do anything other than maintain the normal pattern of land acquisition using those funds available to it. ATSIC is an independent authority and makes its own decisions about this matter. But I do not believe there is any basis for thinking that the kind of strategy outlined by Senator Ellison will be pursued. There are far too many other people around the country with competing interests who would be far too upset for that to happen. I think we can rely on good sense prevailing in that respect.
A little further on, in response to Senator Ellison asking, `Would the main aim be to provide as wide a spread as possible?', I said:

I think everything hangs on the `as possible'. There is a sense in which we have to leave it to the ILC's discretion. Situations vary enormously around the country. To talk about an even spread, it begs a lot of questions that need to be answered by the board. I hope it will be equitable and balanced but how that is best done depends on the combination of national and regional strategies that emerge. There will be a consultative process associated with that and I hope, again, that good sense will prevail. We expect it will.

It was because I had that expectation that there would be that kind of spread generated by the ordinary internal dynamics of the board that I said what I did, but I made it absolutely clear that it was a matter for the board's discretion.

PARA.TAB: Why I was a little bit puzzled when things unfolded as they did without me knowing anything at all about any further background to the decision is because the board had obviously decided, as a result of its own internal processes, to concentrate most of the money available in the next two years that was not going to be spent on land management in the Northern Territory. The board did that for what obviously were perceived by the majority of the board members as good and sufficient reasons.

If we look at the nub of Senator Chamarette's allegations that there is some kind of deal involved here which would unfairly benefit Aboriginal organisations in the Northern Territory to the detriment of those in other parts of Australia, it really becomes pretty obvious that her propositions are quite illogical.

Let me explain why they are. The ILC, newly established, will have $73 million available to it in the two-year period to which the ATSIC decision relates, that is, $25 million from 1994-95 and $24 million for each of 1995-96 and 1996-97 which cannot be used to purchase leases for conversion to inalienable freehold in the Northern Territory under the Northern Territory land rights act. That ought to be clear enough. That is $73 million which, whatever else they can spend it on, certainly cannot be spent in the Northern Territory for the issue that is the nub of concern here, that is to say, the purchase of leases for conversion to inalienable freehold.

The ATSIC board, moreover, has specifically recommended, we understand, that the board of the ILC not approve any land purchases for the Northern Territory over the next two years. While I am obviously reluctant, in the light of various events, to make any predictions at all about the future, I would certainly hope that the ILC will, in considering how it spends its funds over the next two years, focus its attention on land purchases in other parts of the country.

It is a rational decision for the ATSIC board to have come to in the terms that it did. Only three of the 19 commissioners, as I understand it, on the ATSIC board at the time of the decision were from the Northern Territory. That in itself stands in stark contrast to the suggestion here that they were voting for a proposition that was somehow against the interests of their constituents. It beggars belief that that is so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chamarette asked you whether a deal was done.

—There was no deal of which I am aware that has any bearing on this at all. Senator Bob Collins has been more intimately involved in all these matters than I have, but I am not aware of anything that is remotely relevant here. The issue of how much money would be spent by ATSIC in the Northern Territory was canvassed on a number of occasions during debate on the land fund bill, and I have already referred to those particular contributions that I made to the debate.

PARA.TAB: In response to Senator Chamarette's question on this matter on 11 May, I indicated that I did not know whether there were any other understandings or agreements about the way ATSIC was to distribute the $21 million. As far as I was concerned, there was an expectation that there would be a relatively even pattern of distribution, but beyond that I had no knowledge of the background to that—and I still have no knowledge. Again, I can only say that this is a matter for determination by the board itself.

There may well be concern being expressed by the land councils in other parts of the country, and Senator Chamarette has made reference to that, but ATSIC is a representative body and its decisions must be assumed to take account of those interests. The chairperson, Ms O'Donoghue, issued a press release in April explaining some of the factors which the board took into account in coming to its decision. I understand that Senator Chamarette pursued some of these issues in estimates committee hearings on 26 May. I have not seen the text of those exchanges myself. But there it is. The matter speaks for itself.

Finally, it surprises me that Senator Chamarette is so concerned about the ATSIC decision. During the debate on the bill, it might be recalled, she moved amendments to remove the provision which gave effect to the Prime Minister's agreement with Mr Perron that ILC money should not be spent on claimable land in the Northern Territory and in fact condemned that agreement. The one element in the bill which limited the amount of money that could be spent in the Northern Territory she actually sought to remove. Yet she is now accusing the government, on the one hand, of secretly agreeing with the Northern Territory Aboriginals to get around the very agreement that she herself vigorously opposed; on the other hand, she is manipulating decisions within ATSIC to support or substantiate deals made between the Prime Minister and the Chief Minister, a proposition which is simply incredible on the facts.

That is all I can say on this matter. I have no further knowledge of the internal dynamics of the ATSIC board decision and what may have prompted the balance of judgments that were concerned. Senator Bob Collins may well wish to say something further on that subject, but in terms of what I have said to the Senate, in the context in which I have said it, I think the record makes absolutely clear that there is no question whatsoever of misleading the Senate. This censure motion is utterly misconceived and ought to be dealt with accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the contribution of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) to the debate, he claimed that Senator Chamarette's censure motion was utterly without justification. He then repeated wads of Hansard which effectively supported Senator Chamarette's motion. On a number of occasions in October questions were raised by a number of senators at various committee meetings and in the committee of the whole debate in the chamber about what could happen in the Northern Territory as a result of the scheme of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). These questions were responded to by Mr Dillon, the minister and Senator Bob Collins saying that we had nothing to worry about and that this could not happen because ATSIC had all of those other priorities. `Don't worry, that is not the purpose of the scheme. It is a transitional period.'

PARA.TAB: I asked how they could expect senators and the broader Australian community to believe that it took three years to establish a new land fund when they already had one established in ATSIC. I remember mentioning how the Australian Securities Commission took six weeks to move from the old cooperative scheme to the centralised ASC scheme which deals with far more clients than the ILC will ever have to deal with. The claim that Minister Collins made in that debate was a joke. It was unbelievable; it was incredible. It was simply not credible that it required three years.

We argued at the time that, on the government's own evidence, it would spend in excess of $3 million on administration of the new ILC. We said that, if you wanted to ensure Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders benefited from this scheme by owning some land at some stage, you would ensure that as many millions of dollars as possible would go into purchasing land, not paying the salaries of more bureaucrats by way of administrative expenditure. Senator Evans then talked about how the worst had happened in their eyes and assured us that ATSIC would act in a balanced way by meeting its priorities across Australia and by not spending the majority of funds available to ATSIC over the next couple of years in the Northern Territory.

Despite their assumptions that ATSIC would behave with justice and fairness to Aboriginals across Australia when it came to land acquisition and management matters, ATSIC decided to spend $20 million out of the $24 million allocated to land acquisition in this year's budget. That is okay because the Indigenous Land Corporation will have $73 million to purchase land across the rest of Australia, and ATSIC had asked the ILC not to spend any of that money in the Northern Territory. That is fictitious.

Senator Evans would suggest to us that $73 million will be available for land acquisition across Australia. He has misled the Senate, just as Senator Collins did in question time in budget week. That $73 million will not be available for purchase of land across Australia. I will give one good reason—Senator Harradine knows what I am about to say. When we proposed that the government allocate an extra $3 million for administration expenses it said, `That would not be enough for administration. We do not want the ILC board to be constrained by such a harsh, unconscionable cap on its administration expenses.' So $3 million will not be enough for administration. It may well not be enough in the first year, let alone the out years.

In the three years 1994-95, 1995-96 and 1996-97, at least $9 million of the $73 million that Senator Evans has referred to most likely will go to administration. So approximately $64 million will be available to the ILC for land acquisition and management, and its other functions. We would expect, if all this money is going into the Northern Territory over the next two years, that some of that $64 million that remains may be spent on management and other activities such as education—and a range of other activities that the ILC is empowered to undertake.

Senator Evans is now saying, `That is fair enough because ATSIC has asked the ILC board to do this.' The further problem with Senator Evans's justification of this is that the ILC board should not be and will not be constrained by some decision taken by ATSIC on the casting vote of the chairman, Lois O'Donoghue. ATSIC has said to the ILC, `We ask you to do this.'

We heard yesterday that David Ross has been appointed as chairman of the ILC board. Mr Ross is a distinguished and active member of ATSIC. Therefore, he may plead with the ILC board. Lois O'Donoghue is on that board, as are a number of other people who have close links to ATSIC. They will use their powers of persuasion, which I am sure Lois and David have, to convince the ILC board that it should not spend any money in the Northern Territory on acquisition or management, even though we will see $20 million in land purchases in the Northern Territory in the next two years. They will say that no ILC money should be spent—that is, if Senator Evans is to be believed. I put it to the Senate that we cannot believe him on these issues. He may be earnest but we cannot believe what he says because he is saying that out of all the money the ILC has available, in three financial years not a lousy cent will be spent on management in the Northern Territory; it will be spent everywhere else or it will be spent on land acquisition.

I am sure a lot of people in the Northern Territory will not be happy with that. Maybe Mr Ross and Mr Pearce will be happy but I am sure a lot of other people, whom Senator Collins would know better than I, would not be very happy at all with that. Senator Evans blames Senator Chamarette for being unfair to the Northern Territory Aboriginal community and there are many people in the Northern Territory who would be just as upset about this decision of ATSIC as would my constituents in the Swan Valley or in the south-west of Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is democracy, Senator.

—That is a form of democracy, just as the Senate is. We know what the Prime Minister thinks of democracy in the Senate. We know how the Prime Minister describes the representative nature of senators. Probably many Aboriginal people around Australia would have similar views about the representative nature of ATSIC. But I do not reflect on that because all Aboriginal people do have the opportunity to be involved in the democratic processes of ATSIC. Many of them are involved and work very hard at that quite noble public pursuit.

PARA.TAB: Leaving all of that aside, if you agree with Senator Evans that not a single cent of that $64 million over the next three years will be spent in the Northern Territory on land acquisition and that indeed the land management money that is coming out of ATSIC will not go to the Northern Territory—which I am sure it should and would—then $20 million of the maximum $64 million available for land acquisition will come from ATSIC. I am sure Senator Collins would not want to see all of the first three years budget of the ILC going into land acquisition and none of it into management. He can perhaps address that when he responds in this debate.

Senator Evans's proposal is that $64 million will be available across the rest of Australia. But there is $20 million available for land acquisition in the territory in the next two years and $64 million available for land acquisition and management across Australia in the same period. So in the order of 25 per cent to 30 per cent of all money available for land acquisition is being spent in the Northern Territory.
I move to away from Senator Evans's contribution to the debate. I reiterate the concerns that were placed on the record during the various parts of the debate on the so-called land fund.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I draw your attention to the state of the house, which includes only one person on the government side supporting the ministers who are under attack.

—I was relating to the Senate the discussion that took place during the various stages of the debate on the land fund bill. Mr Hatton, the Minister for Aboriginal Development from the Northern Territory, raised concerns about the device, which we suggest and as Senator Chamarette's censure motion suggests is the product of a deal. Firstly, there was a letter to Marshall Perron, the then Chief Minister in the Northern Territory, saying that the money going to the land fund would not create an increase in the land claimed under that territory's land rights legislation. Secondly, as will be referred to in a motion to be moved by Senator Chamarette later today seeking the tabling of documents, there was a very private and secret deal made with a small handful of so-called Aboriginal land fund negotiators. It is clear from the ATSIC policy document, which has already been tabled in this place, I understand, that there was, if not a deal and a handshake with the Prime Minister—
—Rubbish!
—We will see whether it is rubbish because sooner or later the Prime Minister—
—It is a conspiracy theory put out by the New South Wales land council and their mouthpiece.

—We know about the consultation on the land fund bill. You sent out letters across Australia saying, `This is the land fund bill, hope you like it.' A small meeting was held. I am trying to ascertain the date. Mr Dillon might even be able to pass you a note and tell you when it was, Senator Collins.
—June 1994. These are the meetings you said never took place.

—No. We know there was a meeting. We have heard about your consultation and we have discussed that for months. We know about the sort of consultation. Your consultation was that you said that you consulted with Dickie Cox in Western Australia. You wrote Dickie a letter on 6 July and said, `Here's a copy of the land fund bill.' We know about those negotiations and we know who you had them with. But we also know there was a meeting in June and we know who was there because Mr Dillon and the leader of the government very kindly gave us a full list of who was consulted.
—Ask Aden Ridgeway—he was there.

—Aden Ridgeway was there. When we were up at Senator Tambling's electorate and your own electorate, Minister, we asked the Aboriginal people at the hearing of the Senate select committee with whom this was discussed.
—Did you talk to Darryl Pearce?

—We did. Darryl was there—Darryl was giving evidence. Senator Chamarette will remember this. There were probably 50 or 60 people in the hall up there during that hot January day when I asked how many people around Darwin had been consulted on the land fund bill, because we had a list. And, of course, no-one stuck up their hands except for Darryl who said, `I was consulted.' I said, `Darryl, you were lucky.' There were two people in Darwin consulted on this bill: Darryl and Marshall. Senator Chamarette will remember that because it actually created a lot of amusement for the Aboriginal people in the hall that day. They were consulted! We know, because Marshall Perron and Steve Hatton have put on the record the basis of their consultations and they have now publicly stated that they believe that they had been `legged over' by the Prime Minister. He looked them in the eye, he probably shook their hand and he wrote them a letter saying, `Don't worry, you've got no concerns. There's not going to be,' to quote Senator Evans's words, `open slather for purchase and conversion to land rights land in the Northern Territory.'
—Rubbish! This is fantasy. It never happened.
—You say it is rubbish. Let us just quote then what Senator Evans said on 9 November in this chamber.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: I again draw your attention to the state of the house. There is still only one member behind the government minister who is defending him from serious censure.

—For the benefit of those many people who, I am sure, are driving into Perth along Mounts Bay Road to work at 20 to nine and who are tuned into this broadcast, I will reiterate what happened just before Senator Harradine drew attention to the state of the house. Senator Collins, who is suffering one of the worst and most important censures in his career, has sitting behind him his honourable colleagues Senator Foreman and Senator Jones. There is no-one else except for Senator Sue West, who is about to leave him all by himself to weather the onslaught of this censure.
—Where are your colleagues?

—They are all here; they are all with us. When I quoted what Senator Evans said, that he was not prepared to allow open slather in the Northern Territory, and that is the commitment that the government had given to Marshall Perron, the then Chief Minister in the Northern Territory, Senator Collins said, `Rubbish.'
—Rubbish! Wrong again.

—I am glad Senator Collins said that again. Let me quote what Senator Evans said on 9 November. We will not listen to Senator Collins because we know that what he says sometimes does not come to pass. Sometimes he says, `We'll get things done and if we don't, I'll resign,' but he is still here. We know about the state of waterfront reform. He said, `If we don't reform the waterfront, I'll resign.' He should go down to Fremantle today and see the state of his waterfront reform. Great reform, minister! What did Senator Evans say about the conversion of pastoral leases to freehold in the Northern Territory? He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We are not prepared to allow the potential for open slather on conversions to inalienable freehold prior to the cut-off for claims.
He said that with reference to the commitments made to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. I again quote from the Hansard of 9 November 1994:

The government has agreed with the Northern Territory government that the allocation of new moneys to the land fund should not lead to an increase in the amount of land claimed under the land rights act . . .

That is the agreement. Senator Evans may have had it wrong when he said that on 9 November. He does get it wrong quite often. But this is what he said: word for word, he said that the new money would not lead to an increase in land claimed under the land rights legislation.

PARA.TAB: The reality we are faced with today is that the allocation of new money—and I do not want to be pedantic about new money or old money—going to the land fund, as a result of the device created by the Prime Minister to get around the commitment he had given to the Northern Territory government, means that the amount of land claimed in the Northern Territory and able to be converted to inalienable freehold title will increase. Senator Evans said that the new moneys given to the land fund should not lead to an increase in the amount of land claimed.

The indisputable fact is that, of course, that is exactly what will occur. That is the reason that the Green senators, Senator Harradine, coalition senators, the Chief Minister and Steve Hatton, the Minister for Aboriginal Development in the Northern Territory, all raised these concerns. They were genuine concerns. They were concerns that Senator Collins shared, because he goes on ad nauseam about the sort of problems that can occur in the Northern Territory with a massive transfer of Northern Territory land into inalienable freehold. That is a debate that has gone on over and over. We do not want to debate that here today. But the reality is that these were problems which were raised by a range of people. Of course, what the coalition and the Greens raised as a concern at that time, as did the Northern Territory government, has come to pass.

The other matter that I wanted to deal with in the time remaining to me is Senator Collins's defence during question time in answer to a question by me in relation to this decision by ATSIC—that is, that I had it wrong, that it was not $20 million out of $24 million that was available for land acquisition in the Northern Territory. Let us just pin that one right down. Let us look at what Senator Collins said. He said, `No, it's $42 million available for the purchase of land.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Over two years.
—Forty-two million dollars available over two years. We said that there was $24 million available for land acquisition over two years.
—Only as a result of the decision by the ATSIC board.

—If I were placed in your situation two or three weeks ago, having to try to defend ATSIC's decision and trying to muddy the waters in relation to my figures, I would have done what you did. I would have said, `No, you've got it all wrong. There is $42 million available for land acquisition.' Of course, that would be and could be true if ATSIC did not need to devote money for land management.
—They didn't in 1991. The lion's share went to acquisition. Have you had a look at the record? They can spend it all on land if they want.

—The money spent in the Northern Territory in 1991-92 was $980,712. The money spent in the Northern Territory for land acquisition and management in 1993-94 was $2.3 million. It did much better in the intervening year; it got $10 million. Senator Collins would be right if no money were spent on management. I ask him in his response in this debate to say whether he thinks it is even practical or vaguely sensible that you should even make that assumption.
—You know my views on that.

—I do; but what you were saying in question time three weeks ago was that I had it all wrong, because ATSIC could have decided to spend $42 million in two years. We know the decision made by ATSIC is bizarre. We know it is a decision that is wrong in terms of equity for Aboriginal people across Australia. But Senator Collins is saying that that is okay because they did not have to spend $20 million in the next two years, they could have spent $40 million. They could have spent $42 million, all buying up the Northern Territory. That is a possibility.

PARA.TAB: It is worth noting what was said by no lesser figure than David Ross, the new chairman of the Indigenous Land Corporation, in relation to management in response to a question from Senator Chamarette in relation to the sensible balance between acquisition and management during a hearing of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. Senator Chamarette was advocating during that debate that more money be spent on acquisition than on management. That is something I disagree very strongly with her on.

David Ross makes the point that of course management is a crucial part of any land acquisition and management program. There is no use buying up large tracts of land anywhere in Australia unless the Aboriginal people who hold those lands can be assured of having ongoing financial support—and some of that must indeed come from the Commonwealth and other governments—to ensure that those properties remain viable, that their communities as a result of that remain viable and that their economic, social and cultural wellbeing is enhanced as a result of those programs. That is something which I think there is absolute cross-partisan support for in this chamber. Mr Ross actually reveals the sorts of demands on ATSIC's land acquisition management program funds, and that will of course be on the ILC in terms of funding that is available to it, when he says, `On this year's figures alone we probably need somewhere in the order of $15 million for land management.' That is $15 million out of an annual budget in the order of $20-odd million. He states, `We have decided not to put $15 million out of ATSIC's funds into land management. For this financial year we have put in $8 1/2 million.' He is talking about the then financial year. He also states, `We are quite a deal short. Maybe the ILC will look favourably at topping up the land management funds.' So again he quite sensibly stresses the importance of money going into land management.

The long-term problem that will be created by the government's deception and the deception by both the minister in the chamber, Senator Collins, and his leader, Senator Gareth Evans, is that, if we put this massive distortion of funds into one part of Australia, albeit a very large part of Australia and a very large part of Aboriginal Australia, and therefore, in terms of acquisition over the next two years, deprive those Aboriginal people living in Western Australia, South Australia, Victoria, Tasmania, which you should never forget in terms of Aboriginal land needs, New South Wales and the Torres Strait Islanders—and we can try to justify it as Senator Gareth Evans did by saying, `There will be $64 million available for land acquisition and management for the rest of Australia during that period'—we will distort forever the balance in terms of equity and the raw square metres or square kilometres owned or controlled by Aboriginal people in one part of Australia. We will therefore create a distortion in the land management fund's needs for the whole of Australia for a long time into the future—10, 20 or 30 years. We will never be able to judge that.

As Tracker Tilmouth said to us, and I am sure Tracker said it publicly on many occasions, much of the land we are looking at in the Northern Territory does need quite intensive management. Senator Collins would know a lot more about that than I do because I have made only fleeting visits to the Northern Territory, and that is something that I regret. I would love to spend a lot more time up there because it is a beautiful, fascinating place. The land up there is very fragile and very old and it requires special management needs, particularly if it is going to be used for productive enterprise, but equally so if it is simply to ensure that the environment is protected. As Tracker makes a point of mentioning quite often, a lot of this land is simply not, in his judgment, suitable for pastoral production and should be managed for conservation, tourism and other land use matters.

The reality, therefore, is that we will have this distortion created by the government's deception and the minister's deceptions, created by this corrupt—`corrupt' is probably too strong a word—stupid, short-sighted decision by ATSIC. It is certainly an unfair decision for the rest of Australian Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders. It will ensure that for 10, 20 or 30 years into the future there will have to be a distortion of appropriations from the ILC to ensure that the land that is acquired in the Northern Territory in the coming two-year period, where ATSIC's decision will come into play, is managed properly.

This is not something that should be swept under the carpet. The government ministers' involvement in this distortion and this deception of the Senate and, of course, the unanswered questions about the Prime Minister's secret deal with this small team of Aboriginal negotiators is something that will create inequity for Aboriginal people for many generations to come. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —This censure motion is in the great tradition of political censures in the Senate. If this censure motion that has been moved against the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) and me were based on a substantive matter of misleading the parliament, I would be gravely concerned about it. I happen to have great regard for the parliamentary institution. As the public record will show, the point I have made on many occasions—and I am glad to make it again here in the chamber—is that with all of the faults and failings of the parliamentary system, it is still a matter of fact that the charge of misleading the parliament is still the gravest charge that can be made against a minister. If it is proven, it claims a scalp. It still does in Australia, I am pleased to say. I have made that comment many times publicly.

PARA.TAB: In terms of a substantive censure motion based on real evidence and truth, rather than anecdotal nonsense that has been fed to Senator Chamarette by the quarters that I know fed it to her, I am not going to lose one minute's sleep over this censure motion being carried, which it will be. It will be carried in the great tradition of political censures in the Senate and the opportunistic way in which the opposition has decided to join the only two votes it needs in here to get it carried.

I do want to make the point that I stand in here on matters of Aboriginal affairs without fear or favour to anyone. I do not represent any vested interest in this chamber on Aboriginal affairs and never have. As my colleague Senator Tambling will be able to attest, I have been in strife from time to time with the Northern Territory land councils. I see him smiling because he can recall it. Indeed, I have been in some severe conflict with them. Without fear or favour and despite the political consequences available to them against me, I have criticised things they have done in the Northern Territory and, I might add, applauded and complimented them from time to time on things that they do.

The reason I raise this is that Senator Chamarette is not in the same happy position. Senator Chamarette's motives have to be placed on the record in this censure debate. I do not think those motives reflect very well on Senator Chamarette. Senator Chamarette has had a consistently anti-ATSIC agenda that she has represented in this chamber and elsewhere. She is entitled to have that, but I disagree with it. That prejudice and personal idiosyncrasy of Senator Chamarette's has been demonstrated many times in here.

Senator Chamarette has an anti-land council agenda, with the exception of the people who control her in the Senate—the New South Wales Land Council. She is a puppet of the New South Wales Land Council and a mouthpiece for the New South Wales Land Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy President. I would like you to rule on whether or not that is reflecting on the motives and integrity of a senator. I am sure it can be a debating point that can probably be responded to. To accuse someone of not coming to this chamber with a sense of impartiality and coming in here as an agent for someone is a gross reflection on a senator's integrity and should be withdrawn.

—On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I do feel that the minister should perhaps reflect on what he did say. As I have it down, he said that Senator Chamarette is the puppet of the New South Wales Land Council in this place and is under the control of the New South Wales Land Council.
—That's what I said.

—You should be ashamed of it because that is a gross reflection on the integrity of a member of this place. I put it to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that that goes beyond a debating point; it goes to the very heart and nature of this place itself.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—On the point of order I rule, on the basis of past rulings, that the Minister's comments are unparliamentary, and I would seek his withdrawal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I of course withdraw, but I am certainly not ashamed of making those comments because the very strong agenda that Senator Chamarette runs for the New South Wales Land Council has been revealed in this chamber many times. But I certainly withdraw the—
—I rise again on a point of order. I do not regard it as an unqualified withdrawal when the Minister gets up and says that he is not ashamed of what he said.
—I'm not, but I have withdrawn.
—Is that, or isn't it, an unqualified withdrawal?
—I would suggest that that was not an unqualified withdrawal.

—I withdraw. The agenda that Senator Chamarette has run in here—which has been strongly anti-ATSIC, and she makes no bones about it—has to be placed on the public record in this chamber. Indeed, it now has been placed on the public record in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: One of my colleagues, Kim Beazley, on one occasion remarked to me that he had been censured in the Senate but that he did not find out about it for three weeks, so censures in the Senate, unfortunately, have not come to be regarded in very good light because so often they have been political censures rather than censures on the facts. But, Senator Harradine, this motion, if it is to be a real motion, and this censure motion, if it is to be treated properly and is not to degrade and devalue the currency of censure motions in the way that has become commonplace in this chamber, has to stand or fall on the terms of the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did Richo say about that?

—I will come to the word you used, Senator Campbell, when you spoke in here. I am talking about this motion, Senator, and it has to stand or fall on its merits. I will go through this motion to point out how false and flawed it is. The words `deception' and `misleading' have been used freely and consistently in this chamber. As I said before, no-one in the parliamentary system has a greater regard for the importance of ministers not misleading a chamber on a matter of fact, and for the convention that the minister's attention should be drawn to a wrong piece of information that he has given and that he should take the first opportunity to correct it, than I have. I have adhered to that throughout my entire parliamentary career.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the terms of the motion to see whether these assertions should be fairly considered by this chamber to be matters of fact to justify the grave charges, so devalued in here, of misleading a house or of deception. `Deception' is a very strong word, indeed, Senator Harradine, and one which I would fairly and courteously suggest to you is probably as substantial an impugning of someone's motives as you could get. But I took that in good stride and I did not dispute it. Let us look at (a):
(a) on 11th May 1995 Senator Collins said that Senator Campbell was wrong—

SPEECH.PARA: Et cetera. It then quotes what I said. The principal issue is that $42 million is available to ATSIC for land acquisition, not $21 million. That is absolutely correct; that is a matter of fact.

PARA.TAB: As a value judgment, and Senator Campbell is correct in saying this, I have a strong view—in so far as I am able to provide it because I cannot direct ATSIC as to how it makes decisions—that ATSIC should devote a substantial proportion of its land acquisition and management funds to management rather than acquisition. In this house I have pointed out before, without fear or favour, that in my view some of the major failures of the past in the Northern Territory, particularly with pastoral properties, have been due to the fact that almost all of the money has been spent on acquisition—which it is open to ATSIC to do, and that is the point I was making—rather than management. In recent years, and just in recent years—this year and last year—I have been pleased to see, and the record demonstrates this, a greater concentration by ATSIC on management funds than ever before.

I have said in this chamber before, and Senator Campbell will recall it, that one of the things I lobbied very hard in Cabinet for—make no bones about this—was that, when the land fund was created, specific reference to land management, as opposed to land acquisition alone, should be part of ATSIC's charter. As for my deceiving the Senate, it is a fact that it is open to ATSIC to devote every cent of this money to land acquisition, if it chose to do so. There is no hindrance to ATSIC doing that. The record demonstrates that in the past it has devoted the lion's share of this same fund to land acquisition rather than management.

The decision this time to devote $9 million to management sees the largest proportion of money ATSIC has ever devoted to management. In 1990-91 almost all of the fund went to acquisition. In 1991-92, again, almost all of it went to acquisition. In 1992-93, again, the lion's share of it went to acquisition, not management. Those are the figures. It is only this year and last year, I am pleased to say, that ATSIC has determined, as it has the right to do, to devote a greater proportion to management than it has before.

It is open to ATSIC to spend all of the fund—its early practice was to spend almost all of it—on acquisition rather than management. That is the point Senator Chamarette simply does not want to accept. It has been made clear in statements by Lois O'Donoghue that that is the case. I have already tabled her press statement. It is accurate and confirms what I have said about the management break-up of the money and the historical pattern of spending in the Northern Territory. I table it again.

The first point of Senator Chamarette's motion falls flat. I make no bones about it: I agree with Senator Campbell that, as a value judgment, it would be very unwise of ATSIC to spend all the fund on land acquisition. I would stand up here and say that, as I have stood up here without fear or favour and expressed my concern about the recent decision ATSIC did take. I did that knowing it would get me some flak from the Northern Territory land councils. But that is a value judgment we are entitled to make in here. It is a value judgment I gave in the Senate during the debate. That is all it was, as the Hansard record clearly indicates. There was no misleading of the Senate.

I am pleased to see that all of the newspaper reports on this issue have correctly carried the assertion I made that `it was not likely' that ATSIC would do this. I made that assertion on the basis, which Senator Evans also recognised, that there are three people from the Northern Territory on the board of ATSIC. I assumed that they would not have the persuasive powers to persuade a necessary majority of the board to make the decision it ultimately did. I expressed my concern about that at the time and I still do.

The fact that my judgment on this issue was not entirely warped is revealed by the extensive controversy the decision has caused within ATSIC. As I have already told the chamber, Lois O'Donoghue is a woman I respect greatly and I did her the courtesy of ringing her before I canvassed that matter in this place. When I found out that the decision had been made on a casting vote of the chair—the first and, to my knowledge, the only time in ATSIC's history that a casting vote has been used—I was concerned about it, and I expressed that concern in this chamber. That is a matter of fact. There was no misleading of the Senate.

It is open to ATSIC to spend all of this money on acquisition, should it choose to do so. It is within its charter. I would disagree with it so doing but that is a value judgment I make in here. I cannot direct ATSIC not to do it. So the first assertion made in the censure motion is wrong.
I come now to part (b) of the motion. Again, this shows the bizarre interpretation that Senator Chamarette has placed on the words used. On 9 November Senator Evans stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The government has agreed with the Northern Territory government that the allocation of new moneys to the land fund—
not ATSIC—
should not lead to an increase in the amount of land claimed under the land rights act . . .

Clearly, he was talking about the land fund. There was a grave concern to ensure that this land fund, which will be funded for land acquisition to a substantially greater level than ATSIC has ever been, should not be able to purchase properties in the Northern Territory and convert them to inalienable freehold title.

PARA.TAB: That was the undertaking that the Prime Minister has given—the only undertaking that he has ever given to the Northern Territory government—and he has discharged it. Senator Chamarette can sit there shaking her head for as long as she likes.

I was warned. My office received a telephone call from Cathcart and Cathcart told my adviser that he and you—or the Greens—would `pursue' me to eternity on this issue. The prospect of being pursued to eternity by Senator Chamarette and Cathcart does not disturb me all that much. But nevertheless, I know the obsession that Senator Chamarette has with her interpretation of these events; it has been relayed directly to my office. All I am saying is that Senator Chamarette has placed a bizarre interpretation on this; an interpretation similar to that which has been placed on it by the New South Wales Land Council. As we speak, the New South Wales Land Council is taking legal action to contest the decision. It is in the federal court now.

I would have thought that Senator Chamarette would have waited until there is a determination—which I do not think will be long coming—on that matter. The New South Wales Land Council is entitled to take that legal action. As I have told the Senate, this was a controversial suggestion within ATSIC. It is a matter of public knowledge that it was a split decision and it was determined on the casting vote of the chair of ATSIC. I have expressed my concern about that.

It is not impossible that ATSIC, in its own democratic forum, may perhaps reconsider this decision at some future time. Senator Chamarette is nodding assent to that. The question of the determination of ATSIC and Senator Chamarette's anti-ATSIC agenda—which is a very public one—needs to be canvassed. There may be many decisions of ATSIC that I disagree with, and I will say so in here, as I have in the past. But it is a democratically elected body—unique in that sense—with elections run by the Australian Electoral Office on exactly the same basis as this parliament is elected. ATSIC is the only other organisation in Australia that has a national election that is similar to ours. It is a democratic vote.

If Aboriginal people disagree with this decision—and many of them do in the Northern Territory—they will have an opportunity at the next ATSIC election to cast a vote that reflects that. That is democracy. One cannot stand in here and say, `We should direct them'. That is what Senator Chamarette is saying; it is on the record in the chamber. She says that we should direct ATSIC to change this decision because we disagree with it. That is very democratic! That is great support for Aboriginal self determination! It is the old white support for blacks: `We agree with you as long as you agree with us, and when you do not agree with us, even if we think the decision is dreadfully bad, we will direct you to change it'. They are the words that Senator Chamarette has used. She has called on the government to direct ATSIC—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise to a point of order. I ask the minister to table any speech I have ever made in which I requested that ATSIC be directed to do anything. I ask Senator Collins to table it.
—No.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—That is not a point of order. It is a point of debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not be directing ATSIC. I think it is highly likely that ATSIC will reconsider this decision in the light of the controversy that is raging around it. I did not even know about it until Senator Campbell kindly told me about it on the basis of papers that he had leaked to him from ATSIC. As I said here in the parliament, the fact that papers were leaked to Senator Campbell is an indication that there were unhappy people inside ATSIC.
