But that is a value judgment that we are entitled to make. It does amount to misleading this parliament. There was no misleading of the parliament, Senator Chamarette. There is no justification for this censure on the grounds of `deception and misleading the parliament'.

PARA.TAB: I said that in my view—and the newspapers have correctly reported it—it was likely that the ATSIC board would not do this. I based that opinion on that fact that three commissioners out of the 19 are from the Northern Territory. I completely underrated the persuasive powers of territorians both black and white. We are a pretty powerful bunch and we are obviously able to sway opinion.

It is a matter of public record, and you know that Senator Chamarette. But despite saying all of that, I have, as I am entitled to do, publicly expressed my concern about that decision. That deals with (a) and (b). No undertaking was given that the ATSIC funds would be constrained. The undertaking was that the land fund would not be allowed to be used for a big land grab in the Northern Territory which could then be converted to inalienable title.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what Gareth said.
—That is your bizarre interpretation of it. The clear meaning is that the land fund would not be used. That undertaking was given and it has been discharged.

PARA.TAB: Now I turn to the most serious part of this censure motion—and it is the most serious part. It is bizarre. It is false. It is utterly untrue. The most serious part of this censure motion is the suggestion that the briefing paper reveals that an agreement had been struck with the Prime Minister, ATSIC and a group of indigenous land bodies singling out the Northern Territory for special treatment for land acquisitions. That is a conspiracy theory which I know is being run by the New South Wales—

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the document.

—I have read the document. You read it and then have a look at the decisions that were taken. This secret meeting was in a room jammed full of people! I know many who were in there. Daryl Pearce, who was there—and I am sure he would not have the slightest difficulty with my placing this on the public record—made the point to me that not only was this charge absolutely and categorically false, and not only did the Prime Minister say nothing of the sort, but that the only people who are making these assertions are people who were not there.

PARA.TAB: I will tell you who was there—Aden Ridgeway from the New South Wales Land Council. It is a fact that, at the end of the meeting, he said that he opposed the bill. Indeed, the Greens opposed it, even though the opposition did not oppose the bill in here. The New South Wales Land Council did not want the bill, so the Greens opposed it—to hell with all the other land councils around Australia and to hell with all the other Aboriginal people who actually wanted it. Because the New South Wales Land Council did not want it, the Greens actually voted against it. The Hansard record shows that.

Aden Ridgeway did register his objection to the bill and his objection to what was agreed to at that meeting. This agreement was reached in front of a room full of people, not just representatives of Aboriginal organisations but also their advisers and ministerial advisers. There was no secret meeting and no wink, wink, nudge, nudge suggestion from the Prime Minister, which is what you have asserted on the basis of no evidence whatever. What was agreed to was this: a transitional period of two years after 1994-95 during which ATSIC would continue to receive $21 million for land acquisition and management. That is the agreement referred to in the ATSIC papers.

Senator Chamarette, take your warped glasses off, re-read the ATSIC papers and consider what I have just said to you. That is what that referred to. It was not a reference to some conspiracy theory of an agreement. It was a reference to the agreement that was reached in those negotiations—negotiations which, of course, the Greens and the opposition said had never happened. The agreement reached was that there would be a transitional arrangement for two years whereby ATSIC would continue to be able to acquire land and manage it. I have spoken to the people who made the decision, Senator Chamarette, and that is what that reference in the ATSIC papers is a reference to.

There was no wink, wink, nudge, nudge agreement, as you have asserted on the basis of no evidence at all. I might add that the Prime Minister, in a room full of people, is asserted to have said, `You can ramp up some crook decision on ATSIC that will be okay.' Nothing of the sort happened. In fact, Daryl Pearce got very angry about it. He said to me, `I was there. It did not happen. The only people who are making these assertions are people who were not there.' It did not happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —At that meeting.

—There is another meeting now, is there, Senator Campbell? Perhaps you should bring another motion in here then. Frankly, Senator Campbell, that is weak, and it indicates how flawed this censure motion is when you say that there must have been another meeting. The Prime Minister gave no undertaking nor made any decision in respect of how much ATSIC should set aside for land acquisition in the Northern Territory. What is more, it is obvious he had absolutely no capacity to even do so. The suggestion that the Prime Minister could do a deal of the kind alleged by Senator Chamarette is just not credible.

PARA.TAB: The publicly known facts of the board's decision were tied, as I have said before, with the one and only casting vote in ATSIC's history carried on that basis. To even suggest that happened in the face of that publicly known evidence is ludicrous. It was a highly controversial decision and carried only on a casting vote. As I told this chamber, I took the trouble and the courtesy to ring Lois O'Donoghue personally to express my concern about that decision before I did so in this chamber. The ATSIC board made its own decision on how it would allocate the funds. The basis of the board's decision was set out in the chairperson's press statement released on 11 April, which I have tabled for the second time.

I know that Senator Chamarette does not want to accept the facts contained in Lois O'Donoghue's press statement. That is fair enough. She can say so. But to censure three ministers, including the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Government in the Senate, on the basis of suggestions of deception, duplicity and misleading when clearly nothing of the sort occurred is just a nonsense. It is a political censure of the Senate, not a real one. This is the most serious part of Senator Chamarette's censure and is the only part which applies to the Prime Minister. Having spoken to the people who were in the room, even though I thought the suggestion was bizarre in the first place, I can assure Senator Chamarette that it is false. It did not happen. Many witnesses have asserted that it did not happen. Senator Campbell's riposte by interjection that there must have been another meeting is false.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say that; you said that.

—The Hansard record will show it, and if you are contesting it I will check the tapes afterwards. I clearly heard what you said. Senator Chamarette should produce evidence that supports this very brave charge against the Prime Minister that warrants his censure in this parliament. Why don't you ring up Daryl Pearce and the people present at that meeting where all of this was thrashed out? There was no other meeting where a deal was done. It was a negotiation where concessions were made. One of the concessions was that ATSIC would have a transitional role to play for two years in acquiring land. That occurred as a result of those negotiations. Aden Ridgeway disagreed with it and said at the end of the meeting that he opposed the entire bill, which is something the Greens subsequently did in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: I think the Hansard will show, unless Senator Chamarette can come up with some information or some documents that she has not produced so far, that this censure motion is not deserved. The information that I and Senator Evans gave this Senate is absolutely correct. It was open to ATSIC to spend all that money. The historical record of its spending indicates that only in the last two years has it spent any money on management at all. I am pleased that is happening. I would have disagreed with ATSIC if it had made a decision to spend it all to ramp up the acquisitions in the territory. I would have disagreed with ATSIC, but it was open for it to do so because it is a democratically elected board. This parliament has given ATSIC the right to make democratic decisions and us the right to publicly disagree with them when they are made.

The gravest charge made on this piece of paper—the only charge levelled against the Prime Minister that warrants his censure by the Senate—is utterly false. The Prime Minister has said so categorically. The people who attended the meeting have said so categorically and have made the point that the only people asserting this are people who were not there. This censure motion is based on nothing except Senator Chamarette's prejudices and deserves to fail. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are addressing today a censure motion against the Prime Minister, Mr Keating; the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans; and the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal affairs, Senator Collins, who is also a Northern Territory Labor Party senator. What Senator Collins has just said—he made light of this matter—was a special Joan Sutherland like performance. It sounded musical, it sounded theatrical; but it was very difficult to make sense of the words in plain English.

PARA.TAB: When we address the censure motion before us, it is important to note that each of the three points raised by Senator Chamarette concern land acquisition in the Northern Territory—and the action of government. Senator Collins made a lot of trying to defend the actions of ATSIC and trying to look at the issues that have been taken on by the management of ATSIC. That is not the issue of this motion; and I think that is important.

The first part of Senator Chamarette's motion shows very clearly where Senator Collins had been misleading in his statements. Certainly we know that Senator Collins always gets up in the morning and talks to the mirror; goes on doing that all day, and very seldom talks to anybody else.

The second part of Senator Chamarette's motion is about where Senator Evans has misled this Senate and been inconsistent. I will quote from what Senator Evans has said in Senate debates, going back several years. I will quote some words he said which also complement and compound those that have been outlined by Senator Chamarette in her censure motion. The third part of the censure motion refers to the Prime Minister's involvement. Essentially, he has been part of it, in approving the budget process of approving funding allocated to ATSIC.

Let me put this matter in context. On 25 October 1993, in the lead-up to the debate on the Native Title Bill, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Marshall Perron, wrote to the Prime Minister. I will quote parts of that letter. He issued a very substantive warning that reflects on this motion here today. Mr Perron said:

SPEECH.PARA: In the Northern Territory, unlike the other States, because of the Land Rights Act, your proposal will result in the purchase and subsequent conversion of productive pastoral land to inalienable freehold. Not only will there then be no obligation to maintain the land as a pastoral venture, but the Act means the veto will apply, there will be no power of acquisition and uncertainty as to whether Territory laws can be fully enforced on that land. Your provision of vastly increased funding and compensation payments for validation will greatly accelerate that process.
Further in the same letter Mr Perron stated:

The land of the territory was granted upon Self Government for the benefit of all Territorians. It has already been significantly reduced and further conversions of pastoral leases will exacerbate the problem. Your proposal overlooks the Territory Government's repeated appeals to you and your predecessors to put a halt to the conversion of the pastoral estate in the Territory.

The difficulties faced by the Territory were recognised in 1983 by Mr Justice Toohey in his review of the Land Rights Act entitled `Seven Years On'. He noted, after only two pastoral properties had been purchased, that there was no case at that time for precluding future claims to pastoral leases and he went on to state "if, at some future time, more pastoral leases have been acquired by or on behalf of Aboriginals and real problems have arisen in regard to the operation of laws of the Northern Territory and the prohibition against mining, this matter may need to be reconsidered".

Earlier Justice Woodward recognised the potential difficulties which would be caused by claims over pastoral leases. He said "It is my own belief that claims carrying varying degrees of conviction could and would be brought forward in relation to almost all the pastoral properties of the Territory".
The letter continues:

In 1985 the then Minister for Aboriginal affairs, Mr Clyde Holding, stated that the "Government would not allow the continuation of the present arrangements whereby pastoral leases could be acquired on the open market and then converted to inalienable freehold title. . . .".

They were substantive warnings that were given in 1993 by the then Chief Minister to the Prime Minister. I followed that up in the native title debate in November of that year. In the committee stage of that debate, I asked Senator Evans a question, and this impinges on the second part of this censure motion. I asked:

PARA.TAB: Given that for the last number of years the federal government has been saying that it would amend the Aboriginal Land Rights Act to preclude the conversion of pastoral leases under the Northern Territory act, I am keen to establish how the minister sees these two pieces of legislation working in parallel or working with some degree of compatibility. Given that there are quite extenuating circumstances, will there now be a slush fund that will enable the purchase of more properties?

SPEECH.PARA: I asked this question on 20 December 1993. Very interestingly, Senator Evans replied:

The Northern Territory government—Senator Tambling is obviously following that position—has expressed concerns that the land fund under the legislation we are debating now will be used to convert pastoral leases to inalienable title under the Northern Territory act and hence take advantage of the veto provisions that are associated with that.
He went on to say:

PARA.TAB: It is my understanding that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has indicated to the Northern Territory Chief Minister, Mr Perron, that we will not necessarily allow the land fund under this act to be used in this way. My understanding is that there has been some communication of that kind and that that has also been repeated to the Aboriginal negotiators on the subject.

SPEECH.PARA: That is Senator Evans in December 1993. I move on almost a year to when we were embroiled in the debate in this chamber on the indigenous land fund. Senator Collins needs to go back and look in his mirror because he obviously does not remember what he said. I remind Senator Collins of what he did say on 16 November last year here in the Senate. He was referring to Senator Chamarette and the very important issues that were under consideration. Senator Collins said:

. . . I am prepared to bet Senator Chamarette a huge sum of money—any sum she would like to name—that the prospect of ATSIC's land acquisition funds exclusively being devoted to land purchases in the Northern Territory is a highly unlikely scenario indeed.

PARA.TAB: What I confidently predict will happen is that the pattern of purchases by ATSIC over the next three years in the Northern Territory will continue very largely as it has since ATSIC was set up, because the same balance of power exists on the commission.

SPEECH.PARA: So much for Senator Collins's argument. He cannot even go back and remember what he said in November of last year, because further in that same debate he also said:

PARA.TAB: So far as the transitional arrangements are concerned, I believe they have considerable merit in allowing ATSIC, after a long period of being in the land acquisition business, to gradually wind down its operations over that period while at the same time allowing the ILC to establish its expertise. The government is absolutely assured by ATSIC that there will be no difficulty at all with these transitional arrangements being handled professionally, competently and cooperatively by the Aboriginal organisations concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collins today came in here and did a 180-degree turn on those comments he made back in November. Very obviously he gets tripped up by his own rhetoric or by the various arias that he puts out like Joan Sutherland.

PARA.TAB: Earlier this month when this issue was being considered here just after the budget and Senator Chamarette had raised it, the then Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Marshall Perron, attacked ATSIC's decision to spend its land fund money for the next two years solely in the territory. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We have been warning that this would happen for many months but it was denied on all sides from the Prime Minister down.
Because the Territory has to exist under two sets of land rights laws—unlike the rest of Australia—Aborigines in the rest of Australia are being denied their fair share of these funds.
Aborigines have already either been given or claimed about 50 per cent of the Northern Territory and this extra money will now be used to buy up pastoral properties.

Mr Perron said the land fund was established to help redress the loss of land by traditional people throughout Australia not just the power brokers of the land councils whose aim is to acquire as much
of the Territory as they can before 1997 when claims under the Land Rights Act will cease.

Very important. Bring that back and now put that in the context of yesterday's announcements and statements by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner, when he announced the appointment of the new ILC board—a most interesting issue.

PARA.TAB: I am not into conspiracy theories—and Senator Collins likes to imply that that is the sort of process—but we do need to look at the consequences of government decisions because they all flow. As I just illustrated, Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Collins rightly are being censured here today by Senator Chamarette's motion because they are just not consistent with what they said previously.

But then it is interesting indeed to look at the appointments of the people to the ILC board yesterday. There is a requirement that the chairperson and four other persons of the ILC board be indigenous people. So who were appointed? Mr David Ross, and his credentials are well set out in the minister's press release as a former director of the Central Land Council and also a current commissioner of ATSIC who is going to step down to take this appointment; Mr Peter Yu, the deputy chairman, who is the Executive Director of the Kimberley Land Council; and Mr Noel Pearson, who is of course the Director of the Cape York Land Council.

All are from northern Australia. There is no representation whatsoever from anywhere else in Australia. Certainly, they are part of Mr Tickner's mafioso when it comes to the office of Aboriginal affairs and all of the negotiating team on this particular legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: would not reference to Mr Tickner's mafioso reflect in a most unparliamentary manner on Mr Noel Pearson and the other people named by Senator Tambling?

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: Senator Kernot knows perfectly well that Mr Pearson is not a member of parliament. Senator Kernot and some of her ilk may take their riding instructions from Mr Pearson, but he is not a member of parliament. Senator Kernot's point of order is entirely frivolous and is designed solely to interrupt Senator Tambling's address to this chamber.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—No, I do not uphold the point of order. I do not believe it is a reflection on a member of parliament. Of course, the individuals referred to would have the ability to correct the record through the resolution on privileges.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pointing out that the appointment of this board is in the control of Mr Tickner and the board has fallen into the hands of the groups of people who have been very much part of a special arrangement and deal that does not represent all Aboriginal people throughout Australia. I think that is a point that Senator Chamarette is making in this debate.

PARA.TAB: The other people appointed, Commissioner Stephen Gordon and the Chairman of ATSIC, Ms Lois O'Donoghue, of course, are there because of their position and stature under the act as members of the board of ATSIC. The appointments require at least two members of the board to be people with experience in business or financial management—at least two. Only two have been appointed. Ms Penny Morris and Mr Lawrie Willett are the two people who have been appointed to do that. So the minister once again has stacked this board, as with so many other appointments, with his particular group of cronies who are not representative of the wide range of Aboriginal interests throughout Australia; he has selectively picked only a few mates.

That is important in looking at this entire issue. It is important that we get an Indigenous Land Corporation that is properly representative not only of financial and business interests and those holding statutory office but also of the wide range of Aboriginal expertise that ought to apply throughout Australia.

I am also concerned—and I make it quite public—that I have previously criticised the new Chairman of the ILC, Mr David Ross, because of his prior involvement when, as Director of the Central Land Council, he and the person who now occupies the position of Aboriginal Social Justice Commissioner, Mr Mick Dodson, were the advisory committee to the then Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account in the Northern Territory. I proved, through extensive work in Senate estimates, through the Auditor-General's work and through ATSIC's Office of Evaluation and Audit, that Ross and Dodson were the advisers specifically with regard to the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account when it went through major problems of financial mismanagement.

I do not think anyone would argue with me that millions and millions of dollars of the ABTA were channelled through to the purchase of pastoral properties at the expense of Aboriginal organisational and community grants and inept Aboriginal Land Council administration. For Mr Ross to now be appointed to this position, which will be a billion dollar trust fund, when previously he showed what I term to be gross ineptitude, illustrates that the minister has not properly fulfilled his role and responsibility in that area. I am surprised that Senator Collins and Senator Evans, who were so intimately involved in all the negotiations with these people, were not well aware of the consequences of many of those issues and these appointments.

It is interesting to note that Senator Collins today and previously in the parliament and also in the media has expressed his reservations about the decisions of ATSIC in this important issue. Senator Collins likes to say, in a grandiose manner, `I disagree, but it is their right.' When it comes to budget provisions, there are still guidelines and principles and there still has to be a consistency in the budget programming of the funding that this parliament makes. Whether it is through the office of the Prime Minister, whether it is through ATSIC, whether it is through the ILC, sure, there can be discretionary decisions within those areas, but the government still has an obligation to the Australian community, and specifically to the Aboriginal interests throughout Australia, to make sure that all these groups are being very well served.

Senator Collins said today that he had reservations about this entire issue. The fact that he talks to the mirrors and does not talk about what I consider to be the issues is a major problem in this area. We need to be reminded that whenever we ask Senator Collins to look at this area he should bring to it an understanding of the Northern Territory, just as I think I do. At the same time, Senator Collins has demonstrated time and time again in this parliament that he is not up to the job of carrying it out consistently. One has only to look at the history of Senator Collins's involvement in his various ministries. He was his own biggest fan in the shipping portfolio. He talked about reforms. He talked about resigning if they were not achieved. Finally, he talked his way out of the whole mess.

Senator Collins will be remembered as the minister who was rolled by two Prime Ministers in two portfolios—firstly by Bob Hawke in shipping on waterfront reform and then by Paul Keating in communications. It has been said in the Senate, I think by Senator Alston, that Senator Collins has been rolled on such a regular basis that he is a laughing stock amongst his colleagues. The Weekend Australian on 5 December 1992 quoted one of Senator Collins's cabinet colleagues as saying, `If I were Bob Collins I would probably have slashed my wrists by now.' We need to remember that the Civil Aviation Authority hit the headlines in 1992 when it stood aside two executives following a damning report into the tendering process of a $300 million air traffic control system; yet we are supposed to believe that Senator Collins had no idea what was happening in the portfolio, even though he was the aviation minister at the time.

How can he come in here today and argue this land acquisition issue with regard to the ATSIC funding program? He argued that back in December last year with a very different turn of phrase to what he applies it today. Perhaps instead of looking at mirrors we should ask Senator Collins to go back and remind himself of the entire fiasco that he created in pay TV and how that went. He should look at the decision-making process.

It is therefore not surprising that Senator Chamarette has been so frustrated, so annoyed and so indignant—and I share that annoyance and indignation—at the way in which Senator Collins has attempted to shift on this issue and to use the debate purely to be like Joan Sutherland and be very theatrical. It does not work. The issue we need to be guaranteed of with the funding for ATSIC—and it is over $1 billion—and the funding that is being created into the Indigenous Land Corporation, which is also so important for the long-term interests of Aboriginal people and their social development in Australia, cannot be treated with inconsistency or in this attempt to mislead and to totally confuse Aboriginal people.

Aboriginal affairs is a significant issue. It is a significant and important budget allocation of this parliament. The parliament has now underpinned it with important legislation. Honourable senators will remember that the creation of ATSIC was a complex, difficult and onerous task of this parliament. The fact that there were so many amendments to the legislation in its gestation to create it pointed out not only the controversy within the wider community but also that the debate centred on a lot of the issues required by Aboriginal interests and Aboriginal people throughout Australia.

The native title debates of 1993 were probably, in my memory, the most important, most paramount and most difficult in the Senate, certainly in my time here. To now find that Senator Gareth Evans is not honouring the statements and the commitments he gave at that time in this debate or in this year's budget is much more than annoying and gives us much more reason to be indignant. For Senator Collins to come in here and to play as if this were a petty cash voucher system does not carry any weight. The facts need to be clearly stated. Certainly there is an accountability requirement on the board of ATSIC to fully explain and detail the decisions that that commission has taken. But I do not expect government ministers to then come in here and fudge the truth about such issues. (Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make my first comments on process, and I want to put on the record that the Greens did not have the courtesy to advise the Democrats of the existence of this censure motion, something that they criticise others for, and something that Senator Harradine has shown himself to use in the past as a reason for being disinclined to vote for or against a particular motion. However, I have listened to the debate and I would make the following comments.

PARA.TAB: In respect of process, considering that Senator Chamarette already has a return to order due for debate later today, I was waiting to see the documents that were going to be produced by the government. My expectation was that we proceed in these matters usually in a fairly logical order. We ask for the extra information; we assess the information; then we decide whether there is information worthy of censure of a particular minister or ministers. I am not sure, having listened to the debate so far, that the `facts' have been proven or disproven, and I will move to that in a moment.

I cannot resist, though, making a comment on the matter of self-determination, because I sat here for all those hours too, particularly on the matter of whether individual indigenous people should be allowed to purchase land. I heard members of the opposition and the Greens say repeatedly, on the matter of self-determination, that Aboriginal people should be allowed to make mistakes as well: if they wanted to get this land and then on-sell it straightaway, that was their choice. We had quite a discussion about whether self-determination meant the right to make mistakes or not.

Without saying anything about ATSIC's decision, the same principle applies to ATSIC's decision. It is the principle of self-determination. You may not like it. There may be a whole range of reasons why ATSIC made it, but it made it. It is empowered to make it and we, I believe, have to accept it and reserve the right to cast an opinion, as many people have done.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is all we are doing.
—You are doing more than that.
—The motion does not criticise ATSIC.
—It does really. In your comments you criticised ATSIC. I have made the comment I want to make, which is that you are very selective about when to champion self-determination.

PARA.TAB: We do need to ask questions about the facts of parts (a), (b) and (c) of the motion. In relation to part (a), Senator Tambling talked at length about what Senator Collins said on 16 November but the fact is that this censure motion confines its remarks to what Senator Collins said on 11 May. That background may have been useful for him but that is just a technical explanation. Senator Collins is quoted as making the distinction on 11 May between $42 million and $21 million being available to ATSIC. I made a point of speaking to the Northern Land Council.

My researcher spoke at length with Mr Darryl Pearce when this matter was first raised on 11 May. I think we can put a different interpretation on this $21 million and $42 million—that interpretation being that ATSIC made a decision to quarantine two lots of $10 million over the next two years. As well as that, there was $9 million per annum to land maintenance Australia-wide and $2 million per annum for the rest of Australia for purchase. I do not think it is fair to say that Senator Collins is being misleading over the distinction between the $21 million or the $42 million because, quite clearly, you can get $42 million over two years from the breakdown of ATSIC's figures.

In relation to part (b) of the censure motion, I think we can say, as the conclusion of the quotation says, that ATSIC's decision will cause a dramatic increase in the amount of land claimed under the land rights act. That is quite clearly the case. As to the assertion that Senator Gareth Evans has misled the parliament in that respect, that is wrong because, as has been pointed out, this is the allocation of new moneys to the land fund that Senator Evans has been quoted as referring to, not ATSIC. The land corporation has not yet made any determination of what moneys should be spent in the Northern Territory or anywhere else. Senator Tambling has advised us that it has just been appointed. I think it is wrong to say that in referring to the allocation of new moneys to the land fund and the fact that it would not lead to an increase in the amount of land claimed under the land rights act, Senator Evans was misleading the Parliament, because technically the terms of part (b) do not show that.

Part (c) of this motion says that an ATSIC board briefing paper reveals that an agreement had been struck between the Prime Minister, ATSIC and a group of `indigenous Land Fund Bill negotiators', et cetera. The briefing paper says that there will be special treatment for the Northern Territory for land acquisitions from ATSIC's land acquisition maintenance program in line with discussions with government and the restrictions of the bill. I do not see any conspiracy there that we should be alarmed about. Others have pointed out the facts already. Why should we disbelieve these people? Is there some evidence that we should disbelieve Mr Darryl Pearce when he says that the Northern Land Council has done no deal and there is no conspiracy of an arrangement with the government?

What is on the record is what we heard in the debate—that the Prime Minister extracted agreement from the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory for support for the bill in return for a sunset clause for indigenous land claims in the Northern Territory by 1997. The dialogue between the Prime Minister and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory came up in the wider debate, but that is not a deal. I do not understand why we would be reading something conspiratorial into this ATSIC board briefing paper. There are parallel arrangements, there are restrictions and there is an overlap of what happens in the Northern Territory Land Rights Act and the application of the land acquisition fund.

This is not secret; this is on the record. We have talked about it before. Yes, there is a transitional arrangement for two years, and what was agreed was part of the debate that we had. It is also on the public record. I guess what it is about is ATSIC's right to link politically some opportunities in the way other people link them.

If ATSIC is given compelling argument by indigenous people in the Northern Territory through the normal ATSIC processes that the Northern Territory has a particular case, that it should be given special consideration, and if ATSIC is persuaded of that, then it is its right to be persuaded of that. If ATSIC sees it as a priority, it is ATSIC's right to do so. If, as part of the discussions, those claimants or those arguing the case also say, `And we understand we don't have any priority in the allocation of money under the indigenous land fund', then what is wrong with ATSIC linking those two decisions, claims or whatever you want to call them? We might not like the outcome, but there is nothing intrinsically wrong with its right to do that. That is the politics of it, is it not?

I come back to the fact, on the matter of self-determination, that ATSIC has the right to do everything it has done. On the matter of the censure motion, I do not believe that the case has been proven in relation to part (a).In regard to part (b), I do not believe that the appropriate distinction between the ATSIC decision and its ramifications and Senator Gareth Evans's assertions about what would happen to moneys in the land fund has been adequately proven. Yes, there is more land claimed under the land rights act, but not because of the allocation of new moneys to the land fund, so I do not believe that has been misleading at all. Regarding part (c), I do not believe that a substantial case has been made out to warrant censure. Decisions have been made; they may be political decisions. It was perfectly entitled to make those decisions, and that is the fact of the matter.

None of that matters when you are into conspiracies, when you are into coalitions of convenience or when you are disrupting business for other reasons. That needs to be said in this debate as well. Why are we now spending so much time debating this at this particular point in time?

TALK.START.PARA: —Because the government misled us during the debate.
—But it isn't misleading. You haven't proven that, Senator Campbell. You have proven that there are some assertions—
—In your view.

—In my view you have not proven that, Senator Macdonald. You have proven that there are some assertions, and maybe the return to order will shed light on some of this detail, but we do not have the benefit of that return to order at this point. From listening to the debate today I do not think that you have proven parts (a) and (b), and I see part (c) as part of a political debate that is happening in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I say at the outset I am disappointed that Senator Kernot has allowed her concern at the electoral gains the Greens are making at the Democrats' expense to enter into this debate in the petulant way that Senator Kernot has just demonstrated. It just goes to show that people who are thinking of voting for the Democrats need not bother; they need just vote for the Australian Labor Party and they will get the same result. Here the Democrats are galloping yet again to the Labor Party's defence on this particular issue.

PARA.TAB: I can understand Senator Kernot's concern. I do not want to praise the Greens—nor does Senator Kernot—but I have to say this about them: they are at least genuine to their cause; they believe what they are talking about. I do not agree with them but they have this genuineness and commitment that has been sadly lacking in the Democrats for a number of years now.

The Democrats have proved themselves to be one of those parties, like the Labor Party, that will fiddle, interfere, deal and do all those sorts of things simply to retain their position. They have become quite irrelevant in the political scene at the moment. Nobody really needs their vote in the Senate and they have been sidelined. That irks the Democrats. While the last thing I want to do is praise the Greens—we will be trying to defeat them at the next election—I have to say that they do have a genuineness about them that is sadly lacking in the other minor party. I was disappointed with Senator Kernot's address on this subject.

I want to make it clear that on our side and, I am certain, on Senator Chamarette's side as well, there is no particular criticism of ATSIC. It is simply that in this matter, when this legislation was coming through, we warned the government what it would lead to. We were told in no uncertain terms that we were wrong. The words used by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Bob Collins over the course of the debate, which Senator Chamarette and Senator Campbell have referred to, led the parliament and the Australian public to believe in certain things. Perhaps, when you examine them, the words used could support some of the things that Senator Evans said but the whole tenor of the debate was meant to give a certain impression and was meant to convince some of those in the Senate which way they should vote. That is our concern.

Unlike Senator Kernot, I found the case put by Senator Chamarette in moving this censure quite compelling. The trouble with the defence made by Senator Evans is that it was the typical Queen's Counsel defence. Senator Evans is very good at acting as Queen's Counsel. He says he does not believe in those sorts of things but he is pretty keen to keep the QC after his name. It was that typical sort of defence—the smooth words, the persuasive intonation, the selective quotation—but it really did not convince anyone. Senator Evans is not interested in this debate at all. He put in an appearance and that was the last we have seen of him.

The problem Senator Collins has is a problem that most of Labor frontbenchers have these days: it really does not matter what they say, nobody believes them. Unfortunately, Senator Collins is one who has this tag that anything he says is not believed.

TALK.START.PARA: —And he is one of the better ones on their front bench.
—I could not concede that.
—Not much choice.

—There is not much choice but I could not concede that. As Senator Harradine has quite graphically pointed out a number of times, there are more Labor Party people in the chamber for this debate now than there were when Senator Collins was here defending himself. It is dramatic to note that not even the Labor Party wanted to come in, sit behind Senator Collins and show a bit of support when he was defending himself against this very serious censure motion. It is the most serious thing that can happen.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coates interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that you, Senator Coates, and your boss, Mr Keating, think of the Senate as unrepresentative swill. I see you nodding. You people would like to do away with the Senate—the second chamber, the chamber of review, the chamber that acts as a brake on the executive—and have the Mr Keatings of this world run the country with an iron fist without any reference to democracy whatsoever. We know that is your thought on it. But this chamber serves a very serious purpose and its procedures should be taken very seriously.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins compounded his error in a loud voice during the quorums and during his so-called defence. He makes it clear that he is just not concerned about this at all. He says, `Who cares what the Senate says. This is just a rubbish motion. I am not going to take any notice of it'. I heard him telling his colleagues with some pride, `You wear it as a badge of courage if you get censured by the Senate.' Fancy that coming from a senior member of the government! Fancy a minister of the Crown taking that sort of attitude to the procedures of the Senate!

Senator Collins compounded that in his address by saying that he had great regard for the parliamentary institution. He said that he knew that it was the gravest charge, but he went on to say, `But I am not going to lose any sleep about this. I do not take any notice of it.' He could not even get his arithmetic right when he said that the coalition only needs two votes to get this motion passed. He needs to go back and have a look at the numbers in the Senate. It is just another instance of Senator Collins being wrong.

The fact that Senator Collins was not supported in the quorum, I suspect, shows that the Labor party is waking up to him. As I recall my history, Senator Collins was not going to be put in the ministry a few years back. He had not shown any particular ability or competence, but the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, for some reason insisted that Senator Collins be brought onto the front bench. I am not quite sure of the reason, but Mr Hawke stood on caucus—perhaps someone in caucus will tell me that this is not right—and made sure that Senator Collins was appointed a minister. Senator Collins owes his political position to the goodwill and the work of Mr Hawke.

Unfortunately, that goodwill was not reciprocated during the very vicious leadership battle and Senator Collins apparently had no hesitation in switching camps and going to Mr Keating—no doubt retaining his spot on the front bench. Unfortunately for Senator Collins, he has the problem now that no matter what he says in his defence nobody believes him because his credibility is completely shot.

My colleague Senator Tambling has quite rightly pointed out—and I will waste the time of the Senate in repeating it—that Senator Collins has a history of having things go wrong in his department. The pay TV fiasco became a laughing-stock. We all remember those days. It was serious, but one could not help having another chuckle every day about the way the pay TV issue was handled. The TAAATS communication matter was another fiasco. All the problems that we have had with the CAA were initiated whilst Senator Collins was the minister. As my colleagues have quite rightly pointed out, we also have the matter of waterfront reform. This is typical of Senator Collins' performance here today. He said, `I will resign on 6 May' or whatever the date was `if the waterfront is not fixed.'

Before I entered the parliament I saw Senator Collins at a chamber of commerce meeting in Townsville. I thought, `Oh, this guy is good. Fancy putting your career on the line'. Senator Collins said, `I am going to fix the waterfront or I will resign.' Senator Collins received a standing ovation from the audience—including me. I have to confess how stupid I was at the time. That is the way that this guy does it. He said he would resign, but what happened? The waterfront is in an absolute mess. As Senator Campbell pointed out, one has only to go to Western Australia to see the great reform that Senator Collins brought to the waterfront.

But he gets away with it because of the way he does it. People are waking up to him now. He said, `I will resign if it is not fixed.' There were great cheers, but nothing happened. Of course, he does not resign. In this instance Senator Collins said, `I will bet you any money you like that this is not going to happen.' As Senator Chamarette said, if she had taken his bet she would have been a wealthy woman now.

TALK.START.PARA: —She would have been as wealthy as the bloke who made the $30 million out of his pay TV blunder.

—That is right. He took the bet. That is how Senator Collins gets away with it. I do not bear Senator Collins any ill will. He is a likeable enough sort of fellow. But when these things are done by a minister of the Crown they must be exposed. He is running around having a joke here and a bluff there with the farmers. He says, `I will bet you this' and `I will resign if this does not happen.' The farmers say, `Oh well, he sounds pretty good,' but he never delivers on anything. This particular debate before us today is exactly the same.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to pretend to the Senate—I do not think that the Senate would believe it anyway. I am not involved in the substantive issue before us. I am entering into this debate because I consider the allegation of misleading the Senate, particularly a minister of the crown misleading the Senate, the most serious. Without any particular involvement in the substantive issue that has been discussed, I have listened to what has been said, and I think it is quite clear that Senator Collins has misled the Senate in a number of ways. These have been pointed out by the previous speakers. I do not want to go through them, but I will make a couple of comments about them.

The motion before us calling upon the parliament to censure the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Government in the Senate and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy relates some issues. I refer to paragraph (c). The ATSIC briefing paper which has been spoken about quite clearly reveals that an agreement had been struck between the Prime Minister and ATSIC and a group of indigenous land fund negotiators about singling out the Northern Territory. From the debate so far, I think that has become very clear, and some answers need to be given.

I have borrowed from Senator Chamarette's speech some of the questions which she asked and to which, I regret to say, both Senator Evans and Senator Collins, who were talking to advisers, did not even listen. Therefore, they did not answer them. I think it is worth repeating the questions: was there an agreement struck between the government, ATSIC and a group of indigenous land fund bill negotiators? Senator Collins has, I think, in a roundabout way, denied it. But he has not at all been convincing. He has not answered the particular allegations that Senator Chamarette and, I think, Senator Campbell put to him. He certainly did not answer the questions, and neither did Senator Evans, about what the Prime Minister actually dealt with in this deal, what the terms of those agreements were, whether they included agreements about appointments to the ILC board and whether special attention would be given to Northern Territory Aboriginal people above Aboriginal people in other parts of Australia.

The question went on to ask: if all of that was wrong, what is then meant by the ATSIC briefing paper? There was no satisfactory answer from either Senator Collins or Senator Evans to those questions. I doubt that they heard them, because, in their typical way of paying little respect to the Senate, they were not listening. It raises questions which, again, need to be answered: did the Leader of the Government in the Senate lie? Did Senator Bob Collins lie? What was Mr Keating's part in all this? These are questions which have been asked, but still have not been answered and must be satisfactorily answered if these ministers are to have any credibility at all.

I refer briefly to paragraph (a) of the censure motion. As I understand it, Senator Chamarette is saying there that Senator Campbell said that $20 million out of $24 million had been allocated for land acquisition in the Northern Territory. Senator Collins got up and said that that was not right; it is not $20 million out of $24 million, it is $20 million out of $42 million. So, if they spend $20 million in the Northern Territory, they still have $22 million to spend on the rest of Australia. That is the impression he was trying to get across. He was trying to say that it is not an inordinate amount for the Northern Territory, because there is another $22 million that you can spend elsewhere. That is absolutely ridiculous.

A considerable part of that $42 million had, as I understand it, been committed to management. ATSIC might say, `We'll buy $42 million worth of cars, but we won't allocate any money to put petrol in them?' Why would you do that? You would not buy the cars without having some way of managing them and of making them go. Similarly, with land purchases, you do not buy $42 million worth of land and put no money aside to manage that land. That is patently ridiculous. Senator Collins was trying to say, `$20 million is not a big amount because the rest of Australia will get another $22 million.' That was not right. He knew it was not right. For trying to move the debate from reality and trying to hide and confuse the facts, Senator Collins deserves to be censured.

One thing that Senator Kernot rightly pointed out in this debate was that we were not talking about what was allocated to ATSIC. She said that Senator Collins's bet of large sums of money is not part of the censure motion. It is worth making reference to it to demonstrate that, in this whole course of events, Senator Collins and Senator Evans, to a lesser degree, have tried to confuse the issue and put it off track. As Senator Collins stated in Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: The only fear that would then be raised, and I am prepared to bet large sums of money that this is not going to happen, is that the $21 million of ATSIC funds would be used . . . exclusively or largely over the next three years to purchase land in the Northern Territory to the exclusion of elsewhere in Australia.
Senator Collins was trying to say that he would bet millions that this $21 million would not be spent on land acquisitions in the Northern Territory.

PARA.TAB: It then became quite obvious, through the minute of the meeting that Senator Campbell tabled in the parliament and which was the subject of his question without notice on 11 May that $10 million was set aside one year for land purchases in the Northern Territory, $2 million elsewhere and $10 million in the following year. There was the $20 million for land acquisitions in the Northern Territory which Senator Collins previously had `bet you any money you like' would not be spent on land acquisitions. Whilst it is not part of the motion, it is relevant to show the way that these particular ministers have tried to confuse the issue and mislead the Senate about a very important matter which deserves better attention from the nation's parliament.

I know that other honourable senators want to speak to this debate and we have other business to deal with, so I will leave my remarks there. I think Senator Chamarette has made out her case. I am pleased that we will be supporting this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to add a bit to this debate. I will not get into the substantive measures involved but I want to put a few points on the record. Before I do that, I congratulate Senator Chamarette of the Greens for having the gall to tackle the government and for having the gumption to tackle the minister and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on this matter, and to tackle Senator Collins on what has gone on here today. Rather than debating this motion, I am sure the government and those of us on this side would have much preferred to get on with the business of the day, knowing how short a time we have to complete before 1 July the start-up legislation under the budget program.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Collins had any gumption, he would have come clean, in answer to the request made by Senator Chamarette, with all the papers and documents requested. No, he chose not to—I think he will be forced to—so we have now lost at least an hour and a half today.

I want to put it on the record that the Western Australian Greens have finally come to the realisation that not all is well in ATSIC. Senator Chamarette may remember a proposed inquiry into the accountability of ATSIC and its forward programs, an inquiry that I wanted some 12 months ago. On that occasion I was very nasty with her for not supporting my proposal, but I suppose the Greens were new to the chamber—so we can forgive them.

It is too late to have that inquiry now because we are close to an election and the coalition, in government, will put things in order. If we had had 12 months ago that inquiry on the accountability of ATSIC, we would have been in a far better position. Most importantly, ATSIC and the Aboriginal community would have been in a far better position than they are today.

Let me turn now to the Australian Democrats. Senator Kernot bounded into this place and told the Senate that she had not heard of this motion until five minutes ago. She immediately, of course, took on the defence of the government, as the Democrats do. Let me put it on the record again in this place—this is also for the benefit of the rest of Australia as it is a non-broadcast day—that Senator Kernot had given me an undertaking over 12 months ago that she would support my proposed inquiry into ATSIC. We debated the motion but, unfortunately, on the Thursday night we ran out of time. When the debate came on, on the following Tuesday, she had turned tail and would not support us.

What was the reason for turning tail over the weekend? I probably still have the relevant letter on record in my files. I had kept it in my drawer in the Senate but, unfortunately, I lost it in the last few days when changing desks. The letter was from Lois O'Donoghue and it implored Senator Kernot to retract the support of the Australian Democrats for my motion to have an inquiry.

Senator Kernot is the leader of a party in this parliament which pretends to have the balance of power. Fortunately the Democrats do not have the balance of power now, but they still think they do. On the strength of one letter from the head of ATSIC—I thought it was unethical and I said so at the time—Senator Kernot turned around and refused to support my motion. At least the Greens of Western Australia said first up that they would have supported my inquiry. I believe that they have learnt the error of their ways. If I was to propose that inquiry now, except that it is too close to the election, I am sure that Senator Chamarette would be the first to support such an inquiry. However, as I said before, our side will be in government very soon and we will fix those problems with ATSIC.

I believe that Senator Kernot stands condemned for once again blindly supporting the government. We all know—those of us on this side anyway—that Senator Collins failed to come up with the documents that are so urgently needed. Of course, he was covering up for the blunder he made. I am not going to criticise him for the waterfront and the other mistakes he has made in the past. They are well recorded and I will not repeat them now.

Finally, I congratulate Senator Chamarette for her motion. I condemn Senator Kernot for once again defending the government. I urge Senator Collins not to waste any more time of the Senate and to agree to the request at this late stage that he should have agreed to some time ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the censure motion moved against the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) for misleading the Senate and the people of Australia over the use of land fund money available through ATSIC. I would particularly like to make reference to my own state of Victoria which, after all the statements made by those personages over the last two years, would have every right to feel that it has been misled in every way.

PARA.TAB: The Native Title Act and the land fund acquisition bill made it very clear, or were supposed to make it very clear, to Aboriginals throughout Australia that they would ultimately have access to land fund money or to money available through ATSIC. As I think has been proved by my colleagues in respect of the differing statements made by Senator Evans and Senator Collins, this will indeed prove not to be the case, with much of the money going to the Northern Territory.

When I say that, obviously the right of ATSIC to make that decision must be respected. But the process by which it was arrived at and the devious manner in which these particular parliamentary ministers proceeded to arrive at that arrangement are things on which I feel Aboriginals in Victoria have every right to feel that they have been mislead.

The Senate will recall that over January the select committee on the land fund bill had a series of hearings throughout Australia in most capital cities on whether or not Aboriginals had been consulted on their input into the way in which the land fund was to be used. I make particular reference to the hearings that the committee held in Melbourne on Tuesday, 17 January 1995.

Speaker after speaker, in their submissions at that hearing, referred to the fact that in any consideration of disbursement of land fund money through ATSIC or through the ILC, consideration must be given to Aboriginals throughout Australia as well as Aboriginals in the northern rural and remote areas of Australia. No disclaimer was ever put by the government, the Prime Minister, or the ministers involved on the fact that that was what would happen.

Naturally enough, Aboriginals in the southern states have been led to believe that they will have equal access to land fund money. I would like to quote from some of their remarks on that day on the reasons why this would occur. For instance, Ms Sharon Firebrace, Director of Palm River Pty Ltd, said:

SPEECH.PARA: From a dispossessed point of view, the people in Victoria and the south-east west coast of Australia are the most dispossessed. I think we should have priority over those in communities who are not so severely dispossessed and who have access to native title. I speak predominantly of the northern communities.
Mr Johal, solicitor for the Victorian Aboriginal Legal Service, said:
This is of particular relevance to Victoria—
talking about the disbursement of money through the land fund—

because in Victoria you are now unable to claim compensation for any act done prior to 1975 and most of Victoria, perhaps all, was taken away from the rightful owners prior to that date. So Victoria is actually in double jeopardy in terms of native title as well as the land fund and it has got to be addressed, particularly from that perspective.
Mr Larry Kanoa, Director of the Ballarat and District Aboriginal Cooperative, said:
However, our community—
speaking of the Victorian Aboriginal community—

still has needs similar to other Aboriginal peoples and communities across Australia in relation to owning and managing their own lands. Communities such as Ballarat are surely the most dispossessed in Australia and have been for a long time.
Mr Edward Lovett, a founding member of the Ballarat and District Aboriginal Cooperative, said:
In Victoria we seem to miss out on a lot of things that happen, especially funding wise. We seem to get more or less the crumbs on the plate.
That particular phrase sums up very well the division of money that has just been made according to the ATSIC board briefing paper.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot spoke before about us dividing the Aboriginal community. It is this sort of decision that will divide the Aboriginal community in north set against south and urban against rural. Many more divisions will appear in the Aboriginal community as a result of funding decisions like these and the singling out of the Northern Territory which is particularly mentioned in paragraph (c) of the censure motion.
I again quote from the land fund hearing on Tuesday, 17 January. Mr Edward Lovett must have had a degree of foresight when he made this remark:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the national strategy will only reflect the requirements of the few regions with the biggest numbers and/or largest political influence.
Perhaps that is exemplified by the way in which the ILC board is being made up. He continued:
This has been evident by the lesser recognition by ATSIC of Koories in the South Eastern States.
Indeed, that proved to be a very forward looking remark. Mr Andrew McEwen, senior project officer of ATSIC Victoria, said:

The point is that we believe, and our submission argues, that the bill has been framed to meet the needs of northern and remote communities and not in fact to meet the legitimate economic needs and aspirations of urban communities. . .

PARA.TAB: While that is larger, obviously, in remote communities, if we are going to have an economic future for the Koori families in Victoria, we require the legislation to very clearly enable . . . families, clans and organisations in Victoria to get into the economic development main game, not just to purchase land.

SPEECH.PARA: How is this funding decision going to assist that? It is not. He made this further remark:
But the real issue is about equity and fairness between the states and territories and the various families and tribes.

PARA.TAB: It appears that it—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, the land fund bill—

is based on meeting the needs of more remote communities and not on dealing with the problems and the economic realities of urban indigenous people in Australia, which constitute 67 per cent of the indigenous people of Australia.

To divert this money in the manner that has been done, towards singling out the Northern Territory, would clearly seem to divide the Aboriginal community further and not unite it. Mr McEwen continued:
That then means, in terms of southern and urban indigenous Australians, that 30 per cent more resources go out of ATSIC to the northern communities to fix up the infrastructure deficit.
So when you look at the total economic model for Koori families, on one level of public perception, you say—
that is, to the framers of the bill—

the need is up in the north, or in remote communities. On another level, what you have actually got is an adjusted income for the Koori families in Victoria of $5,400, which would compare with $9,000 for indigenous people in the Northern Territory, if you add in the value of the mineral royalties and land claims. So that is a major problem. The majority of poverty in indigenous Australia is in urban areas. That is not to disrespect or devalue particularly the dispossessed people across Australia and the infrastructure problems in communities. But the Senate committee must be well aware that the majority of dispossessed and Kooris living in poverty are in urban areas, not in remote and rural communities.

Never at any stage in the two years of debate on either native title or the land fund bill was any mention made by the government of the proportions, or the geographical areas to which money would be distributed. Some of us imagined that a more or less even division would be made across Australia, probably on a needs basis. The way in which this division has been done is singling out a particular area for very privileged treatment, for special treatment, as is stated in the censure motion. Mr Andrew McEwen's final remark was:

ATSIC and, by other levels of government, the Victorian Koori community, is underfunded by $5 million. If you do not have an asset base it is extremely difficult to borrow and to set up an economic development base.

Among its more generous assessments of the government's land fund bill it has always been imagined that not only was money available to buy land but also, in the longer term, it would be made available for Aboriginals to build up an economic development base. If some areas of Australia are being treated more generously than others in the way that Senator Collins and Senator Evans now appear to be doing, this simply will not happen. One of the government's landmark words has always been `equity'. I ask honourable senators: where is the equity in this if an agreement has indeed been struck between the Prime Minister, ATSIC and a group of indigenous land fund bill negotiators in singling out the Northern Territory? There is no equity in that. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., we will now proceed to debate matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have found that a matter of public interest drawn to my attention by a taxi company in Launceston, Tasmania, is a matter of much more widespread interest than purely for one company in Launceston. In fact, thousands of taxis throughout Australia have been affected by the incompetence or delaying tactics of Telecom. I, in trying to represent the interests of the taxis, have been thwarted by either the incompetence or the stonewalling of the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Mr Lee.

PARA.TAB: The issue is the 131-008 problem for taxis. Back in about 1992 the taxi companies of Australia were informed that they could have a better system of access for mobile telephone users and for everybody else by using a 131-008 national taxi phone network. However, mobile users using that 131 number get put through to a Melbourne company even if they are in Tasmania or in Timbuktu. If a non-mobile phone is used, the call goes through to the local company as the caller planned.

The taxi companies which found that mobile phone customers were getting the raw end of the deal started to complain. They were told by Telecom, `This is going to be fixed soon.' Although they started complaining in about 1992, they were told that the technical difficulty was to be resolved by August 1994. That was later amended to August 1995. There is still no certain date as to when it is going to be fixed.

I had representations from my local taxi company, Central Cabs. In September last year I made representations to Telecom chief executive officer Mr Ted Taylor and to the industry ombudsman, Mr Warwick Smith. The ombudsman said that, following Telecom's response, the taxi companies were to get back to him if there were further problems. Telecom responded on 17 October, saying that the problem was recognised but no commitment for a solution could be given at that stage and that the 131-008 service franchise owner, which is in Sydney, had been contacted with suggestions for improving the service.

On 18 October I wrote to Minister Lee asking why no commitment had been given for a solution, what was being done to solve the problem and, if nothing was being done, why not. On 12 December I sent a reminder letter to the minister. On 31 March my office phoned the minister's office. We had had no communication from the minister's office at all. My staff were told that the delay was due to Telecom's failure to get back to the minister—a communication problem between the minister and Telecom. We were told to expect a response within two weeks. That was 31 March.

On 3 May my office rang again. We still had received nothing from the minister. We were told that the continued delay was because the response provided by the department was not satisfactory and it had been returned from the minister's office to the department several times—not once—for changes. On 3 May it was awaiting the minister's signature. There must be carrier pigeons carrying correspondence from Minister Lee to my office! It has been pretty standard in the past on other matters for me to wait five or six months to get a response from the minister. As of 31 May—that is today—I have still not received a response from Minister Lee, the Minister for Communications and the Arts, on a matter which is affecting thousands of taxis around Australia.

Let me just draw to senators' attention some extracts from a letter that was written to Telecom on 17 September last year by the Executive Officer of Taxi 131-008 Pty Ltd—that is the company that arranges these access telephone numbers for taxi companies around Australia. He wrote to Mr Frank Blount on 17 September and he said:

SPEECH.PARA: As a consequence of the fact that Telecom will only presently provide four (4) receiving locations for incoming mobile phone calls to 131 008 within Australia, the cost of routing the taxi booking to the local taxi operator (the Telecom relaying charges and the labour costs associated with double handling) are commercially unacceptable. As an example I draw your attention to the taxi customer with a mobile phone in Perth. His/her call is routed to our 131 008 answering location in Adelaide, Suburban Taxis. Suburban takes the booking then faxes it back immediately to our Perth Licensee B & W Cabs. At times of peak demand it is anticipated this will require a continuously open fax line between the two companies if we are to service the requirements of a reasonable proportion of our Perth customers.
In his letter he goes on to say:
Telecom itself has recently attributed a major proportion of its substantial profit to the proliferation of mobile phones.
We all know that. Telecom is doing very nicely, thank you, out of mobile phones. He goes on to say:
There are now over forty taxi companies throughout Australia accessing the 131 008 network.

The problem is that a growing number of their customers who have and use mobile phones are being routed not to the taxi company that they think they are ringing, but through one of the four receiving stations that are provided for this service by Telecom. It is simply not good enough.

PARA.TAB: We have a very real suspicion that it is suiting Telecom very nicely, thank you, because these are analog calls. Once Telecom puts up digital equipment to improve the service for these taxi numbers, its competitors, Vodaphone and Optus, will be able to compete with it in this lucrative market. For the moment, Telecom has a monopoly on the thousands and thousands of calls that are going out every day for the booking of taxis. Telecom has it in its own interest to drag its feet and not provide better relay stations so that it can keep its competitors out of the market.

I would have thought the minister for communications in this country would have seen through Telecom, would have been concerned about the telephone users in this country and would have been worried for the small businesses that Mr Keating is desperately trying to run out of business. I would have thought the minister for communications would have recognised that communications for small business is a critically important part of business and would be trying to do something to stop this monopoly treating small business and individuals in the cavalier fashion that it has over these calls.

The taxi companies tell me that daily they receive calls from many dissatisfied customers and that the usage of the 131-008 number has proved terribly complex and a serious problem with public relations with their customers. Why is it that this issue has gone right back to 1992 when Taxi 131-008 Pty Ltd first raised the issue with Telecom? Why is it that the minister has had such trouble providing a response? Why is it that he will not come out publicly and explain some of the things that I have been putting on the record here today? Why is it that the minister's office is clearly so totally incompetent that, despite phone calls and repeated letters, a senator in this parliament cannot get an answer from the minister responsible for communications?

It is a totally unacceptable matter. I think it is a disgrace; it is scandalous, in fact. Is it a fact that the minister is encouraging Telecom to pursue this monopoly for all it is worth? Does the minister want to cut Optus and Vodaphone out of the market? Is that really what he is about? Let him come out and deny it. His delay has meant that this monopoly has continued for even longer than it did previously.

The thousands of taxis around Australia are fed up with the way Telecom has been treating them. They are fed up as customers of Telecom that they cannot get a decent service. They are fed up with this government and this minister's lack of concern for them and their customers. I would not want to have the taxis of Australia badmouthing me in the months leading up to the election. It is one more example of the arrogance and complacency of this government and its lack of attention to the needs of average battlers trying to make a quid in today's Australia that there has not been something done about this before now. It is a total and utter national disgrace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to continue some remarks which I made when asking a question and taking note of an answer of the Minister representing the Treasurer, the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), about a week ago relating to the Industry Commission inquiry into charities. I draw the attention of the Senate to the draft report of that inquiry and draft recommendation No. 4, which indicates a concern which I have been expressing—many of the charities have also expressed this—on many occasions. The recommendation reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Commonwealth and state/territory governments should develop a set of principles for the selection of service providers:
.applications should be called by open tender . . .

This practice—which is a draft recommendation of the Industry Commission—was confirmed by the Deputy Prime Minister, Brian Howe, as the government's preference at a breakfast last Monday morning organised by the National Anglican Caring Organisations Network. I want to place on record again both my opposition, and certainly the opposition of most welfare organisations in Australia, to the possibility of this practice—and for very good reasons. For the information of the Senate, I will read a little more of the draft report of the Industry Commission. It states:
A more mature financial relationship between the sector and government would also give greater assurance to governments that policy objectives will be effectively and efficiently fulfilled.

We need to ask the question: whose policy objectives and who is getting the assurance? Certainly governments need assurance that money they spend is efficiently and effectively used. I would like to suggest that what is far more important are the policy objectives of those charity and welfare organisations which government is seeking to control in this way. The report of the commission goes on:
But governments also need to ensure that funding arrangements encourage best practice, and that poorer performing CSWOs—
community service welfare organisations—

which cannot lift their performance or form co-operative alliances to offset their disadvantages, vacate the field in favour of more effective CSWOs. Their funding should not be continued at the expense of those CSWOs which can provide a better quality service or the same quality of service at lower cost.
That sounds very well but there are a number of questions which are absolutely critical and which are causing great concern to the whole of the welfare, community and church sector.

PARA.TAB: One of these concerns is a fundamental one. Who defines poor performance? Who defines quality service? What about a service provided, for instance, by the Catholic church at Port Hedland to boat people? This service has been the basis for severe criticisms of the government by the Catholic church, or at least by those involved in providing that service. Would senators say to me that government would fund that kind of service which was so critical of government policy, or would it be defined as being a poor performer and as not being a quality service? Senators can see the problem. In its report, the Industry Commission further comments:

SPEECH.PARA: Tendering would improve efficiency by encouraging best practice through opening up service delivery to alternative suppliers.

Does this mean private agencies? Are we going to allow private agencies to make a profit from welfare delivery? What about the welfare infrastructure—a vast infrastructure which has been established by the churches and other welfare agencies across Australia? Are we going to say to them, `If you don't obtain funding by tender, bad luck. Someone else is going to take over and all that infrastructure which you've developed will simply go down the drain'?

PARA.TAB: But the Senate need not take my word for these concerns. Let me place on record, in the time I have available, some of the concerns which have been put in writing to me and to the Australian Democrats. Eldercare is the agency in South Australia that the Uniting Church uses to deliver its service to the aged. The letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Eldercare Inc. is not a prominent organisation but we are one of the larger providers of care to the elderly in South Australia. The Industry Commission lists us in the 50 largest charitable organisations in Australia.

Eldercare has over the last 3-4 years undergone considerable self-initiated change and actively pursues good management and competitive outcomes.
