We do this for the two reasons of providing better care to our residents and to achieve some surplus which we can direct specifically to areas of need that are not covered by other funding opportunities.
My reading of the emerging assessments is that the loss of the current tax exempt status will do several things . . .

I should explain again to the Senate that the trade-off is the loss of the tax exempt status for funding by tender. This is what Eldercare says are its concerns if this trade-off should go ahead. They read:

.charitable organisations in aged care, with their low overheads and providing maximum value to residents, in order to manage the new taxation arrangements will have to introduce administrative structures and new costs which produce no gains to government, the beneficiaries of the service, nor the organisations.

.access to tax concessions has allowed the not-for-profit sector to competitively recruit quality managers at no additional cost, but with significant qualitative and tangible benefits to the beneficiaries, governments and the organisations from improved efficiency.

.the recommendation by the Commission that these changes be introduced on a revenue neutral basis to government is clearly flawed in that all taxes cost to collect and dispense. With three or four tax collection and dispensing steps being proposed the current funds available may shrink by up to 40-45%. Revenue neutral does not necessarily equate with cost neutrality.
In his conclusion, the writer of this, the chief executive officer of Eldercare, says:
After much deliberation I am still not able to see the gains to government or the community from the changes being suggested to the system.

In Aged Care the Commonwealth government's own consultancies are clearly showing considerable funding difficulties and shortfalls. We as an industry are just coping now. If the government was to adopt the report as it is currently drafted it would create a funding crisis with no winners.
The National Anglican Caring Organisations Network has a critique of the Industry Commission's report. In that critique it states:

One question not asked is why the community organisations continue to exist—what is the reason and motivation which sustains a `non-profit' organisation? The answers to this are fundamental to understanding the sector, viz.

.the importance of the values of community organisations which motivate them to continue to exist (irrespective of government funding) and which attract continuing community support in cash and time . . .
.the importance of the `charitable impulse' . . . or in other words, the relationship where assistance is given to the organisation from the concerned community.

This is not a `market response'—a market would leave the less deserving to their own fate, if they could not afford to buy their `wants' (needs). The charitable impulse does not operate on market principles—it operates on the principle of responsibility for one's neighbour.

This is a deficiency in the report. In not acknowledging the power of the organisations' values in directing its activity, nor the power of the cooperative effort where people respond to a need without market incentive, the report is somewhat out of focus.
I hope that the government will take note of these concerns. The Anglican organisation further stated:

The recent history of tendering has shown that `savings' have been achieved by reduction in client service ie. less time for client support, and focus solely on the specific service eg. deliver a meal. The Christian ethic places a responsibility on agencies to provide for the whole person, not to neglect their human needs which surround the direct service.
The national organisation of the Uniting Church has also spoken of its concern in a press release headed `Government at risk of eroding the work of charities'. It states, in part:

Community Services Australia, the national body for Community Services in the Uniting Church, is concerned the Commission and the Government has not given enough consideration to the way market forces are complicated by human factors associated with community service development and delivery.
Robert Fitzgerald of the Australian Council of Social Service, writing about the report in Impact, says:

PARA.TAB: The report also assumes that applying certain market mechanisms, particularly tendering, will produce better outcomes for clients and enhanced performance. This is a very questionable assumption that warrants rigorous scrutiny before being accepted as a general principle.

It must never be forgotten that community services are not `just another business'. Nor are we simply agents of government or `little fingers of the state'. Moves towards increased competition and more prescriptive output based funding run the risk of undermining the very strengths of the sector which the Commission has highlighted.

SPEECH.PARA: In a press report from Australian Associated Press, the Brotherhood of St Laurence in Melbourne has placed on record its concerns. In the same press release Mr Begley, the Salvation Army representative at the commission hearings, has also placed his concerns on the record. The press release states:

PARA.TAB: Mr Begley said removal of tax concessions would add considerably to the cost of service delivery and could result in some reduction in programs.

`The Commission suggests that any change in tax exemptions should be `revenue neutral', however, experience has shown that government budget constraints frequently lead to a drop in funding resulting in deficits for approved programs.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Council of the Society of St Vincent De Paul, in a very serious comment, totally rejected the idea of the tendering model. The society rejects this recommendation as the tendering model is based on a profit oriented paradigm. This process will inevitably lead to one community service organisation being played off against another community service organisation and with the client being the loser. As previously stated to the Industry Commission, it is unlikely that the society will tender for projects in competition with other organisations. In collaborative community models, both the selection of the types of expanded services needed and the selection of the deliverers are carried out through a joint community planning and decision making process. That process will be lost in the model which is proposed. The society concludes:
Therefore, the Society strongly objects to tendering for family/community based service delivery based exclusively on `cost'.

PARA.TAB: What further convincing does the government need of the concern the community and welfare sector has about this model? Nevertheless, the Deputy Prime Minister told the national Anglican gathering on Monday that it will proceed in this way.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw to the attention of the Senate an ongoing problem which doctors are experiencing with the pharmaceutical benefits scheme authority required prescriptions. Earlier this year, I asked a question of Senator Crowley, the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence), concerning the changes which the government instigated on 1 December 1994 and which made it necessary for prior approval to be obtained from the Health Insurance Commission for all pharmaceutical benefits scheme authority required items.

PARA.TAB: Despite the minister's assurance that additional staff are employed by the Health Insurance Commission to ensure an efficient 24-hour telephone approval of any authority requests by mail, many doctors, particularly those in my state of Tasmania, are still impeded by the changed requirements. I have received many letters from disgruntled medical practitioners who are still battling with the new system because of lengthy delays in telephone approvals. Most doctors prefer to obtain telephone authorisation for such prescriptions because it enables their patients to take the prescription with them and to commence treatment immediately.

However, the considerable delays in telephone authorisation continue, with doctors frequently having to wait seven to eight minutes. This amount of time appears to be the average delay. In some cases, the delay has effectively changed the patient's consultation time from a short consultation to a long consultation which incurs a much higher fee. On some occasions, doctors give the authority to their patient to post, in this case to Hobart. However, this action inevitably causes a delay in the patient receiving his or her treatment. Statistics have it that some patients do not bother to send the prescription to Hobart and so the treatment is bypassed, which is obviously a less than desirable situation.

Under the NUS, the government sends every doctor a list of drugs which he or she can prescribe on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. There have always been several drugs which require a special authority. For example, drugs such as Zoladex and Flutemide are specified for advanced prostate cancer only. Prior to December 1994, when these drugs were required a special prescription form was completed which gave specific details of the drug, the method of administration, the quantity and the illness. The prescription was handed to the chemist, who forwarded it to the PBS authorities and then received payment for the drug.

If the prescription was sent without a specific illness marked on it and if it did not meet the PBS guidelines, the doctor was liable to pay for the drug, and, no doubt, also to pay a fine for misrepresentation. As stated, the drug was clearly marked on the list. The accepted purpose for which it was prescribed was delineated, as was the exact quantity that could be prescribed. The system worked very effectively and with minimum delay and disruption to both doctor and patient. However, since 1 December 1994, the new guidelines and procedure have been less than satisfactory, to the great dislike of many doctors and patients.

Senator Crowley's answer to my question on 9 February stated that the new regulations are to `ensure that the drugs are used appropriately.' To meet this requirement, the doctor must obtain an authorisation number from the Health Insurance Commission, prior to handing the prescription to the patient. However, in my view, there is no greater guarantee that this method is any more effective than the previously existing system. The main impact of this new system is that doctors are having to wait for lengthy periods on the telephone while permission is obtained, which only delays a consultation.

The important point is that doctors make clinical decisions about patients and decide to treat them with the most effective treatment. It remains quite ludicrous for a health insurance telephonist to instruct a doctor on the drugs he or she cannot use. The decision should be a clinical decision enabling doctors to prescribe the most modern and, more importantly, the most effective drugs.

Another concern which has been brought to my attention regarding authorities is that many patients are on increased quantity prescriptions which now require authorities. For example, somebody could be on a fairly inexpensive blood pressure tablet or, for that matter, paracetamol tablets and require extra amounts. The normal packets of many of these medications last them 15 days. However, from 1 December, the government introduced a requirement that patients cannot get repeats within 20 days. This means that every patient who is on an increased quantity of medication requires an authority prescription. This is part of the reason for the increased number of authorised prescriptions now being asked of the government.

I take this opportunity to urge the government, and particularly the minister, to again examine the effectiveness of the system and to institute any changes that may be necessary to streamline the process for doctors and their patients. I think it is certainly a retrograde step when doctors are not judged by their peers, in terms of the quality of their prescribing, but by a telephonist, untrained in medical issues, at the other end of a telephone line. I think the whole matter needs complete review.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Customs: Passenger Arrival Security Surveillance System

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to deal with a civil liberties matter that I hope Senator Gareth Evans will apply his mind to because, quite frankly, it relates to a procedure which I think is totally improper and which clearly involves almost the `thought police' approach. I will explain it in this way: there is an arrangement whereby when a person arrives in Australia they have to go through a barrier and present their passport and various other travel documents. Normally there are very long queues but I think they are dealt with very efficiently and promptly by officers from Customs. They process matters which mostly relate to Immigration but, nonetheless, it is normally an efficient process unless the person going through happens to be someone whose name comes up on the computer.

PARA.TAB: The passenger arrival security surveillance system is a system whereby material about people has been fed into a computer. If a person's name has been put into that computer by the department of immigration then that person will be subject to further questioning, and there are various ways that passengers will be subjected to that questioning.

As I understand it, under this PASS system, there is an automatic trigger for the department of immigration. For example, if a person kept visiting locations which are high on the department's drug list, then that person would be likely to be asked where they had been and what they had been doing there. For some people who make a habit, because they have dual passports, of travelling outside Australia on a passport of another country, and then coming back into Australia on an Australian passport—which obviously would not have any arrival stamps from any other nation—they are also likely to be asked where they have been and so on.

They then hold up the queue behind them and find themselves subjected to questioning that they might find offensive, intrusive and so on. Nonetheless, it seems reasonable that they should have to put up with it. However, it is not reasonable and it is grossly improper that, for example, a journalist who travels overseas should be repeatedly stopped at the barrier and asked such intrusive questions during a 15-minute grilling as, `Whom have you talked to while you have been overseas?'

In raising this I remind the Senate that for about 20 years of my life I was a journalist. A journalist colleague of mine has been subjected to this kind of interrogation at the barrier. I might say that the people standing behind him in the queue have been less than impressed by that, but I am less than impressed by the fact that he was subjected to that kind of interrogation—not just once. It seems now to be a pattern, no matter by what entry point into Australia he has come in. It is no coincidence, it seems to me, that this journalist—who, to my knowledge, has an impeccable security record, has not been involved in any illegalities and holds an Australian passport—should in this extraordinary manner be continually questioned about matters like, `Whom have you talked to?'

What I note about this journalist is that he has had the temerity at times to write about security issues for the media outlet for which he works. He has written about ASIO and he has written about other security matters. From what I have seen in the papers lately, it is just as well we have had some journalists writing about some security matters.

Perhaps Senator Evans's apology yesterday about his incompetent handling of some security matters might be extended to the journalist who has been subject to this kind of improper interrogation at the barrier, for what appears to be no good reason and in an intrusive way which I believe to be a deliberate attempt—I will not say to terrorise; that overstates it—to let the journalist know that Big Brother is watching him.

This is not a nation where we should have thought police. It is not a nation where Big Brother, in the guise of a Labor government, should have any right or exercise any right to ask a journalist, on his return from overseas, `Whom have you been talking to?'—or any other intrusive questions that may relate to his profession. Naturally, when he was asked such a question he suggested to the officer, in polite terms, that he would not answer such a question and that it was improper to ask him. To that the customs officer, who was just acting on instructions from his computer, simply said okay.

What I want to know is what sort of agency is feeding this kind of request through the immigration department into the passenger arrival security surveillance system? On whose authority are journalists being asked whom they have talked to? What is this government about in this sort of thing? If the government itself does not know and it is being done by governmental agencies without the government's knowledge or approval, then I think the government ought to smarten itself up and find out what its agencies are doing on its behalf. This is intrusive, it is offensive and it implies a clear standover tactic against Australian journalists.

If every journalist who is going to write critical things about the government or its agencies is going to be subjected to this kind of interrogation at customs barriers in Australia, I believe it is an absolute disgrace. I ask the minister or Senator Evans, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, who holds himself up to be a protector of civil liberties, to take some action. I would not expect Senator Bolkus, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, to be over-excited about it but—

TALK.START.PARA: —You've got to be joking.

—I accept the interjection from my colleague from Tasmania. The fact is that the immigration department is in charge of this computer system. As I understand it, in the past there have not been any concerns expressed by the operation of the PASS system but I want to stress that this is a matter of concern now. I would hope that any other journalists who have been subjected to this kind of treatment would let me know. As an ex-journalist, I have a particular concern at any attempt to do this by any government, particularly this government whose Prime Minister is renown for standing over journalists, insulting them and abusing them. I would be particularly interested to hear of any other examples of this government through this system standing over and harassing Australian journalists.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting listening to today's speeches in this section of our proceedings because every person who has spoken has pointed to some aspect of arrogance on the part of this government and the way in which it treats ordinary citizens. I wish to continue in the same theme but what I want to pick up is the way in which people are being treated by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy under FOI requests. FOI stands for freedom of information. What do we find from this government? Far from making information available so that people can participate in the public debates about important issues, we find—and I will go through a letter shortly—that the government is putting every obstacle in the way of people who apply for information so that they cannot get that information. The government makes it as difficult as possible for people to get the information on which they might base an argument, no matter how comfortable the government might be with that argument and with the debate that would ensue.

PARA.TAB: The letter comes from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. It is in response to an application from the Wilderness Society in Victoria for information in relation to various forestry practices: correspondence which passed between the Commonwealth government and the state government of Victoria relating to the 1,300 forest areas identified as being worthy of interim protection from logging by the Department of Environment, Sport and Territories late last year; and, correspondence between the Commonwealth government and the relevant state governments and business corporations and companies relating to current and future hardwood woodchip licences.

The opposition and the Democrats may well disagree about the outcome of any debates which might arise as a consequence of that information but I think we would all agree that in entering that debate—and I see Senator Abetz nodding his head vigorously—in the first instance what we need is freedom of information so that all the information is on the table and the matter can be properly debated.

What do we find? When the Wilderness Society wrote seeking this information, we find the Department of Primary Industries and Energy writing back in these terms. I would interpolate here that the Wilderness Society had also asked for the charge for the FOI to be waived. The department, among other things, says:

SPEECH.PARA: In deciding whether to reduce or not impose a charge, the decision maker must, among other things, take into account whether payment of the charge, or part of it, would cause you financial hardship and whether the giving of access to documents is in the general public interest or in the interests of a substantial section of the public.

Immediately, we can see the deliberate obfuscation and the confusion which the department is trying to introduce between the two requests: the request for the information on the one hand and the request that the charge be waived on the other. It continues:

It is not clear from your latest correspondence whether your contention that charges should not be imposed is based on the fact that payment of the charges would cause financial hardship to your organisation or whether giving of access is in the general public interest, or in the interest of a substantial section of the public, or both.
Again, it is beautifully obfuscating these two quite separate issues. The letter goes on:
Should you contend that payment of the charges would cause financial hardship to your organisation—
and notice that this is to a public interest organisation, namely the Wilderness Society of Victoria—

you should provide details of your organisation's income, estimated weekly commitments and available cash in the bank or building society or like accounts as a basis for assessing the degree of hardship involved in the payment of the charges in question.

Should you contend that giving of access is in the general public interest or in the interest of a substantial section of the public you should provide the following information in support of your contention:

.details of the objects of your organisation and other information which would demonstrate a special interest in the specific subject matter of your requests, observing that intellectual or emotional concern for the environment is not enough to constitute such an interest.

Really, that means that only having either an economic or a political interest in the matter would bring it within the purview which would allow the department to provide this information. That draws a very narrow constriction around the availability of information which clearly, just from the general context of the debate which has gone on for many months over the woodchip licences and the exploitation of forests, would lead the department to know it was in the public interest. It goes on:
.whether The Wilderness Society is the peak environmental organisation for the areas covered by your FOI Requests . . .

That is implicitly saying that if one is not in some way recognised as the peak organisation by some mechanism—and I am not sure what the mechanism is—then one is not entitled to get the information. Again, I would have thought that freedom of information meant that anybody who had a reasonable interest in getting that information for the purposes of entering the public debate should have access to the information.
.whether The Wilderness Society is the peak environmental organisation for the areas covered by your FOI Requests—
How is that defined, and who decides?
and how its activities relate to these areas, observing that one request relates to areas of Victoria and the other relates to woodchip licenses in all states.
Of course, those two are quite closely related. The letter then goes on:
.evidence that The Wilderness Society has been recognised by the Commonwealth as a responsible environmental organisation.

Does that mean that an individual or an organisation that has not been recognised by the Commonwealth can simply on those grounds have an FOI request refused? Those words clearly imply that that is the case. What does recognition by the Commonwealth as a responsible environmental organisation actually mean? It goes on:
Such recognition could be in the form of regular financial grants for the general purposes of the organisation or grants in relation to projects and conferences on matters of environmental concern.

Does that mean that all those conservation bodies that are not in receipt of Commonwealth grants under the various budgets are not legitimate organisations, and therefore can automatically be denied any freedom of information request? Clearly, that is implied in that paragraph. It goes on:
.evidence that The Wilderness Society has been recognised by State governments as a body that should represent environmental concerns on advisory or similar committees.

So not only does it have to be an organisation which by some weird definition is a peak conservation organisation and is recognised as a peak conservation, it also has to be recognised by the Commonwealth as a responsible environmental organisation and has to be recognised by the state government. What a catalogue of criteria is put up in the way of the Wilderness Society obtaining this information! Further, the letter says:
.details of significant submissions and/or studies by your organisation on forestry management and related issues.

Remember, Mr Acting Deputy President, that this is an organisation which by and large is a voluntary organisation. It is working in the public interest as it sees it. One can argue about that, and I do not doubt both government and opposition would argue about that, but I do not think they would argue about the general proposition that according to its lights it is acting in the public interest, and therefore has a legitimate right to enter the debate and therefore a legitimate right to get the information. Finally, the letter says:
.what benefits will flow to the public at large, or a substantial section of the public, from the release of the documents . . .

My God, talk about a catch-22! It has not yet got the documents and it is asked to provide the benefits which are going to flow to the public at large, or a substantial section of the public, from the release of those documents.

PARA.TAB: There is a reasonable case for supposing that those documents are central to the ongoing debate over how this federal government and various state governments have handled the forestry issue, but in terms of delineating, as is asked, precisely what benefits would flow, that places the organisation in an absolute catch-22 situation and provides a condition which could not be fulfilled. The letter concludes:

SPEECH.PARA: A decision will be made on your request for remission of charges on receipt of the above information.

In other words, the processing of this FOI request would not go forward until all these conditions are met. The implication is that each and every one of those conditions needs to be met. I return to the point at the beginning: what an arrogant letter to write to an organisation which is widely recognised and which is seeking legitimate information in an area of its concern, clearly recognised in the community as an area of its concern, which is vital to entering this debate over forestry and woodchip licences. Clearly, this department has no intention whatsoever of providing that information. It is simply putting every obstacle in the way of those who might legitimately seek to get that information. Mr Acting Deputy President, I have read all but a couple of introductory and final sentences in this letter and I seek leave to incorporate the letter in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In commencing my remarks this afternoon, I note that I am in fact the third Tasmanian Liberal senator to be involved in this debate. I think it just follows the proud tradition the Tasmanian Liberal senators have established in this place of being effective and rigorous representatives for their state.

PARA.TAB: Ever since the Green-Labor accord government experiment in my home state, our economy has been very fragile. After difficult and often gut wrenching decisions, the Groom Liberal government has made the necessary reforms to assist small business in my home state. My fellow Tasmanians are now acknowledging that, as witnessed by the substantial increase in support for the government in the latest poll and the fantastic support received by Peter McKay, the Leader of the Government, in last week's Legislative Council elections. A recent yellow pages survey shows that Tasmanian small business has defied the national trend by expressing increased confidence in their future. So small business, like Tasmanians generally, are now recognising the foresight and strength of leadership of the Groom Liberal government.

However, the greatest threat to Tasmania's economic recovery is the federal Labor government itself. Of course, the latest budget rips out another $57 million of funding from Tasmania by way of increased taxes. The federal Labor government has walked over my state and over its rights with hobnail boots. It stops the harnessing of our resources; it seeks to drain our lakes, stopping our `clean green' electricity generation; it locks up over one-fifth of our land mass; it stops us from sensibly harvesting our forests; and it stops businesses such as Barry Arnold and Sons from being able to export.

On top of all that, the Labor Party then gives us these paternalistic and, indeed, very condescending lectures about how Tasmania ought be run and the need to develop clean green niche businesses. One such clean green niche business was developed well before that became a trendy term, and before the Labor Party caught onto the term and got into the act. Of course, I refer to our aquaculture industry. This industry employs 2,000 of my fellow Tasmanians and that industry is now at risk.

The risk to which it is being subjected is the potential adoption by Labor of a draft report by AQIS, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. AQIS considered the import risk analysis related to diseases associated with the importation of uncooked salmon product from North America. The import risk analysis, as presented by AQIS just this month, concluded that the risks of importing disease are negligible and that importation under the suggested conditions is acceptable.

This view is not shared by the Tasmanian government, our aquaculture industry or those associated with the recreational trout fishery. The reason is that the product under consideration is subject to at least 24 exotic diseases of concern to the salmonid and recreational trout fishing industries. At least eight of these diseases, some of which are the marine equivalent of food-and-mouth disease, are likely to be present in fresh product should importation be permitted.
The AQIS document contains a number of deficiencies. In the final analysis, the AQIS conclusions underrate and undervalue the seriousness and acceptability of the risk inherent in the proposal.

Australia is recognised as free of the major diseases of salmon and trout which are common in nearly every other continent and country. Many of these exotic diseases have serious consequences in other countries. They can cause high levels of mortality and frequently reduce the productivity of fish farms. Some cannot be satisfactorily controlled, while others require vaccination or high levels of antibiotics to reduce losses to a viable level. The industry in my state is saved from all that because it is disease free.

Relatively high water temperatures in Australia mean that salmon and trout are at the upper end of their range. The stress this causes, together with the fact that many fish diseases are more severe in warmer waters, makes Australian fish very susceptible to these diseases should they be introduced.

It is acknowledged that Australia has world trade obligations. Under GATT those obligations require importing countries such as Australia to justify health related restrictions in a transparent scientific and technical way. The risk analysis process used by AQIS does fit the guidelines. However, countries free of the diseases in question—and clearly Australia is such a country—are also expected to take into account the feasibility of control and eradication and relevant economic, social and environmental factors. Additionally, if there are gaps or shortcomings in the scientific or technical information, countries are expected to be conservative and err on the side of caution. The AQIS document fails to take these very important aspects into account.

The risk analysis fails to take into account the feasibility of control and eradication of the disease if introduced. The simple fact is that eradication is not a realistic expectation, but AQIS attaches little importance to the long-term consequences that would result from disease outbreak. The risk analysis fails to take fully into account relevant economic, social and environmental factors. A disease outbreak would have a serious long-term effect on Tasmania's economy. Aquaculture and recreational fisheries are expanding and creating major employment opportunities in areas with no alternative options. A matter of interest as well is the potential effects on world heritage areas and the native fish populations within Tasmania. They are ignored by the report.

The risk analysis ignores considerations available to Australia's stance under GATT, the World Trade Organisation and OIE guidelines. Australia's obligations under GATT and the World Trade Organisation clearly allow for Australia to take full account of the consequences of disease outbreak and of our current freedom from the major diseases of salmon. AQIS has not done that. The risk to native fish, including those in the world heritage areas, has not been considered.

Comparisons with the importation of red meat from countries with foot-and-mouth disease are very interesting. The criteria used by the Australian government in protecting the grazing industry against foot-and-mouth disease are very different from those being recommended by AQIS for protection against salmonid diseases. This double standard exposes my state, in particular, to an ongoing socioeconomic risk in the case of salmonid diseases.

The AQIS report acknowledges that while the risk of introduction and establishment in Australia of exotic diseases is currently very low, the risk is not zero. It is therefore essential that full consideration be given to the relevant socioeconomic factors that would follow the entry, establishment and spread of the diseases—24 have been listed and eight are probable. Therefore, the low probability of disease establishment does little to distinguish between safe and unsafe importations and is not the critical factor in determining whether an import should proceed or be banned. This highlights the relative importance of the feasibility of disease eradication and of the potential economic, social and environmental implications of importation in the event of a disease outbreak. It also highlights the importance of the susceptibility of a disease outbreak to eradication.

The Australian atlantic salmon industry is confined entirely to my home state of Tasmania where it provides major employment in some of the more regional and sparsely populated areas where unemployment is very high. Recreational trout fisheries extend beyond Tasmania to several mainland states. The potential for social disruption as a consequence of disease entering recreational trout fisheries in Tasmania alone has not been fully evaluated. Based on the consequences of the recent discovery of European carp, they are expected to be on a similar scale to the disruption of the salmonid industry.

The trout fishing industry in my home state of Tasmania is a very substantial industry. It attracts a lot of interstate and overseas visitors for the one purpose, that is, fishing for trout in our rivers and lakes. The possibility of disease being introduced could devastate that wilderness experience, which is another thing that the Labor Party keeps lecturing Tasmania about by saying, `Sure, we're locking up vast tracts of your land, but at least you can sell yourself as a tourist state.' When they make their final determinations, AQIS and the federal government ought to be considering that as well.

I am aware that Senator Tierney would like to make a contribution to this debate, so I will conclude my remarks at this stage. I plead with the government to protect Tasmania's aquaculture industry against importation of product from North America, not on the basis that the Tasmanian industry cannot economically compete with the imports but on the basis that, if these products are allowed in, there is a risk of disease.

If that disease gets into our aquaculture industries, they will be devastated. The fish will need to be handled more often and they will need to be submitted to treatment by antibiotics and other chemicals. Production will be more expensive, and, therefore, it will be less economic for my state to be able to compete with North American supplies. The fish will also lose their status of being clean, green and not subjected to chemical and other medication. I also plead with them to take into account the potential fate of our native fish population.

I began by saying that the Labor government has completely neglected my state. This is an opportunity for the government to do something positive for my state, and I encourage it to protect the livelihood of the industry which looks after some 2,000 Tasmanians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a story for the Senate about small business in Australia. Small business is under immense pressure to survive, but the Hunter region in my home state of New South Wales is currently leading the small business owners of the nation to take a stand. Small business is certainly down, but it is not out. Owners of small businesses in the Hunter are organised as never before to raise their heads above the ruck and to attract Australia-wide media and political attention. At the core of their anger is the belief that supermarkets and chain stores are driving their businesses into the ground. This is no idle, overblown claim.

PARA.TAB: The group of small business people in the Hunter region has kept accurate figures on business closures in the area and they have case files that should rock the ALP government. The battlers in mainstream Australia are in dire straits because in 12 years the Labor government has not kept pace with the changes in retailing and it has not made an appropriate legislative response.

Over the last four years in the Hunter region, one business has closed every day. One business every day! Who are the casualties of this crisis? We are not talking about glamour businesses here. We are talking about the traditional family retailer from any main shopping centre or street strip: fruit shops, butcher shops, hot bread shops, delicatessens, chicken shops, bottle shops, gift and novelty shops, newsagencies and even chemists.

The alarming reality is that nearly 3,000 small businesses have stopped trading in the Hunter region alone. This situation is alarming for one region, but the big picture right across Australia shows all the signs of the decay of our commercial sector. We are talking about a huge slab of Australia's economic activity. There are over 800,000 small businesses in this country and they employ 47 per cent of the work force; this is what is at risk.

In my own area, the anger has been simmering beneath the surface for some time. It has now broken out and the people in small businesses are desperate for some effective action. These people will wield whatever political and media power they can muster, and their efforts so far have achieved national prominence.

The Newcastle mayday call rally on Friday, 19 March focused the attention of federal, state and local government on the problem that small retailers have. So it should, because the federal minister, the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht), constantly denies in this parliament that the problem has three dimensions: it has a local dimension, it has a state dimension and it has a federal dimension. Senator Schacht was flushed out of his ivory tower to attend the rally in Newcastle, together with the shadow minister for small business, the honourable member for Pearce (Mrs Moylan). The Prime Minister told him to get up to Newcastle, because the Prime Minister was, of course, in damage control mode after his insulting jibe to small business, `It's never going to get better.'

On the night, the program was covered by the Nine Network's Business Sunday program, ABC Radio National and ABC TV News. Many regional networks also took the story. The message of the Newcastle rally was strong and it focused on the real need for a rescue mission for small business in this country. Three main grievances were raised at the rally: nnrestricted trading hours; predatory pricing and misuse of market power by large chain stores; and unfair legal agreements between shopping centre managements and their small business tenants.
I will read for the Hansard record the text of a sign displayed outside a fruit shop in Newcastle last week. I think it sums up, in essence, the three dimensions of this problem. The sign read:

SPEECH.PARA: Customers . . . we are closing down today: Reason 24 hour trading and price wars between supermarkets have halved our turnover and we are losing money every week. The Council, our landlord still wants us to pay the rent of $1,000 a week on the empty space next door. They will not help. Total rent on this shop $2,468 a week. What choice do we have? 12 more on the dole Monday.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a lot of apples—$2,000 a week.

—It sure is, as Senator Campbell says. This message should, I believe, make all governments sit up and take notice. There is another story which shows the craziness of current business practices that are driving many small businesses in this country to the wall. Take the story of Peter Craig from Lake Macquarie Fair: he is the baker who cannot bake bread. Why cannot he bake bread? He cannot bake bread because of the shopping tenancy agreement that he had to sign to stay in business there. He was asked—or I should say `told'—to let a competitor bake it. He is also restricted from selling tea, coffee and a number of other products as part of his lease agreement with the shopping centre management.

PARA.TAB: The response of the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction to the problems and the plight of small business people—such as in the two examples I have just read—is inadequate and disappointing. In April, he wrote to the small business people in Newcastle to wash his hands of responsibility. He said it was a local and state government issue and that supermarkets were the best places to meet modern demands in retailing. He said he had no federal power under the Trade Practices Act to stop misuse of market power or unconscionable conduct by large chain stores. Three strikes and Senator Schacht is out! He has put himself right out of the game as far as small business people in this country are concerned. His record shows a total lack of interest in acting at the federal level. He showed that in April and it has not improved since.

During budget week, he told the Senate that he would set up a working party. He wants small businesses to provide him with examples of predatory pricing and misuse of market power. He should have come with me last Sunday down to the Mayfield Shopping Centre: he would not have needed a report, all he would have had to do was walk along the street to see that all the businesses were shut and that, nearby, a huge supermarket outlet with 18 people on checkouts was having an enormous through-put. A thriving shopping centre has been decimated in a short period by this change.

Action is needed at all levels of government. We need it at a local level, at a state level and particularly at the federal level. We call on Minister Schacht, who has just arrived in the chamber, to stop beating about the bush. He should stop blaming other levels of government and past policies and should use the powers that he has to reform the act in the way he knows he can, in order to do something about this situation to help small business in this country compete on an equitable basis and thus survive.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the minister to Mr Keating's comments in relation to the current account deficit in 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: I think the first thing I'd say is . . . that today's number is much higher than we would have wished but . . . the progress on Australia's current account is being delayed and diminished by a very strong investment phase.
That is, most of the lift in imports . . . is still coming from machinery importation . . . it is coming from the very things which, over time, will produce a much stronger economy.

Six years later, isn't that exactly the argument the minister used in the Senate yesterday to justify the huge current account deficit Australia faces again? When the rhetoric and excuses are the same, why should Australians believe that today's circumstances are any different from those that preceded the massive rise in interest rates in the late 1980s and the recession we had to have?

TALK.START.PARA: —This is frankly outrageous. The opposition, which does not have a policy idea to rub together, seizes on anything, no matter how irrelevant, in order to try to undermine the Australian economy. Fortunately, for the people of Australia, the economy is in the groove. It is in a phase of strong, steady and sustained growth.

PARA.TAB: The March quarter figures and the balance of payments figures that have come out today are proof of that. Those figures illustrate that the economy is consistent with budget forecasts. It is on track for the 1994-95 estimate of 4.75 per cent of growth year average in GDP. There are two reasons why that figure is achievable. There is a significant upward revision in growth for the September and December quarters. We believe that the pick-up in growth in the June quarter, based on a number of performance indicators and particularly on the capital expenditure survey, with an expectation of business investment of seven per cent, will show that we can expect to deliver growth which is strong, sustainable and steady. This is exactly the sort of growth that this economy needs. It is the sort of growth that we can deliver.

We have a question about, effectively, the current account. We have had this debate in the last three days in question time. The question does not seem to have changed, despite the information that has been given. While the actual number in the forward estimates for the budget that we have put down is the same year on year, nonetheless there has been a fall in the current account. The figures that have come out today illustrate that that, too, is on track.

Indeed, the interesting thing about the March quarter figures which bears repeating in this chamber is that exports grew by 2.8 per cent during the March quarter and imports grew by two per cent, which is to say that we are exporting more than we are importing. The national expenditure and national output figures have come closer together. We can be confident that the current account is turning around.

I repeat that what we have from today's quarterly accounts is figures that encourage people to have a great deal of confidence in the forward estimates in the budget, which shows strong, steady and sustainable growth. The opposition does not seem to have challenged that. It has pointed to a weakness of the current account in the overall economy. But, again, by those figures, exports in the last month outpaced imports. That is also a very positive sign.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the minister says that we should have confidence that the current account is turning around, is he now saying that the budget projection, on which he said the current account deficit would be as bad in this next budget year as it has been in the last, is wrong? When he says that the economy is in the groove, that is what the question is all about. Is it not in the same groove that it was in in the late 1980s, when the government was using the same excuses that it has been using for the last three days? Will it not lead to the same consequence, which is rising interest rates and another recession?

—That makes three times this week. It is about time you did not mangle my words and actually repeated them back to me honestly—which would be a big break from your practice, Senator Hill, I have to say. The current account is falling. That is what the budget forecast is about.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. If you are not allowed to call someone a liar, why are you able to get up and say, `If you did so honestly, which would be a change for you'? That carries the clear inference that someone is dishonest. You cannot have it both ways here, Mr President—as I keep telling you—you have to apply the rules evenly.

—Senator Hill misrepeated, re-emphasised and misconstrued the words in my answer to give them a completely alternative meaning. Why did Senator Vanstone not call him to order for his misleading this chamber? It is entirely appropriate for me to point that out at the beginning of my reply.
—Order! In response to the point of order I note that if I were to pick up every variation in the way that notion can be expressed I would never stop pulling people up. It is not out of order.

—The other important thing about these figures is the growth in manufacturing output. That is very good. We have had 13 consecutive quarters of manufacturing output growth, with seven per cent growth in the March quarter.

PARA.TAB: If we look at the farm growth, there has been a reduction there due to the drought of 26.5 per cent. In other words, in the manufacturing sector we have had growth in exports from manufacturing—the most value added and valuable area to the Australian economy—holding up despite the big impact of the drought on our national accounts.

They are reasons for celebration and encouragement and reasons to recognise the hard won improvements being made in the economy. They are not reasons to try to sabotage confidence, as the opposition wishes to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's Gallery of His Royal Highness the Sultan of Jogjakarta, who is leading a trade delegation to Australia. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Trade. Some honourable senators would be aware that I have vivid memories of a visit to India in 1993. Probably because of that visit, I was interested in recent discussions about growing opportunities for Australia to trade with India. Minister, has there been any evaluation of the major trade mission you led to India in February this year? If so, what does the evaluation reveal about the real opportunities for Australian business in India and what should we be doing to make the most of those opportunities?

—This is a good opportunity to deal with this matter, being in the presence of such a distinguished trade delegation. The trade mission to India can be used to illustrate some of the things we are trying to achieve through our program of trade missions, our attempt through that to enhance our trade in India, as Senator Colston referred to, and the broader question of our trade profile.

PARA.TAB: India is quite a good example. It illustrates how we are trying to fit trade missions into broader trade promotional activities: studies, like that done by the East Asia Analytical Unit on our trade opportunities with India; the concerted business promotions, like the trade and investment outlook conference; the opening of Austrade offices in Calcutta, Madras and Bangalore; and fitting those in with sector specific missions to India, like the one Senator Schacht led on construction, the one that special trade representative John Button led on telecommunications, and that which David Beddall led recently, as a consequence of my visit, on coal mining and technology.

The second thing that the Indian mission illustrated, and which is an important trend, is the cooperation between the private sector and the states. It was a mission that we shared with the Western Australian government, through the Deputy Premier, Hendy Cowan, and with the private sector, through those on our mission and others from the Australia-India Business Council and through the academic community. In particular, it was about trying to build on that momentum to change the image of the Australian economy, to illustrate the diversity and sophistication of the economy, and to address some of the continuing errors in perception of Australia.

The business mission featured banking, insurance, telecommunications and engineering as well as our traditional strengths in mining and agriculture. We are trying to build on our strengths, as David Beddall's subsequent mission on coal mining and technology illustrated, while adding to it through new areas like telecommunications, other communications facilities, infrastructure, construction and services.

We did get some interesting joint ventures in those areas during the course of the visit. These changes are being increasingly reflected in our trade profile. We see an increase in the percentage of our exports of sophisticated goods and services, the most rapidly growing area of our exports being manufactures followed by services. But we need to do more. India is a very good case in point.

The East Asia Analytical Unit report said that India's economic growth output suggests that we could get a doubling of Australia's annual exports to India by the year 2000 which, if I recall the figures correctly, would mean an extra $1 billion of exports. But we will need to diversify our exports to maintain our market share. We cannot just do it by doing better in our traditional areas. We need to move into the new areas of growth in Indian imports.

That was one of the factors that motivated the composition of the trade mission and the priorities that we set. We did an evaluation of the mission. We are trying more and more to evaluate missions when they are conducted. The business people on the mission, in particular, emphasised the value of the mission for networking and for establishing a credible business presence. That seemed to me to be an admirable reflection of the fact that they are taking a long-term view.

We did get some short-term benefits with joint ventures and MOUs, but they are not the key measures. The key measure is the extent to which these missions contribute to changing our trade profile, building on our strengths, and broadening the basis of our trade. The evaluation suggested that, while no one measure ever solves all our problems, it has made a significant contribution to some of the issues that Senator Colston and others have raised as a result of their visits to India in the past and which the research says we need to continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the minister representing the Treasurer. I remind the minister that, in this year's budget, interest payments on Commonwealth debt will exceed $10 billion. Are these interest payments as much as the government's total education budget? Are they as much as the entire defence budget? Are they three times the total training and employment assistance budget? Are they three times the science and technology budget? Is not the cold hard fact that Labor cannot properly fund our future because it is just too busy paying for its past?
—You never ran a surplus in 31 years in government.

—All I can imagine is that Senator Vanstone has asked this question in order to try and make a rhetorical point rather than any sound economic point. I might acknowledge the interjection from my colleague the Minister for Trade, Senator McMullan. When the coalition was in government it never ran a surplus at all. In this budget that we will adopt in this chamber shortly we will run a surplus and it will—
—The real deficit is over $8 billion.

—Why do we not go to Moody's, the international credit rating house, and quote what it said about our budget. Moody's said that the budget `is in surplus and that is a good thing'. Moody's rubbished the argument that Senator Hill is making saying that it is not the important element. The important element is the bottom line, and the bottom line is surplus.

PARA.TAB: In the following year we will see a situation in which the budget is in structural surplus in excess of $400 million. For the first time in a long time, and the second time in our period of government, the Australian budget will have reached surplus; the level of national savings will have grown; downward pressure on interest rates will have come into play; downward pressure on inflation will have come into play; and there will be the ability for Australia to raise funds for internal investment. As a result, the change in the Australian economy from being an investment-seeking nation to an investment-providing nation will have occurred.

These are major, important and fundamental long-term historic trends. The fact that we have been managing for over two years a recession in which there was countercyclical investment by the government to pull this country out of recession is good economic management. We are now well out of it—13 consecutive quarters out of it—and we are now in a budget surplus. Senator Vanstone, I would be pleased if you would acknowledge some of those things rather than try to make some sort of arcane rhetorical point, as you have in this question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I would be grateful for some indication from you at a later stage, because no doubt you do not know now, as to what a rhetorical point is. But we will leave that for another day. Put aside the rhetoric about failing to fund the future because you are paying for the past. I accept your answer on that; I think it is rubbish, but that is all I expect from you. Let us come back to the simple facts of the matter. You defend this budget, so you ought to know all about it. What we need you to tell us is what you were asked, that is: is it not true that in this year's budget, interest payments on Commonwealth debt exceed $10,000 million? You know the budget so well and you defend it, so why don't you tell us. Are these interest payments as much as the total education budget? Are they as much as the entire defence budget? Are they three times the total training and employment assistance budget? And are they three times the science and technology budget? If you are so proud of the budget, why do you not defend that?

—I was asked to define a rhetorical point. Let me say that, in your case, a rhetorical point is a flight of political fantasy which has nothing much at all to do with the underlying substance of the issue. That is an appropriate description for you and for your venture into the fields of rhetoric. As far as the rest of this question is concerned, I have answered it in general terms. If I have a need to answer it in more detailed terms, I will do so later.

—I address my question to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Can the minister inform the Senate about measures he has taken in requesting the Australian Sports Commission to combat racism in sport?

—I thank Senator Reynolds for her question. Let me again make my position on this issue absolutely clear: there is no place for racism in Australian sport. I am very keen for the government and for the sporting community to work closely together with the common aim of stamping out racism in sport. Earlier this month, I wrote to the Chairman of the Australian Sports Commission, Mike Fitzpatrick, to ask the commission to take strong and constructive action on this issue.

PARA.TAB: I asked the ASC to work closely with sporting organisations, with ATSIC and with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to develop a comprehensive strategy to combat racism in sport. I am pleased to say that the commission board met last week and has agreed to put a comprehensive strategy in place and to do so quickly. The strategy will include education programs and Aboriginal sports participation programs, including providing special assistance to NSOs with high Aboriginal participation rates. The strategy includes modifying the codes of conduct in sports, including ensuring that racist sledging is an offence and subject to punitive action.

The debate about racism has also brought to the fore the issue of Aboriginal participation in sporting activity, and the Australian Sports Commission has been working for some time now on measures to improve access to sport and recreation by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I have asked the Sports Commission to work closely with ATSIC to expand our programs to ensure that we are working to improve participation at all levels—from the grassroots level to the elite level.

Regarding the needs of elite Aboriginal athletes in particular, the ASC and the Australian Olympic Committee have been developing a program for some time. This program will target talented Aboriginal sports people and provide them with coaching and support services to assist them in achieving olympic standards.

Australia has already put in place the Oceania and Africa olympic programs, which include intensive coaching, sport science and sports medicine services, and athlete support. We are now at the point of establishing a parallel program for potential Aboriginal olympians. Such a program could include the establishment of an indigenous olympic training centre and the establishment of a talent identification program focusing on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders as well as providing opportunity for greater exposure of olympic sports in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. I am committed to working closely with the olympic movement to make these proposals a reality, as is the government. I think these cooperative programs intended to address racism and Aboriginal sports participation are very good examples of the government's approach to developing strategic partnerships with Australian sport for the benefit of all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given that to date 114 members and senators have signed a statement to the Commonwealth Games Association expressing concern about Arthur Tunstall's comments about Cathy Freeman and Lionel Rose, does the minister believe that this cross-party expression will assist the strategy to combat racism in sport?

—I have indicated that, while Arthur Tunstall has given long service to both the Commonwealth Games Association and the sport of boxing, I do believe a number of comments that he has made have been damaging to Australia's reputation as a sporting nation. I have made very clear that, in the light of those comments and as a result of that damage, I do believe it is time for Arthur Tunstall to resign.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In 1990 the then Treasurer, Paul Keating, accused the banks of excessive margins and fees and generally of ripping off customers. The government set up an inquiry. Five years later, with the banks pretty well unrepentant, unreformed and highly profitable, Ralph Willis has set up another inquiry. If we believe the press, they are talking about basic banking accounts on which there will be no fees. Given that the government is selling the Commonwealth Bank and with it the opportunity of forcing a more customer focused banking industry through competition, what measures will the government take to ensure that banks fulfil their community service obligations by reforming practices your government has been carping about for five years, inquiring into for five years and also doing nothing about for five years?

—As this question acknowledges, the Treasurer has set up an inquiry into bank fees and charges. The reasons we have done that is that we recognise there is a need to get all of the facts out on the table and plan the appropriate response. That is why the PSA has been asked to inquire into this. It should be recognised that it is not simply an issue solely about bank charges. It also involves questions about the social security payments system. These two factors mean that there are problems—I acknowledge that—for low income people who need or want to use their bank accounts frequently.

PARA.TAB: They are straightforward reasons why the government has asked the PSA to conduct this inquiry and to look at a range of issues within the scope of the inquiry so that they can feed back recommendations to the government on the sorts of issues implicit in Senator Kernot's question—that is, all of the things about the banks as well as the social responsibilities of the banks in this situation. While the inquiry has generated a lot of community debate, the government will welcome a full and public discussion about its findings. As to what we will do about the issue, we will have to wait until the inquiry has considered the evidence and reported. Then we will respond to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, does the government never have a long-term policy position as you do such things as deregulate? Do you not have a view on whose responsibility it is, under policy, to provide those community service obligations? Is it banks, credit unions or no-one's? Who is going to do this? Why do you not think about that at the beginning, rather than at the end?

—One of the big benefits to Australian consumers of financial market and bank deregulation has been the introduction of a greater degree of competition between banks. That will ensure, therefore, a greater degree of product differentiation, which has meant that consumers have been able to shop between banks and other financial institutions in order to get a better financial deal. I can go to a number of examples of demonstrably greater competition between banks and where consumers have reaped the reward. The government does recognise the need for some clearer intelligence on this issue of obligations to the wider community. It is for that reason that we are having the inquiry that will report in June. That is just next month, beginning tomorrow; so we are not all that far away from getting a recommendation, on which we will be acting, on this subject.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I read with interest the Treasurer's remarks in his budget speech about the sale of Dasfleet. I do not want to debate that issue, but I have followed the debate since that time in some media outlets. They have cast some doubt on the figures in the budget speech about the sale of Dasfleet. Can the Minister now clarify for the Senate—for members on this side, in particular—what is the true situation concerning the sale of Dasfleet?

—It is certainly not the situation that the shadow minister, Peter Costello, says it is. In the reply to the budget, Mr Howard announced that the opposition would bring in a charter of budget honesty, or some such thing. Let us apply the charter of budget honesty to the pronouncements of the shadow Treasurer. I will demonstrate he is wrong, flat wrong and absolutely wrong. In the face of a true representation of the facts, not a manipulation and distortion of the facts as he has engaged in, if the charter of budget honesty is to amount to anything, his leader should discipline him or he should withdraw his remarks and apologise for misleading the people of Australia.

PARA.TAB: In a press release from Mr Costello—I cannot find the date of it—headed `The DASFLEET swindle', he said that the government had introduced an accounting rort. He went on to compare the sale of Dasfleet and the sale of Qantas. Mr Costello is wrong about that. He ought to withdraw. Anyone, including Mr Costello, who read the budget papers properly would know that Mr Costello was wrong. For the record, what does the budget say about the Dasfleet announcement? The first thing is that the government is not selling Dasfleet. That is the first thing about this announcement. The government is undertaking a scoping study with a view to determining the best way to sell—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not selling it now.

—Wait for it or you will get it wrong and go down the Costello path. I was talking about Dasfleet vehicles, not the institution. Dasfleet will then lease them back. That is not an uncommon practice in business. It is not a rort; it is good business management. Dasfleet will continue to exist and, because it provides vehicles to Commonwealth agencies and because it continues to trade, it will return a profit. That is why the budget shows an income stream from Dasfleet after the vehicles have been sold.

PARA.TAB: The government decision is designed to provide Dasfleet with a better financing arrangement, one that is more flexible and responsive to its needs. Dasfleet will now access finance on the same lines as private sector lessees. The whole press release of Peter Costello—I have it here—is absolutely misleading. I challenge the opposition, if this charter of budget honesty is to amount to anything, to apply it now. The opposition should apply it to its shadow Treasurer, bring him into line and make him recant and tell the truth to the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Minister, is it not a fact that your high interest rate policy has left households with an enormous debt burden? Is it not a fact that household debt, which was 42 per cent of household disposable income in 1983, is now a massive 66 per cent of household disposable income? Have not households accumulated as much debt in the last five years as they did in the previous 10 years? How will your budget, which dispensed with the l-a-w tax cuts, help households which are still struggling with the leftovers of the last recession?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am tempted to commence my reply to this question by citing the record of Mr Howard when he was Treasurer in the Commonwealth compared with our record on interest rates. Let me paraphrase it without going to all of the statistics. Because your party will not produce a single policy and no-one knows where you stand, the alternative for us is to look at your record and judge what you mean to do by how you performed when you last had the opportunity.

ANSWER.PARA: Your interest rate record is a damned site worse—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. The minister should attempt to answer the question he was asked. That is: has not household debt doubled in the last five years? How will your budget help it?
—The minister made it clear that he was using this as a preamble. I hope that is the case.

—I want it firmly on the record that your performance, no matter how good ours is, is a lot worse than ours. The people of Australia know all about that. If that is your ability to manage an economy, they will know who the superior economic managers are—us, not you.

PARA.TAB: The significant thing about our budget has been to move the budget from deficit to surplus and to introduce a set of budget settings which have ameliorated pressure on interest rates. As we have seen, interest rates have fallen since the budget has come out, and that is an indication in part of the confidence that the market has in the budget. I might say it is not appropriate, nor have government spokesmen ever got into the position of commenting on what interest rate movements might be for the future. But certainly it is fair to say that all the economic commentators do recognise that the structure of this budget—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I wonder how long this preamble is to go on. You indicated to the minister that you would let go on for a while with the preamble, but the question was quite clearly in respect of disposable income. It did not relate to interest rates or any other thing the minister is talking about.
—There is no point of order.

—There is no point of order, but it does demonstrate the sensitivity of the opposition. I was making the point in answer to the question that the budget framework puts pressure to lower interest rates, and that is the intention of the government. The government has a policy of strong, steady, sustainable growth, which is what the current account figures of today show.

PARA.TAB: On the subject of household income, might I also say that the current account figures show considerable growth in the level of household disposable income for a whole host of reasons, including the uptake in employment, the level of job security leading to wage growth and a whole range of other factors. From today's statistics, which is the most recent window on how the economy is performing, household disposable income grew in the last quarter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Minister, our policy of a charter for budget honesty is really to show up what your government is about. I contrast that with a package of running the economy well. Let us contrast that with New Zealand, where 10-year bond rates are now about two per cent lower than in Australia because the international world judges New Zealand to be better managed than your government. All Australians should have the advantage of lower interest rates if you would manage the economy well.
—Since the budget the interest rate level has come down half a per cent. I just commend that to your attention. A small fact, but you ought to notice it because it is important.

PARA.TAB: I secondly said that under your time in office, you had higher interest rates on average than under our time in office. Household disposable income, which is the real measure of how ordinary Australians are going, according to today's figures—the most recent figures available—has improved. That is a current situation state of the nation report.

Not only that, but if we look to the future, one can see the whole structure of the budget moving in to surplus, creating a pool of national savings, thus putting further downward pressure on interest rates. That is a reason for confidence and that is a reason why not only the general community but as well the business community have applauded our budget and received it well.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs representing the Minister for Justice. I refer the minister to the recent incidents in Queensland and South Australia involving the use of firearms in break and enters. I also draw the minister's attention to the most recent figures released by the Australian Institute of Criminology which show that suicides and accidental deaths by firearms outnumber murders by more than six to one. Could the minister inform the Senate about any recent moves by the government to tighten controls of firearms in Australia?

—I thank Senator Jones for his question, particularly for highlighting the annual tragedy of suicides and accidental deaths by firearms. On the Commonwealth level, we do have a commitment to reduce the number of unnecessary firearms in the Australian community. That has always been the major reason for the Commonwealth government's determination to promote a common approach on a state and federal level to gun control.

PARA.TAB: Our starting point is that we have the strictest import controls on firearms in Australia as compared to anywhere else in the world. In particular, those firearms designed for military purposes to kill people are prohibited imports. Recently, my colleague the Minister for Justice announced that import controls will be tightened even further on pistols capable of being converted to submachine guns and also on ammunition for which there is no reasonable use in Australia. I am sure in that context all senators would agree that there is no reason, for instance, to allow the importation of tracer bullets, explosive bullets, incendiary bullets, armour piercing penetrator ammunition, or pistol ammunition designed to penetrate the soft body armour.

There have been further recent developments as well. At the most recent meeting of Australian police ministers in Hobart last week the Commonwealth proposed, and the states and territories in fact agreed, that we should review the major restrictions that were approved in 1991 to ensure that they are in place and working well. All jurisdictions were concerned to ensure that, in particular, tight controls in one jurisdiction could not be thwarted or undermined by lesser controls in another. I should add that this review will not mean any lessening of controls anywhere. It is intended to re-emphasise the minimum standards, which of course are necessary for effective gun control, but any jurisdiction can, and most do, have much stricter controls.

Senator Jones raises a question of public health and community safety. It is unacceptable, for instance, that more than 450 people die annually from suicides and accidents from firearms. While the government acknowledges that there may be legitimate uses for firearms in a country like Australia, we are concerned to continue to press all jurisdictions to pursue tighter controls of all unnecessary firearms and ammunition.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services representing the Minister for Human Services and Health. I refer the minister to reports that the federal government is seeking to reduce the annual intake into Australian medical schools from about 1,250 to 1,000. Is this correct? If so, will the government ensure that the reductions will not be achieved by the closure of the University of Tasmania medical school or by reducing its intake to a level where its viability is prejudiced to an extent where its closure would become inevitable? What assurances for the future can the government give to the academic staff, support staff, students and future students of the University of Tasmania medical school?
