—This is a very important matter. It has been a matter of concern for government over much more than recent times, particularly to try to get the balance of the medical work force right. The questions raised by Senator Abetz are very important and I will seek a detailed answer for him.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. I ask: what discussions took place between ATSIC and the government concerning special treatment for the Northern Territory for land acquisitions from ATSIC's land acquisition and management program, as mentioned on page 3 of the ATSIC board briefing paper No.1849? Specifically, when were the discussions, who took part in those discussions, were any notes taken of the discussions and what were the views of the government expressed during those discussions?

—It is iniquitous enough that Senator Chamarette seeks, with the support of the opposition, to waste as much of the Senate's time today as is currently being wasted. I point out that this matter is currently being canvassed in the Senate.
—All day!

—Correct; has been since half past nine this morning and is still being canvassed in a debate which has not yet concluded and which will resume immediately after question time this afternoon. I have no personal knowledge of the details that Senator Chamarette raised in respect of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, whom I represent in this chamber. I will direct the question which Senator Chamarette, in pursuing her obsession with this issue, has asked, to the minister. But it is a bit rich, considering that we are going to spend most of the time debating this matter, to have it raised in question time as well.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is extraordinary that, having complained that we have discussed it so much, I still have not been able to gain an answer to the question, which is the topic that the minister should be addressing in his role not only as Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs but as the minister who has been the topic of the censure motion this morning. If the minister does not know anything about discussions that occurred between ATSIC and the government, how does he explain the statement in the ATSIC briefing paper that `there be special treatment for the Northern Territory for land acquisitions from ATSIC's land acquisition and management program, in line with discussions with government and the restrictions of the bill'? I ask the minister to table the notes of any discussions. If he will not do so, why will he not do so?
—That assertion was rebutted specifically by me in debate this morning.
—It was not.

—It took 30 minutes to rebut it. Refer to the Hansard, in so far as you are capable of reading the Hansard, Senator Macdonald, and you will see that that assertion has been rebutted. The Prime Minister has also specifically rebutted it. Senator Chamarette should not believe everything that the New South Wales Land Council tells her. As I said this morning, and I will say it again, not only has it been rebutted, but people who were present at the meeting that did occur—Aboriginal people—have also said it is nonsense and have made the point to me personally. The only people who are continuing to assert it are people who were not at the meeting. So it was rebutted this morning. With regard to the papers, I understand Senator Chamarette has a return to order covering all of that currently in the Senate as well. I did not bother taking a point of order on this, as I could have done. I simply say again, in terms of the Senate's time—
—On a point of order: Senator Chamarette's question was quite direct about the discussions—
—It was out of order.
—He is out of order, too.
—I simply conclude my answer by saying that this is the subject of a major debate which is currently preoccupying the Senate for the whole of today. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health. Minister, are you aware that yesterday the national executive of the Returned Services League unanimously backed a petition, already signed by more than 100,000 people, which opposes a government sex guide? In the House of Representatives on 28 February and again yesterday the Minister for Human Services and Health defended her endorsement of the guide and the expenditure of a quarter of a million dollars of taxpayers' funds on its publication. Why are you continuing to spend taxpayers' money on a guide which contains statements that have no scientific basis and which promotes unsafe practices condemned by the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners and by the medical women's group of the AMA, as well as being offensive to mainstream Australian families?

—Why are you continuing to ask this question when the answer has been very extensively canvassed before? The government's expenditure for this is quite clear and your representation that this Cleo enclosure is promoting unsafe sex is to again misrepresent the contents of that document. It makes quite clear in a list what are safe sex practices and what are risk sex practices. You constantly refuse to include that in your comment.

PARA.TAB: This answer has been canvassed before. We are talking about a targeted audience of mainly younger people between 18 and 30 or thereabouts who read Cleo. That targeted audience, as I have said before and as the minister has said, are people who have picked up this and are going to be provided with very useful information on a whole variety of matters related to sexual practices. That is on the record. We have said that before. We are currently evaluating the outcome of that by seeing whether or not the target audience was reached and what the target audience response is.

TALK.START.PARA: —How are you evaluating that?
—I could come back to you with details about that.
—Why don't you tell us now?
—Because I do not have the full details.
—Because you don't know.

—Because you are so loud, Senator, no-one can ever get a word in edgeways. Because this was mentioned at the estimates the other day, an evaluation process is under way. Senator Vanstone, Senator Herron knows so do leave the question to him. The matter of evaluation about the targeted audience is directed to them. Let us wait for the evaluation. But, from all accounts, that document is providing very useful information in language that is familiar and acceptable to those people. If there are other people in the community who are offended by it, that is a matter of regret; but they are not the targeted audience.

PARA.TAB: We are concerned about making sure that young people in Australia have appropriate and full information about matters of safe sex. We know the problems of AIDS. It has received a number of headlines. We have also been aware of the increasing number of people with sexually transmitted diseases. It is a matter of great importance to make sure that young people have that appropriate information. The government has made that quite clear. Let us wait and see the further outcome of the evaluation. In the meantime, Cleo magazine is directing very valuable information to the audience it was aimed at.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. The medical women's group of the AMA said:

QUESTION.PARA: It was thought that promoting the pleasures of anal intercourse in a safe sex guide is similar to promoting the pleasures of intravenous drug use, also a high risk activity, in an article to discourage the activity.
Is the minister aware of this statement?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Herron asked whether I know this. Yes, I do, because he read it to me and everybody else at the estimates the other night. The point that is important to make about all of this is that this is not a document that promotes those practices. It is equally as valuable to say to people, if they insist on doing things like injecting drugs, that they need to know how to do it with clean needles and more safely. That is separate from promoting it. You might as well argue about a whole lot of things.

PARA.TAB: It is a matter of judgment. None of you over there object to clean needles or a needle exchange, as I understand it. If you do not object to a needle exchange, presumably you also see the value in practising these things in a safe way, provided reasonable and balanced information says that these practices are unsafe. The information says, `If you want to do them, at least these are the ways to minimise the risk.' That is the balance the Cleo guide is promoting and that is why we stand by that publication.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Regional Development. I refer the minister to the development and sale of the Australian Defence Industries sites in Footscray and Maribyrnong in Melbourne. These sites will eventually have more than 500 houses and flats built on them. Is the minister aware that there are now more than 45,000 people waiting for public housing in Victoria? Given the enormity of this waiting list and the chronic shortage of public housing in inner city Melbourne, will the federal government ensure, even at this late stage, that at least 10 per cent of the site is transferred to the Victorian government for public housing?
—I do not have an adequate answer to your question, Senator Spindler. I will undertake to get one and provide it to you as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask: will the government ensure that individual consent must be given by each of the 700,000 trade union members who are reportedly going to be slugged with a levy to pay for the New South Wales Labor Party's huge debt? Does the government condone what is in effect a compulsory political donation from rank and file battlers, Liberal and Labor, to pay—in the words of state Labor MP Paul O'Grady—for Labor's `botched property deals'?
—As Senator Woods would well know, this has nothing to do with the federal areas of my responsibility or the Prime Minister's responsibility. I therefore have no answer to offer.

—Let me just focus on an aspect which is undoubtedly a federal responsibility—that is, the question of tax deductibility. Will the minister confirm that, as I believe is the case with other union dues, these levies will qualify for tax deductibility? If so, is it not true that the taxpayer will be paying off the Labor Party's debt?

—I repeat: any levy that may be struck by the state government of New South Wales is none of the federal government's business, nor would it remain so. Any other levy that is struck by a state government obviously has a taxation consequence, whether it is a business impost or anything else. Equally, it is not an area of Commonwealth responsibility or anything we can do anything about.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. I refer the minister to allegations in a press release yesterday by the opposition spokesperson on family services that jobs in child care may be put at risk because of decisions made in the federal budget. I ask the minister: do the allegations have any foundation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we go again. These are typically ignorant comments by Mr Kemp about the government's very sound decision to allow up to 12 hours of subsidised care in long day care centres for families with one parent who chooses to stay at home or care for children full time.

PARA.TAB: First of all, let me remind the Senate that the median usage by parents of long day care centres for preschool sessions for their children is about 12 hours. That means, for a very large number of families, the 12-hour allowance will mean no change. Let me make it clear, too, that in most cases this will make no difference to the viability of any child-care centres which may have to modify the hours provided to non-work-related care or occasional care users where their use is more than 12 hours.

I also remind the Senate, as I said yesterday, that centres have until April next year to introduce any changes. That is why I think it is quite unconscionable for centres to be charging families for 24-hour care when they are not getting it. Let me give you a quote from an operator, Mr Martin Kemp, who said in the Gold Coast Bulletin on May 17:
Even if a child attends for an hour in the middle of the day their time is used up—

ANSWER.PARA: that is, their whole 12 hours is used up—
because in our books that is a 12-hour day . . .

I am very surprised that the opposition would seem to condone these charging practices which obviously affect the ability of lower income families to pay access. Is Mr David Kemp actually suggesting that we should allow people to charge for 12 hours for one hour's use? Is that the opposition's policy in this area—if you use a child-care centre for one hour, you will be charged for 12 hours? If not, why would the opposition spokesperson be protesting and supporting some of the child-care organisations in this extraordinary campaign?

PARA.TAB: The shadow minister seems to be promoting universal child care for everybody. Do I understand that to be the opposition's policy? The shadow minister was asked at a Queensland meeting on 12 May whether the opposition's criticism of the changes in child care in this budget meant that the coalition would overturn them. The answer was, `I don't know.' That is the opposition's policy on child care. He could not answer because, firstly, he is not clear about the policy and also because his leader, Mr Howard, is saying some very strange things about child care.

In the Telegraph Mirror on 18 March, in an article relating to child care assistance and the child care cash rebate, Mr Howard was quoted as saying that these payments would end under a coalition government. So, on the one hand, Mr Howard is saying that he will remove child care payments and, on the other, Mr Kemp is seemingly promoting universal child care assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which one?

—Well, which one of you is right? Which one of you is going to do it? It is quite clear that Senator Hill does not know what his shadow spokesperson is talking about. The point at issue is that if parents are using child care for one hour and are being charged for 12 hours, you need to ask yourself whether you support such a policy. This government does not. It says that it is very proper to have a balance between work related and occasional care—up to 12 hours for those families. We do not support the practice of some centres—and only some centres—charging for many more hours that families use. When the opposition thinks about it, I suspect it would be much more inclined to support what the government is doing than oppose it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Yesterday Mr Keating sought to defend his weak record on family policy by attacking the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, and Senator Harradine in an anonymous document bandied around the press gallery. If, as Mr Keating says, his policies are family oriented, why has the chairman of the Australian Youth Foundation, Brian Burdekin, made the following comment? He said:

QUESTION.PARA: We're seeing a society in which it is no exaggeration to say that hundreds of thousands of Australian families are disintegrating.

Is it not a fact that in Labor heartland areas such as inner Melbourne nearly 71 per cent of young people are unemployed, in the Illawarra district in New South Wales nearly 39 per cent, and in inner Brisbane 46 per cent? What sort of hypocrisy does Mr Keating display when he continues to parade himself as the protector of Australian families when clearly those families are suffering from his high tax and interest rate regime and his mismanagement of the economy? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that there were some errors in the document circulated out of the Prime Minister's office last night because it understated the advantages to working families of the taxation and related policy embraced by this government. In fact, workers were even better off than was described in that particular document. I understand that the Minister for Social Security will further clarify just how great by comparison with what you lot were able to do has been the accumulated advantage to Australian earners and their families as a result of Labor policy—both employment policy and social security policy—over the years.

PARA.TAB: Senator Troeth talks in terms of youth unemployment or unemployment generally. The truth of the matter is that the growth in jobs under this government in this term has been absolutely spectacular with 90,000 jobs being created in April, more than 80,000 of those in full-time employment. Over the last 12 months employment has grown by 396,000 and by 640,000 or 8.4 per cent since the trough that existed in February 1983 when the opposition showed its incompetence so far as the Australian electorate was concerned because it would not give it any vote of confidence at all in taking over the Australian economy.

We are one year ahead of schedule in our election commitment of creating 500,000 jobs, which we made very clearly at that time. The unemployment rate is now down to just over eight per cent. It has been trending down since last year. That is the environment in which Australian families and youngsters are benefiting. That is how we are ensuring that the inequality problem is redressed in this country. There is no justification for the nonsense that has been pedalled by Mr Howard in recent days.
Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell asked me a question yesterday relating to Medicare payments for services involved in the lead-up to, and the act of, administering lethal doses to patients in the Northern Territory. I have been provided with the following answer.

PARA.TAB: Under the Medicare agreements, state and territory governments are funded by the Commonwealth government to provide public hospital services free of charge to public patients. Thus, the Commonwealth does not make specific payments for services received by public patients in public hospitals, regardless of the type or level of service provided.

Under the provisions of the Health Insurance Act, Medicare rebates are payable for professional services received out of hospital or for private patients in hospitals. The type and level of rebates are listed in the Medicare benefits schedule.

No item on the Medicare benefits schedule specifically relates to euthanasia. However, where a medical practitioner renders a professional attendance for the management of a patient, Medicare benefits will be payable under the relevant attendance item. The legal and ethical responsibility for determining medical need for any service rests ultimately with the individual medical practitioner and the patient operating within the framework of the relevant state or territory law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Herron this day, relating to Government endorsement of the sex guide published in the December 1994 issue of Cleo magazine.

SPEECH.PARA: I am amazed that, in relation to that answer, the government does not seem to understand that mainstream Australia rejects totally the promotion of activities that are unsafe not only from a medical point of view but also from a moral point of view. One of the full-page advertisements in the guide says that it is not whom you have sex with but how safe the sex is that counts. In other words, it does not matter. The message the government is giving Australian families is that it is not whom you have sex with but how safe the sex is that counts.

PARA.TAB: Another message—I am sure that nobody in mainstream Australia would agree with it—is that protection equals love. If the minister believes that, it speaks volumes of the minister. If she believes that protection equals love, it denigrates both words encompassed in that advertisement. A full-page advertisement in the government's sex guide says that protection equals love.

I became interested in this from a scientific point of view because I have had five years of training as an epidemiologist. I asked on notice the basis of the figures that were given in that guide. For example, between 40 and 60 per cent of women in Australia have anal sex. I have been a colorectal surgeon for 30 years. I treat patients with AIDS and a large percentage of the homosexual community. I am aware that diseases occur as a result of anal sex and are solely related to it.

I work with a group of five other colorectal surgeons. All five of us have discussed this matter. With over 100 years experience, we can categorically state that certain diseases that do not occur in women are related to these practices. Yet we have this bald assertion in a government sex guide that 40 to 60 per cent of women have anal sex.

I am not alone in this regard. The Royal Australian College of General Practitioners and the Medical Women's Group of the AMA agree, no matter how much the minister might try to denigrate my stance in this regard. The Medical Women's Group of the AMA has said what I have said before. It is not just my personal belief that the guide is advocating those unsafe practices. The Medical Women's Group of the AMA has said that, on its understanding from reading this guide, this guide advocates them. I will quote from the letter that it sent to the minister, which is published in the May edition of the AMA news bulletin in my state:

SPEECH.PARA: It was thought that promoting the pleasures of anal intercourse in the Safe Sex Guide is similar to promoting the pleasures of intravenous drug use—also a high risk activity—in an article to discourage that activity.
This is not a personal opinion of mine; it is an opinion of the Medical Women's Group of the AMA.

PARA.TAB: This guide promotes other activities that are equally as abhorrent. I checked with the Chief Censor and asked him whether this publication came under the guidelines for restricted circulation. He responded verbally that it is the practice for some of these sorts of publications to be sent to him for checking before they go out. In this case that was not done.

When I questioned departmental officers at estimates the other day, they said that they had thought about it but did not send it. I have circulated this publication to a number of people who are knowledgeable in this field and they tell me that there is no question in their minds: it is an R-rated publication. It is an official government publication, it is R-rated, according to the governments own guidelines, yet it did not go before the government's censor for checking before it went out.

I am delighted that the minister is continuing to defend this publication because I will continue my campaign. I already have over 101,000 signatures and I will get more than 250,000 signatures, making this the largest petition ever signed in the history of Australia, because this is repugnant to voters. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Big deal!
—I believe that this is a very serious matter indeed.
—And Senator Evans says, `Big deal!'
—Perhaps he will feel the anguish that is being experienced by parents of teenagers who have been exposed to this type of material, which is found to have been based on a false assertion.

PARA.TAB: Those of us who were at the committee heard that the basis for the assertions in that publication that so many per cent of people were engaging in anal sex was found to be not credible. That, at least, was acknowledged by the department.

The second point is that no-one who has read the Cleo guide will deny that it is an advocacy of anal sex, a high risk activity. If they deny that, let them explain the terminology used in that particular article.

As honourable senators will know, I have a reasonable sized family and I am blessed with many daughters. The discussion at the tea table covers a range of subjects, including this one. I think my children have their ears to the ground. A number of both the boys and the girls are at university, which I did not go to, and they absolutely deny the basis upon which this particular magazine article was founded.

I congratulate Senator Herron for his professionalism in bringing to bear in the committee his undoubted technical and professional knowledge to absolutely destroy the document. Now we have the minister saying, `Let us wait for the evaluation.' What is the evaluation going to do? What are the criteria for the evaluation? As I see it, the criteria of the evaluation include: did people get the message? What message did the people get? Was there awareness of the document amongst young people? What is that going to prove?

What about this document that went into the schools with the connivance of the department? One thing that came out of the hearing was that there are 40,000 copies of this document held in cold storage in a departmental warehouse. As I understand it—correct me if I am wrong—the minister at least gave the undertaking that the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) would have the final say as to whether those were distributed or not. I believe the bulk of the evidence shows that they should not be distributed. However, if they are, the people who have signed the petition are going to have something to say about it. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to second the comments made by my Tasmanian colleague, Senator Harradine. What we have today is the typical stance of a very arrogant Labor government. For those who are listening to this broadcast, the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) is not in the chamber to listen to this debate and respond to it. Indeed, when I asked a question about the University of Tasmania, she did not know the answer, and off she went. The minister had plenty of opportunity to get to grips with the issues raised by Senator Herron because he asked a lot of questions at Senate estimates. However, the minister ran out and did not join in the debate. The reason for that is that she has absolutely been done on this issue.
—She can run but she can't hide.

—She cannot hide on this issue. Senator Herron deserves to be congratulated. He has run an Australia-wide campaign and has captured in excess of 100,000 signatures to a petition condemning this guide. I have been involved in collecting signatures in Tasmania—might I add with the support of every single Liberal candidate for the next federal election. The amazing thing is the degree of support for that petition from the traditional Labor Party supporters; the sort of people that Senator Brian Harradine still represents. I can say to Senator Harradine that day by day the Liberal Party is capturing that vote because these people have seen that the Labor Party is no longer the Labor Party of which Senator Harradine was such a proud member prior to 1975 when the party sought to expel him. The Labor Party does not want any part of Senator Harradine's family values. The Labor party believes in promoting these sorts of practices.

PARA.TAB: I ask rhetorically whether the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) discusses with his young children and family over the family dinner table the joys and the ecstasies of these sorts of practices.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are sick.
—You are sick.

—Senator Forshaw and Senator Gareth Evans say that I am sick. That is the exact point we are making. This is what the government is promoting, and we say on this side that it is absolutely sick. If it is sick for the Prime Minister to talk about at his dinner table, it is also sick for the Australian government, headed by Paul Keating, the Prime Minister, to be promoting it at taxpayers' expense—a cost of $250,000.

PARA.TAB: What a silly interjection that was, Senator Forshaw. You have really made the point for me. No wonder the Prime Minister calls you a bonehead. On this occasion, I have to thank you for the interjection because it has nailed to the mast the colours of this government. You agree with me that it is sick—the minister has gone—but you do not justify why you have spent all this money to promote matters which you agree would be absolutely sick to discuss over the dinner table.

This article, the Cleo sex guide, is morally repugnant; it is medically sick; it is financially irresponsible. This is a government that is allegedly trying to bring the budget into a surplus situation. It tells us about all the difficulties that it has, yet it still has $250,000 to promote these sorts of practices—and Senator Herron, from his expertise, has indicated to this house and to the people of Australia the great and adverse medical consequences that flow from the practices that are being promoted. The Labor government has lost the plot. The minister responsible is arrogant and will not respond. All I look forward to is a change of government whereby some commonsense and a true representation of mainstream Australia will be returned to the Australian political landscape.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended to enter this debate, because I accept that a number of very genuine views have been put forward in this chamber. I respect Senator John Herron as a medical practitioner; I respect Senator Brian Harradine for his views; and I respect those who are genuinely offended by the material that has been described. However, I ask members who have expressed their views to make a suggestion, as pretenders to government in the future: what would your policies be for health education? Would you pass a law banning anal sex in Australia? How are we going to deal with this matter intelligently and educate people about the very concerns that Senator Herron has detailed during the estimates hearing?

PARA.TAB: This is a difficult issue, and it is a difficult question relating to the morals and the personal attitudes that people have. But I particularly found the remarks of Senator Abetz offensive. I think that Senator Herron and Senator Harradine are trying to come to terms with the fundamental issue of how we deal with this particular subject. As responsible law-makers, that is the question that we should be dealing with.

Senator Abetz asks about topics of discussion at the dinner table. It is Senator Harradine who is able to discuss issues with his family at the dinner table. If every Australian family could discuss a range of issues, including the difficult and complex issues about health education relating to sexual matters, maybe government would not have to indicate a range of information in the public arena. What is your policy, Senator Abetz?

TALK.START.PARA: —We would not print it.
—We now know that the coalition would simply say no.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise in the chamber.

—This is a serious matter, far too important for interjections from my side. I think it is time that we were able to debate questions of this very sensitive nature. We have a responsibility to the Australian public. We have a responsibility to young people who, whether we like it or not, are taking risks in their sexual behaviour. How do we communicate the risks? Do we do it through the guide that has raised so much concern in certain sections of the community, or do we say nothing?
—Have you read it?

—I certainly have read it. Senator Newman knows, as a mother, that if you simply pretend something is not going on and does not exist the issue will not go away. I issue a challenge to members on the other side: what is your policy? How will you tackle AIDS education?
—We would not print it, Margaret.

—You would not print it. That means the increase of AIDS through the practice of anal intercourse would increase. We are trying to grapple with a complex issue. I am sure Senator Newman is more likely to have a sensible contribution than that which we have heard from Senator Abetz.

—In answer to Senator Reynolds, this is not only a moral issue, important though that is to many people: it is also a serious public health issue, as she has acknowledged. What the government has achieved by putting this insert into Cleo is an impression that it endorses these practices provided certain precautions are taken. The mischief that this is causing is that these remain unsafe sex practices, regardless of the precautions provided for in the Cleo article. Most adults in Australia would regard anus licking as unhealthy and bad for anybody who practised it. Yet this guide does not make it clear that this should not be a practice in which anybody—young or older—should engage.

PARA.TAB: There is a suggestion that special sexual pleasure can be gained from some of these practices. I do not intend to go into them all. As adults, we know the public health risk. Certainly on our side we would have to make sure that it was well understood that these are not safe practices. You have sent an ambivalent message to the young women of Australia by this Cleo insert, and for that we strongly condemn the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support entirely what Senator Herron has said and the very articulate way that Senator Newman has come to the particular issue arising from Senator Reynolds' sincere speech. I noted the careful way that Senator Reynolds acknowledged the point that Senator Newman was making. I welcome that kind of maturity, the sensibleness—I do not wish to be patronising—and the seriousness with which she went about listening to Senator Newman's remarks just now.

PARA.TAB: The point that we want to make, amongst others, is that we have not seen that kind of seriousness, responsibility or maturity from Senator Crowley, who represents the minister for health in this chamber, or from the minister in the other place. Let me make it clear: Senator Crowley is a medical practitioner. She is a qualified doctor. She ought to know better. The minister for health has a doctorate in social psychology. She ought to know better.

When people are wrong, they ought to admit it. They can say it was their intention to recognise that we cannot sweep certain youth practices entirely under the mat, and it is right to describe some of the possibilities that will confront and endanger young people, such as intravenous drug use or some sexual practices. But to make the mistake of being seen to endorse deviant practices which are a serious health risk to the persons who would be misled by that propaganda, is to compound the original error. I believe that Senator Herron is right to pursue this matter until the minister for health, Dr Carmen Lawrence, and Senator Crowley acknowledge the point and apologise for the committing of government funds to a mistake—an encouragement of an activity which, in the view of the majority of Australians, is not supportable on moral or health grounds.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add very briefly to the debate. This is an important issue, one which will not go away. The Labor Party should be aware that members and senators on its own side are particularly concerned about this sex guide. I notice, for example, that the member for Lilley wrote to a local newspaper and said that the minister for health, Carmen Lawrence, had apologised for offence this guide may have given.

PARA.TAB: I do not think this important issue can be dismissed. It is about the standards that this government wishes to promote in the wider community. I suggest to Labor members of parliament who are so ready to interject across the chamber—and Senator Evans is one of them—that they take some time to read this guide and the endorsement of the guide by the minister for health. I say to Senator Murphy that this is a matter of public debate. This document has been put out in his party's name, financed by his government and supported by his health minister. It is a matter of controversy, one of particular controversy in his home state. His constituents might wish to know whether it has his endorsement.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it does not.

—Senator Murphy has joined the member for Lilley and has apparently said that this guide does not have his endorsement. He should stand up and say that; and maybe his party will change its approach, and maybe his Prime Minister, who has been asked on numerous occasions, will make it clear that it does not have the endorsement of government.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), to a question without notice asked by Senator Reynolds this day, relating to racism in sport.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome Senator Faulkner's statement that he intends to stamp out racism in sport in Australia. I welcome it most at this stage because the AFL has started an initiative in the last few months—it has been going for a while but has been intensified in the last three or four months—as a result of certain occurrences. I am sick and tired of the portrayal around Australia, and the minister said this in his answer today—whether intentionally or not—that the problem of racism shown towards anyone in Australia refers only to Aboriginal groups; and to some extent, as brought out in other debates, to the Jewish community.

PARA.TAB: Other communities such as my own community, the Italians, the Slavs, the southern Europeans, the Asians, the Germans too, I suppose, whatever ethnic group in Australia, have suffered racial taunts from time immemorial. The debate seems to have gone away from that completely. If there is any talk of racism in Australia, it is only about the plight of the Aborigines.

The press has to be taken to task too. I am sick and tired every time there is a crime, such as a drug bust, of the press reporting, `X, an Italian from Naples'. Why an Italian from Naples? The press does not report, `Person A, an Australian from Griffith' or `an Australian from Canberra'. It is always ethnic people and where they come from that are described in that way. The press should look at itself.

I have spoken to other ethnic groups and other ethnic members of parliament, both on our side and on the government side, not only in the federal sphere but in the state sphere. It is certainly a concern that they have. While we are looking after the interests of Aboriginals as far as racism is concerned, I believe that we have certainly lost our way with other groups. Those groups are mostly made up of migrants that came to Australia between the two world wars, although most of them came after the Second World War. They might have integrated more into the Australian community than previous migrants did, but racism is still there, so when racism is spoken about, debated and legislated for, I believe it should cover all groups, not just two small minority groups.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 190, I seek leave to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I seek to explain relates to the Senate Select Committee on Unresolved Whistleblower Cases which, on Monday 29 May, held a public hearing in this place. It was taking evidence from the Criminal Justice Commission as part of its overall inquiry. This was to be its last hearing. It commenced at around 8 o'clock and finally finished at about 1.15. Somewhere between 1 o'clock and 1.15, a question was asked of one of the representatives of the CJC that related to an affiliation on his part to either the Labor Party or Labor lawyers which I ruled out of order.

PARA.TAB: Whilst my ruling the question out of order was correct in technical terms, there was dissent from Senator Abetz, who was the person who asked the question. In accordance with the standing orders, it would be technically correct for me to have proceeded to a private meeting. That was not the case. We were right at the end of the hearing. All of the evidence had been given by the CJC; indeed I had asked on a number of occasions whether there were other questions relating to the evidence and the submission of the CJC.

The reason I ruled the question out of order was that the question had been previously asked on 16 March at a hearing in Brisbane. The question was also asked by Senator Abetz. This debate commenced on page 507 of the transcript of the hearing of Thursday, 16 March at the Brisbane hearings of the Senate Select Committee on Unresolved Whistleblower Cases. It concluded on page 518, so it was not as if it did not have some reasonable airing. After some debate, Mr Barnes, the person to whom the question was directed, answered:

SPEECH.PARA: I indicate that I am not a member of the Labor lawyers, and am not and never have been a member of any political party. That is all I wish to say, thank you.

I go to the question which Senator Abetz actually asked the CJC to take on notice. On 26 April the CJC provided a response from Mr O'Regan, the Chairperson of the CJC in Queensland. It is addressed to the secretary of the committee and states:
Dear Mr Humphery

During evidence before the Senate Select Committee on Unresolved Whistleblower Cases on 16 March 1995, Senator Abetz requested that a matter raised by him be placed before the Commission at its next meeting. During a discussion towards the end of the hearing, Senator Abetz made the following request:

. . . what you might also like to take on notice—to finish my questions on a fairly provocative basis—is on a number of occasions I have heard an allegation that the CJC is full of Labor lawyers. Are you prepared to

make or provide an analysis of those lawyers who have been employed in the CJC who have had a known association with the Labor Party or Labor lawyers or, indeed, the Liberal Party or National Party. I know that I have been provided with, if you like, anecdotal suggestions. It may be of benefit if the air could be cleared in that regard . . .
Mr O'Regan went on to say:

This request was considered by the Commission at a meeting on 21 April 1995. Commission staff are chosen on the basis of perceived ability and integrity. The Commission keeps no record of the political affiliations of its staff and does not consider that it would be appropriate to request staff to provide such information in order to comply with Senator Abetz's request.

In the circumstances, the Commission has resolved that the information requested by Senator Abetz should not be provided. Would you please convey the results of the Commission's consideration of this matter to the Committee.

That letter was circulated to all members of the committee. It is a very important part of my explanation about what happened finally at the public hearing on Monday night. On page 513 Senator Abetz said, in part:
This committee has been provided with the allegation that the investigating officer in the Cape Melville incident, Mr Barnes, is a Labor lawyer.
I repeat Mr Barnes's answer. He said:
I indicate that I am not a member of the Labor lawyers, and am not and never have been a member of any political party. That is all I wish to say, thank you.
The question being asked on Monday night sought to imply that Mr Barnes had misled the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. We are listening to a great canvassing of what occurred. If leave is being given to Senator Murphy in the guise of a personal explanation, there have been a number of matters raised already which I may well feel the need to respond to. Really, I am not sure that he is doing anything at this stage relating to himself, other than canvassing certain evidence. It has been going on now for some considerable time. I would ask you, Madam Deputy President, to ask him to come to the point.

—On the point of order, I am entirely sympathetic with the point of order that Senator Abetz raises, but I was very much listening to the beginning of Senator Murphy's remarks because it appeared that in a short compass he might actually be giving a personal explanation. However, what has occurred is a matter that really is appropriate for either a press release or a discussion within the proceedings of that committee. I think that it is, as it turns out after a few minutes, not a traditional personal explanation. I think that Senator Murphy, whilst we all love him a lot, could be directed to—
—Hey, hey!
—He is a representative of the people. He could be directed to take this matter further within the proceedings of the Senate committee concerned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Herron

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, on the same point of order: rule 190 states:

PARA.TAB: By leave of the Senate, a Senator may explain matters of a personal nature, although there is no question before the Senate, but such matters may not be debated.

INTERJECT.PARA: Obviously, there is a lot of debatable material in Senator Murphy's matter. By our rules we are not allowed to debate that, so there will not be the opportunity for Senator Abetz to dispute what Senator Murphy is saying.Senator Murphy should be ruled out of order beyond the matter of personal explanation which he introduced at the beginning. To go on in the way he does is abusing the personal explanation rights of a senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, the opposition gave leave because we believe that when senators have been misrepresented, they should have the right to make an explanation. I have been listening very carefully to Senator Murphy. He has proceeded to canvass evidence given in a Senate committee hearing. I do not see how that relates to Senator Murphy having been misrepresented or otherwise.

PARA.TAB: These are matters before a committee and if Senator Murphy has a matter where he has been misrepresented or there is a matter of a personal nature, we are happy to hear it and hear the explanation. But I do not believe that it is appropriate for Senator Murphy to continue to canvass proceedings in a Senate hearing as none of the material he has brought to light bears any relationship to how he could have been misrepresented.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, on the point of order: I might have served a better purpose had I put in context the part that is actually very relevant in seeking to cover some of the areas that I sought to cover during the course of giving this personal explanation. It relates to a media release put out by Senator Abetz in which he makes certain assertions. I do not want to waste time and read it all, but I am happy to do that, because that is exactly why there was a need for me to set out the parameters under which the events occurred so that, in giving the personal explanation, I would at least allow senators the opportunity to understand exactly what I was talking about. It may seem as though I am taking some time, but I have to do that—
—You have to do it very briefly.

—Yes, Senator Teague, I understand that I have to be brief and I am trying to be as brief as I can. This is clearly a public press release; it is not one that was made inside the Senate. It clearly misrepresents me and, indeed, the person about whom the press release is written.

—Senator Murphy, we would all agree that you were making a personal explanation when you began. You seemed to be getting a little far from that and I was waiting for you to come back to the personal explanation. You should do that promptly with perhaps less detail in between.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy President. I will go to the end of what I am actually seeking to make a personal explanation about: the basis on which the committee proceedings ended on Monday night. I adjourned the hearing and left the committee room, which then caused the quorum of four members to lapse. That was at 1.15 in the morning. Whilst it was technically incorrect for me to have done that, in those circumstances I do not detract from what I did. With regard to Senator Abetz's press release, it is not only misleading but it is also incorrect. I thank the Senate for its indulgence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate the totality of my media release that Senator Murphy referred to and also an article from page 18 of today's Courier-Mail—the only media outlet that printed it—which also details Senator Murphy's personal allegations against me. He alleged a conspiracy theory by me and a lot of other matters that reflect on me personally.

PARA.TAB: Clearly, this has been a matter which is in the political arena. There are two sides of the story. I believe Senator Murphy has abused the standing orders by trying to make a personal explanation. I will not do that, other than to set the record straight by incorporating the media release of which I am very proud and also the article in the Courier-Mail which puts Senator Murphy's point of view. I know what the people of Queensland are going to say about this issue and they can judge it. But in order to set the record straight, I seek leave to incorporate that media release and the article from the Courier-Mail.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: SENATOR ERIC ABETZ
Liberal Senator for Tasmania
Media Release
SENATE COMMITTEE ENDS HEARING IN SHAMBLES
The disgraceful walkout at Whistleblowers committee hearings by the Labor chairman last night was slammed as irresponsible, by former chairman, Liberal Senator for Tasmania Eric Abetz.

The final scheduled hearing of the Senate Select Committee on Unresolved Whistleblower cases ended in disarray early this morning, when the chairman of the committee, Senator Shayne Murphy, walked out on the public hearing.
Senator Abetz said the move came after probing questions had been asked of a Criminal Justice Commission (CJC) witness who appeared to have obfuscated about his Labor Party affiliations.
"I wanted to establish whether or not the witness was a member of the Australian Labor Party and another affiliated group known as the Association of Labor Lawyers Queensland Inc."
Senator Abetz said evidence before the committee had shown that the Queensland Labor Lawyers had one of two aims, that is:

"Given that one of the policies of the Labor Party is to win Government at all costs, my line of questioning, to the CJC officer, was perfectly reasonable.

THE COURIER MAIL—31 May 1995
SENATE INQUIRY ENDS IN CONFLICT
By SID MAHER
In Canberra

A SENATE inquiry focusing on unresolved whistleblower cases in Queensland ended early yesterday morning in a row over whether a senior Criminal Justice Commission officer had connections with the ALP.

Unresolved Whistleblowers Committee chairman, Tasmanian Labor Senator Shayne Murphy, clashed with Tasmanian Liberal Senator Eric Abetz over CJC complaints section chief officer Michael Barnes's former membership of the Labor Lawyers Association.
After a protracted argument about whether Mr Barnes had misled the committee, Senator Murphy called the hearings to a close at about 1.15 a.m. to cries of "farce" from Senator Abetz.
Senator Abetz demanded to be allowed to ask further questions of Mr Barnes.

At the centre of the row was an answer Mr Barnes had given to the committee when it sat in Brisbane in March: "I indicate that I am not a member of the Labor Lawyers and am not and never have been a member of any political party."
Senator Abetz had accused Mr Barnes of giving an answer designed to mislead the committee in the light of the fact that he had formerly been a member of Labor Lawyers.

But Mr Barnes strongly denied this, saying the answer he had given, in the context of the question asked (which was about Labor Lawyers in the CJC), could not be read any other way than to acknowledge he had once been a member of Labor Lawyers but not a member of the ALP.
Senator Murphy agreed that Mr Barnes had not misled the committee and ruled out of order attempts by Senator Abetz to further pursue the matter.
Senator Abetz said yesterday Senator Murphy had conducted a "disgraceful walkout".

"I wanted to establish whether or not the witness was a member of the Australian Labor Party and another affiliated group known as the Association of Labor Lawyers Queensland Inc," Senator Abetz said.
"What sort of message is the chairman sending to people with valid concerns when he can't handle the heat, protects his Labor mates, and walks out on the democratic process."

Senator Murphy said he had not walked out of the committee hearings but had closed the proceedings after allowing Senator Abetz a significant amount of latitude on a subject which was outside the committee's terms of reference.
He said Senator Abetz had been trying to develop a "conspiracy theory" and he had already established that Mr Barnes had once been a member of Labor Lawyers but had never been a member of the ALP.

PARA.TAB: The unfair and unjustified consequences of wholesale sales tax imposed on builders' hardware and certain building materials and its impact on housing affordability and the subsequent repercussions for employment in the construction industry.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling Senator Tambling, I point out that agreement has been reached as to times for speakers in today's debate. The clocks will be set accordingly.

—This issue relates very specifically to the government's budget proposal to impose a wholesale sales tax of 12 per cent on certain builders' hardware and building materials. PARA.TAB: Many people will be affected by the Keating government's 1995-96 budget, and this aspect is nothing more than a blatant attack on the great Australian dream. It is an attack on home ownership; it is an attack on those Australians who rent their homes; it is an attack on those who choose to renovate and maintain their existing homes and, as such, it will have a particular effect on self-funded retirees and elderly people throughout Australia who are very vulnerable at a particular financial period in their lives. These new taxes and additional taxes will have a major effect on them.

This proposed new building tax will hit more than three million Australian households per year. The 1995-96 Keating budget will result in considerable stress for home owners and tenants and will have major repercussions for the construction industry throughout Australia.

If we look at Budget Paper No. 1, we see that the explanatory memorandum details that the particular wholesale sales tax is on builders' hardware and certain building materials used mainly in the completion of buildings, which will become taxable at the concessional WST rate of 12 per cent from 1 July 1995. WST will apply to presently exempt goods such as screws, nails, paint, putty, adhesives, wallpaper, ceramic and glass floor and wall tiles, taps, nozzles, handles and joinery such as prefabricated kitchen cupboards and office partitioning. That just about picks up everything that most Australian households have.

It is also interesting to look at page 4.20 of the revenue estimates for this year. I note in particular that indirect tax—sales tax revenue—will rise this year to a collection of $14,160 million. That is an increase of $2,580 million, an increase of 22.3 per cent in the sales tax collections for this year. That, of course, includes this additional new budget revenue item.

It seems to me that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has an attitude problem with housing. He told the Collingwood Football Club on 11 May that he considered Australia's spending on housing needed change. Speaking later in Canberra, he said, `Banks simply resorting to housing lending is, I think, a bad thing.' At the last election Mr Keating promised to keep home purchase within the reach of those who wanted to buy their home and to keep mortgage repayments at affordable levels. This could not be further from the truth.

Honourable senators might remember that at the last election Mr Keating did a deal with the Australian people. He promised to deliver tax cuts if they delivered him office. He was returned to office. What did Australians get in return? More taxes—$3 billion a year of more taxes. There was higher taxation of unused long service leave and annual leave lump sum payments; increased tax on credit unions; increases in fringe benefits tax; an increase in the general rate of wholesale sales tax; extra sales tax on wine and cider; an increase in petrol excise; an increase in tobacco excise; and a departure tax increase. That was previous budgets.

What about this year's budget? The promised tax cuts did not eventuate, but we certainly got increases in fuel taxes; increases in existing wholesale sales tax from 20 per cent to 22 per cent; increases in vehicle sales tax; an increase in company tax, FBT and superannuation; a higher Medicare levy; and the introduction of this particular issue that we are addressing, the introduction of a 12 per cent wholesale sales tax on building hardware, with the possibility of it increasing to 22 per cent. So all of that pre-election promise area was forgone. The Prime Minister's credibility is down the chute. It is nothing more than electoral fraud and straight electoral dishonesty.

The consequence of it, particularly in this area, is that housing affordability continues to decline under a Keating government. The evidence of that, of course, has been the interest rate uncertainty and strategy of this government after the last year or so. That mistrust of Keating has kept the housing market in decline. There have recently been large falls in housing finance commitments which will continue to flow through building approvals over the next few months. Housing finance commitments for March were a whopping 31.4 per cent down on March 1994. Mr Keating has betrayed the average Aussie more than any other section of the Australian community, and he continues to decimate middle-class Australia. The Keating budget, by taxing the range of building materials, has penalised home buyers for the government's policy failure.

Where is the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) in all of this? He is the Minister for Housing and Regional Development. Mr Howe certainly is implicated in this latest attack on housing. He has been promising us a major housing statement since February of this year. It slipped from February, to March, to April, to May and now it is obviously slipping into the election rhetoric. It has slipped off the agenda. It is not going to appear before the parliament.

We need to ask how much clout does Mr Howe really have. He has been totally ineffective and should resign. There is no social justice coming from Mr Howe and the left wing at all. To see this, we only have to look at the estimates questions I raised in the last round. We asked a whole series of questions about urban development; about the some 16 policy objectives that were under way; and about the seven consultancies that had all reported nine months late and what the results were. We asked about the three-year $2 million review by Jenny Macklin, who was on Mr Howe's staff. She has now gone off as the Labor candidate for Jagajaga. The review has folded after 16 months. The money is all spent. The department has to pick up the tab and finish off the work, which has been a total waste of taxpayers' money.

We can identify the problems as being those in home ownership, renovation on homes and crisis accommodation. There will be, as a result of this, price rises for new homes. Landlords will be forced to raise rents in the private sector, and that will have a consequential effect on Australian homes. With affordability conditions declining, there will be increased pressure placed on the rental market.

Pensioners, who traditionally rent or, in many instances, renovate and maintain their home, will be hurt. This makes a mockery of other government initiatives in all of the areas that affect rental assistance and rental programs. With every nail driven and every brush of paint, Mr Keating is now there for the grab and is certainly going to hurt and affect all of these people.

The building industry has been deliberately, almost vindictively, hamstrung by the Keating government. This proposed 12 per cent sales tax on building hardware is another savage blow to an industry already doing it tough. The repercussions of this impost will be felt throughout the housing sector. Builders will be forced to rationalise their businesses, and this will result in job losses. There is confusion within the industry surrounding the tax treatment of different forms of prefabricated components and building materials, whether constructed on site or in the factory. Industry associations have suggested that the government ought to go back to the drawing board on this particular matter.

As I said in my opening remarks, the group that worries me the most is the self-funded retirees. If you look at the figures of people over 55 who purchase or change their homes, you will see that they take about 10 per cent of the average changes of home buying components in Australia. They are all now going to be severely slugged through this tax. (Time expired)

The opposition should nominate where it is going to cut expenditure. It will be very interesting to see how the opposition will come up with a budget surplus for this year in its alternative package, if it dares to present one, without any tax increases whatsoever. We have the absurd position of the shadow treasurer, Mr Costello, saying, `Okay. We will vote against the tax increases. Some of them might get through. If we are subsequently elected to government we will keep them'. That is a ridiculous position. The general public is starting to wonder about the contortions that the opposition is getting itself into over tax increases.

The opposition says, `We are macho. We do not agree with tax increases but, if they go through, we will keep the money anyway'. The opposition is trying to have it both ways. Any responsible government putting up a responsible budget must have some degree of flexibility in its fiscal approach. If that means that from time to time there are tax decreases in certain areas or tax increases in certain areas, then that inevitably occurs. I am a person who believes it is very difficult to give an absolute commitment that there are not going to be any tax increases anywhere. That is not a practical option.

The government's approach on this measure—$215 million from the increase in the wholesale sales tax—aside from addressing some inequities in the wholesale sales tax area, is a very important and very central component of the budget. If the opposition turns a surplus into a deficit by opposing these measures it is on its head if interest rates start to go up. It is on the opposition's head if the dollar starts to slide. As part of the government I know that we will be happy to confront those opposite politically on the consequences of their irresponsibility. We have an opposition with no alternative budget strategy and no alternative package of policies. It boasts that it will keep them hidden until the next election—which it will lose.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to participate in this debate about the effect of the savage tax increases that this government has placed on the average Australian home owner and renovator. We seem to have gone back into history. I recall Senator Sherry talking about the so-called unbiased Housing Industry Association.
—They support the GST.

—It is no secret that the Housing Industry Association became involved in the campaign to protect the livelihood of its members. It was a campaign that was not motivated by greed but by survival. The Housing Industry Association initiated a public awareness campaign against the Keating Labor government because it knew how hard the government had hit the housing industry. It is also history that Mr Keating deceived the Australian people to win the last election by the scaremonger campaign about the GST.
—Are you still crying about the scaremonger campaign?

—We heard it here again today from Senator Murphy and Senator Sherry. The government did not tell the people about the offsets that were going to be granted, together with the reductions in fuel tax and payroll tax. The Housing Industry Association knew that. Since the election Mr Keating has waged war against the housing industry. He has driven the industry further down. We only have to look at the trends to see what has happened to the building industry since the Keating Labor government was returned to office.

PARA.TAB: This latest measure in the budget adds to that trend. We have a 12 per cent goods and services tax on previously exempt building products. It could not have come at a worse time for the industry. My colleagues have pointed out what has happened to the building industry. We have seen the effects that the high interest rates over the last few years have had on the building industry. We have industrial disputes and a general decline in the economy brought about by the recession that we had to have.

I was talking to one of my colleagues in small business the other day. He said, `I tell you what, I would rather have the recession than the recovery'. That is borne out by the facts. Overall, housing activity in this country has dropped by about 30 per cent in the last year. The March 1995 figures issued by the Australian Bureau of Statistics show that private housing fell 7.8 per cent in February to its lowest level since January 1992. An article in the West Australian this week mentioned that home building approvals are now at their lowest level since June 1991. We had another 7.9 per cent decrease in building activity last month.

Senator Sherry cannot have it both ways. We have a decline in the building industry. We all know that the building industry, like small business, is the engine room of the economy. This massive downturn in the building industry is going to cost jobs. It is an industry which relies upon a sound economy and the private sector confidence that it produces.

TALK.START.PARA: —Robin Gray could do better than this. I don't want to ring him up.

—At least he would not be misleading people. Senator Sherry was misleading in his speech. He told us that he was carrying out kitchen improvements at his home, and he tried to ram it down our throats that there would not be increased costs on labour. I can tell Senator Sherry that there is going to be a 12 per cent tax increase on custom cabinets. He should go around his electorate in Tasmania and talk to some of the people in joinery shops and see what effect the 12 per cent increase is going to have on them.

PARA.TAB: A lot of businesses in Tasmania are using our unique timbers to produce export furniture. There is going to be a 12 per cent tax on that as well. As a result of that, these people are going to have to put off staff. A lot of these firms have just hired apprentices. Kingston Joinery was one of those firms. The firm employs 30 people, but it is very seriously looking at putting off at least four, two of whom are apprentices. The reason for that action is the 12 per cent hike which the company did not expect. It came out of the blue in the last budget. It is going to increase the firm's taxation and reduce its profits. I looked at some of the company's figures and it will be going into debt after having a reasonable surplus. We know that this is going to have a great impact on unemployment. There will be a cut-back in apprenticeships.

One area that has not been touched upon is the effect that this will have on the hardware market. Throughout Australia there are literally thousands of hardware stores providing nails, paints, puttys, adhesives, wallpapers and tiles that the home handyman or handywoman needs. The increased prices that the hardware shops will have to pass on to customers will affect sales, and thereby affect their profit margin. As a result we will see jobs going out the door.

It is going to hit young families; the people who have the great Australian dream of owning or improving their own home. The Housing Industry Association and the Master Builders Association have been able to establish that people will be paying $720 more in tax on a $6,000 kitchen. At the last election the coalition was willing to tell the people the truth. On 1 July 1995 we will see another one per cent increase in wholesale sales tax across the board. The people might have forgotten about that. That is another result of Mr Dawkins' budget.(Time expired)
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Watson)—Order! I call Senator Burns.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, it is with a feeling of security that I rise to my feet knowing that you are presiding over this chamber and knowing your innate fairness in dealing with people. I congratulate you on being elevated to the position of Acting Deputy President.

PARA.TAB: It is very interesting to hear those opposite talk about increased costs as a result of taxation increases on some items that go into the building of homes and houses—and, of course, those two things are different. However, they have not raised any question about other costs, and there are one or two other costs that are very significant.

Most Australians view owning a home as something very important. It has been the goal of most Australians to purchase and live in their own home at some stage during their working lives. Certainly, many home loan ads that have been shown on television target young working couples, with or without young families, and one could say that it is part of the Australian way of life—and it has been for some time. Even the opposition, when it was in government, sponsored the ideal of home ownership.

Home ownership levels in Australia rose rapidly in the late 1940s and 1950s, and since the early 1960s home ownership levels have remained steady at around the 68 per cent mark. This level of ownership is equal to, or better than, most countries in the developed world. It has been and remains this government's objective to keep home ownership affordable for most Australians. Affordability is affected by inflation and home loan interest rate levels, not by the odd bit of wholesales sales tax on nails and other items.

Senator Tambling clearly must be struggling with the government's success at keeping interest rates and inflation rates down, because all he can grasp at is talking down the housing industry and some minor wholesale tax changes which will affect by around $500 the cost of a house and land purchase worth, say, $100,000. That is certainly much less than the housing industry has indicated, and I am certainly suspicious of its calculations. I am sure that most Australians are happy to know that this budget is providing the framework that ensures home ownership remains affordable, by ensuring that cost of living increases are kept to a minimum and that interest rates are kept as low as possible.

Many things go into the cost of a house, land being a very substantial value item. I am surprised to see that the HIA estimates that revenue from this wholesale sales tax on some building products will be about $500 million, instead of the government's budget estimate of $215 million. Perhaps the building industry is in better shape than even the government has estimated. I would certainly like to hear how the HIA arrived at this figure.

I stress that these wholesales sales tax changes are restricted to a small number of building items. Most of the building material used in building construction remains exempt from this tax, including: timber, bricks, roofing tiles, stone, sand, gravel, concrete, cement, bitumen, electrical fittings, doors and windows. If Senator Tambling is so upset at the alleged impact this tax will have on the housing industry, why were he and his colleagues eager to embrace not so long ago a GST that would have substantially increased the cost of housing in this country? I know that Senator Tambling is hoping that everyone will forget about the GST, but we won't and they won't. Senator Calvert made the point that there were going to be some tax cuts on certain items, like fuel—as though the tax on these items we now discuss, which are only part of the large budget, were the only increases that would have taken place.

Home ownership is part of a broader strategy to ensure that all Australians can achieve a better standard of living. It is no good providing opportunities for Australians to own their own homes and then not provide an adequate environment for that home and the family that lives in it. The better cities program aims to improve the economic, social and environmental development of Australia's urban regions. For example, areas like the Brisbane-Gold Coast growth corridor must be provided with proper planning and infrastructure support to ensure that home owners living, or planning to live, in that area are not neglected.

Other programs—like the urban and public transport pilot project, the one billion trees program and the national house energy rating scheme—all combine to build a better environment for our cities and towns. All these programs have to be financed out of taxation, and people are always ready to say, `We would like some of that money so we can be involved in these schemes.' But you have got to raise the money before you can spend it. Let us get away from the cheap political point scoring, and let us stop talking the housing industry and economy down. Let us start talking about the benefits that this budget and a healthy economy can give to all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the matter of public importance has now expired.

—by leave—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 28 of 1994-95—Efficiency Audit—Insurance and Superannuation Commission—Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act—Administrative Arrangements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian National Audit Office has identified some areas in which the Insurance Superannuation Commission needs to do some further work. I have some very specific concerns relating to this. One area in which I believe the ISC needs to do more work is derivatives. Well before the Barings collapse, I gave notice of public warnings about the dangers of derivatives. In fact, as chair of the superannuation committee of the Senate, I wrote to the ISC and the ISC responded with a discussion paper. But I believe that that is not enough.

PARA.TAB: For example, the gearing of superannuation investments must stop, and must stop immediately. The ISC must respond decisively in the light of the potential risks that imprudent derivative investment can pose to superannuation investments. In doing so, I urge the ISC to canvass legislative proposals to address this issue. (Quorum formed) In fact, the potential for excessive derivatives exposures to challenge long-term confidence and superannuation has been a longstanding concern of mine. I have given a number of public addresses on this issue. This issue must not simply be lumped into the too-hard basket. The experience of the 1980s must surely remind us that waiting for the horse to bolt, and counting our losses once the stable is empty, does not put bread and butter on the tables of ordinary retired Australians.

Enormous resources have been poured into developing the SIS regime, which is now recognised as a world leader in its field. In fact, the tapestry of law of which we are the weavers is not simply to authorise the prosecution of breaches. More importantly, it is to encourage compliance and avoidance of breaches. We cannot allow superannuation investments to be speculative. I place on the record my desire to see within a year a thorough examination of the appropriate role of derivative investment and the development of subsequent legislation addressing, in particular, issues such as the prohibition of gearing of superannuation portfolios and exposure limits for derivative investments.

This morning I had the opportunity of meeting with Mr Stephen Smith MP, of the House of Representatives Banking, Finance and Public Administration Committee and the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities. The Banking, Finance and Public Administration Committee is to take evidence tomorrow from the Insurance and Superannuation Commission on the use of derivatives. I have outlined my concerns to Mr Smith and pointed out to him the relevant gaps which must be filled.

In the area of education to date, the role of the ISC in educating those involved in superannuation according to the industry has been less than satisfactory. I acknowledge that. The government has millions of dollars to provide education on superannuation, and this money must be spent appropriately. My concern is the use to which the ISC has put its money. I acknowledge that it has produced a trustee guide book, but I question the extent of consultation undertaken in the preparation of this document. For example, 95 per cent of funds are mum's and dad's funds to which only five per cent of the SIS legislation applies. The guide book has attempted to cover two very diverse groups of trustees, and neither group has been served well. The ISC must put more work into its communications. This is an area in which the Australian Taxation Office superannuation group has been highly commended by industry.

I make these few observations from the point of view that I hear many on and off the record comments on superannuation. It is imperative that the regulator in the vital and emerging field of retirement incomes is constantly reviewing and improving its communications.

I believe there are issues that the regulator must look at. For example, to what extent are trustees responsible for monitoring the use of derivatives by their investment managers? How can trustees, particularly member trustees, have any hope of assessing the risks of these highly technical and intricate investments? Further, how does section 52(2)(f) impose an obligation on trustees in relation to the use of derivatives? Is trustee responsibility a realistic route for derivative regulation? These and other vital issues must be addressed by the ISC. Given the nature of superannuation—that is, lifetime savings of individuals for their retirement—do we believe that a direct approach to the regulation of derivatives would be adequate, or should there be a more definite prudential regulation?

There are other issues. For example, in the event of a major derivative loss under the current law, which entities would be required to account for the events resulting in the loss—the trustees, the investment manager or the auditors?
