Further, what happens if a large super fund crashes in the way that Barings did? I believe we do have a prudential regime aimed against that, but a derivative is a new product for which there is no legislative prescription. What would be the consequences of a fallout? How will this be handled?

I believe we should distinguish between over the counter derivatives and exchange traded derivatives for regulative purposes. Is it possible to distinguish between these two groups for the purpose of the regulations, because they have diverse consequences in terms of their application in the event of loss. It is possible, with certain types of derivatives, to lose more than the actual investment. This is one of the far reaching consequences of my concern about using derivatives, certainly in circumstances where they are used for other than taking or hedging a position. The real difficulty lies in distinguishing between a hedging and a speculative function. I ask the government and the ISC to further address this important issue in the light of ensuring an absolutely tight prudential regime for the protection of our future retirement incomes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak to the Auditor-General Report No. 2 1994-95, because this report deals with the Superannuation Industry Supervision Act 1993 and it makes many recommendations. However, there is a recommendation that it did not make which was made elsewhere and which has been implemented. I refer to temporary modification declaration No. 14. As I understand it, it is in conflict with the views of the committee on which Senator Watson sits. This modification raises some concerns with me.

PARA.TAB: There are two modifications. The first one is to waive the disqualified persons status of persons with minor dishonesty convictions, which will enable such persons to be trustees, investment managers and custodians of superannuation entities and responsible officers of corporate trustees, investment managers and custodians of superannuation entities. A minor dishonesty conviction is not defined, is not a legal definition and is entirely at the discretion of the insurance commissioner. It seems to me that that is an incredible way to legislate. I do not know how they could do it better, and I do not know what the agenda is behind allowing people with minor dishonesty convictions. Maybe it is only those pinching under $100,000 or, judging by the way major corporate cheats seem to be treated these days, perhaps you have to be a major corporate cheat to be regarded as having a minor dishonesty conviction. I view this with some concern, particularly in light of the very well informed opposition to this change.

The other change under modification declaration No. 14 is to permit disqualified persons under part 15 of the act as a result of having been convicted of an offence involving dishonesty—not a small offence but any offence involving dishonesty—to continue to act as trustees, investment managers and custodians and as responsible officers of corporate trustees, investment managers and custodians for up to six months without being liable to penalty. Reasons are given, but quite frankly I do not find them to be persuasive. I think the government should explain to us in better terms why this sort of thing has been snuck through the Commonwealth Gazette. That is where this change of some significance appeared.

In the Australian of 25 May, this matter was raised and concern was expressed. Obviously there are things such as minor convictions. There is bus fare evasion. I acknowledge that it would be ludicrous if a person who was caught for scaling on a bus or train by accident as a result of failing to buy a ticket was no longer allowed to be a trustee or an investment manager. But nothing says what this `minor dishonesty' conviction really is. Legal advice is that the term `minor dishonesty' has no legal meaning. In fact, the term is strictly interpretive and is so wide that it could mean anything to anybody. In the absence of any guidelines to the insurance commission, I think it is grossly improper for this temporary modification to be changed in this way. This does not just affect peanuts. The insurance superannuation pool at the moment is something like $200 billion, which is expected to increase to $600 billion within the next few years.

It is vitally important that people in control of this kind of money be totally and absolutely honest. I have great concern that the ISC has gone down this track. This move is not well thought out and I hope some corrections will be made to make it much clearer exactly what the ISC is about. On the recommendations made by the audit office, there is real concern in this report by the audit office about some matters which I want to raise very briefly. Among the key findings of the audit office is that there is an absence of a compatibility check between the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner and the Australian Taxation Office superannuation records.

According to the Auditor, checks would have revealed a number of discrepancies in both databases and highlighted delays in the processing of Insurance and Superannuation Commission returns. He also points out what I think is a serious problem. Superannuation funds were claiming the concessional tax rate without first having been granted compliance status by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission. He goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: While it is permissible to anticipate that compliance will be given, the ANAO considers more follow-up action needs to be taken to ensure that the benefit of the tax concession is restricted to eligible funds complying with the legislation.

Something like 79,000 funds lodged returns. The audit office found out that something like 7,817 funds which lodged returns with the ISC did not lodge income tax returns with the ATO. This, the Auditor-General says, `could have serious consequences for tax revenue'—at worst who knows what—`at least deferring receipt of tens of millions of dollars.' The Auditor says that the tax office is following up to determine whether there had been a breach of lodgement requirements and to collect whatever revenue was payable.

PARA.TAB: If the audit office had not compared the databases, further revenue losses would have been realised in addition to the loss of interest on the deferred payments. It strikes me as absolutely extraordinary that there has not been proper comparing of the databases of the tax office, which provides the tax concession, and that of the insurance commission, which provides the status for the tax concession. I am glad the Auditor-General has established this. He goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: there is a need for the ISC and ATO to finalise arrangements for the unique identification of funds (currently by tax file number) to avoid totally undesirable restrictions on the meaningful exchange of data between them.

The importance of this is that, with the introduction of Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992, superannuation became mandatory for most Australian workers and moneys held in superannuation funds are expected to treble to about $600 billion by the year 2,000.

PARA.TAB: The Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner has the responsibility for ensuring that the proper prudential safeguards are applied to the funds into which the compulsory superannuation contributions are paid, as well as being responsible for monitoring the compliance with legislation by regulated superannuation entities. It seems extraordinary that with this enormous need for effective supervision, the prudential requirements, in terms of the integrity of the people handling these funds, are to be diminished by the latest ISC temporary modification declaration.

The audit office also found that, in some areas, Insurance and Superannuation Commission activity had been insufficient to meet its responsibilities fully under the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987 and that, in the audit office's view, the then current planning for its increased scope under the SIS arrangements would have limited the effectiveness of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission in meeting the government's stated policy objectives.

The audit office considers that good cooperation and communications between the ISC and the ATO are critical and considers this to be an area where more work should have been done, and needs to be done, to protect Commonwealth revenue. A comprehensive compatibility check of ISC and ATO superannuation records had never been conducted. The audit office has recommended that an annual compatibility check of these records be conducted.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, as you indicated in your speech to the chamber, the Attorney-General's report is very important.

PARA.TAB: The report is a must for every senator to examine thoroughly, particularly given the fact that the government is pursuing the policy of compulsory superannuation.

The question must therefore be pre-eminent in our minds: is there a prudential arrangement to ensure that those superannuation funds into which these compulsory contributions are to be paid are doing the right thing by the contributors? I welcome this report. Some parts bear further discussion. Mr Acting Deputy President, you pointed to some of those in your speech and I will not go over them. Nor will I go over the points raised by Senator Michael Baume. I believe them to have been quite valid. I appreciated the insert which the Australian National Audit Office thoughtfully placed in the report. It gave the key findings, the background to the report, the planning for SIS, the ISC audit program and the ISC-ATO interface. Senator Baume has also mentioned that.

It is quite extraordinary, is it not, that some 7,817 funds have lodged ISC returns but not tax returns, leading—in the words of the Auditor-General—to potential loss of significant revenue. But that is not the only potential loss. I will not go into the merits or otherwise of the proposals that the government is seeking to have implemented through the award system and through the system of enterprise bargaining.

However, a question does arise as to the constitutional validity of some of the suggestions being made. Questions arise as to whether it is appropriate to appropriate workers' wage increases into a superannuation fund, against their will. These funds are recognised as the workers' only for the purposes of taxation. I will go into that later. I wish to raise, for consideration by the chamber and the Auditor-General, a rather prudential matter that should be borne in mind. There are some doubts about how well the superannuation funds will fare, in the commercial sense.

EPAC has just released an interim report on private sector involvement in infrastructure. Senator Gibson would be well aware of that, as would other honourable senators. The Kelty report on regional development proposed that airports be sold to institutional investors such as superannuation funds. The EPAC report advocates full cost recovery through user charges for all public infrastructure.

Through privatisation, the government is shifting off budget most of its commitments to supply public works for essential services. Increasingly, roads, airports, communications, water, electricity, et cetera will be supplied by private investors such as superannuation funds. Thus the workers, through their compulsory employee and employer contributions to superannuation, are being forced to pay for essential services which used to be provided on a subsidised or break-even basis by governments. In effect, the superannuation levies actually represent an additional tax designed to make up for the decline in public utility services provided by government.

Because the superannuation levies are not shown as taxes in the national accounting statistics, the official figures will show that the ratio of tax to national income is actually falling. That is a nice twist of the figuring, is it not? By shifting public works off budget more of the budget is freed up for actual vote buying schemes.

Let me come back to investments. Henry Aram, an investment adviser, has pointed out that this shuffle of public assets into private hands at inflated prices may mean that long-term investment returns are not there in 30 years. That should be considered. As billions of dollars—the Auditor-General puts a figure of about $600 billion on it by the year 2000, which is a lot of money—accumulate in a limited number of investment funds, the dangers of investment manager group-think increase. With fewer and fewer dominant players in the bond and equity markets, there is less stability in the financial system as larger masses of money can move in and out of stocks on the say-so of fewer people. The potential for instability, market rigging and insider trading must weaken the efficiency of Australia's capital markets.

I will not proceed any further with that because I think I am straying a little from the topic at hand, which is the Auditor-General's report. I felt that I should make those points because these are relevant considerations when regard is had for the need for prudential schemes to ensure the proper compliance of superannuation funds with the law.

The efficiency of superannuation funds to deliver to their members the benefits which the government considers will be delivered must be considered. I have yet to hear from the government how those benefits will be delivered. I will be listening very intently for any indication from the government as to how this outcome will arise and will be required to arise.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Watson)—Order! It being 10 past five, the time for consideration of reports has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I rise to make a short comment on Auditor-General's report No. 28—Efficiency Audit—Insurance and Superannuation Commission. I draw the Senate's attention to pages 24 and 25 of the report, where the audit office points out the compatibility check between the ISC and the Taxation Office shows previously unidentified differences of about 12,000 between the two databases. On the next page it points out that the 12,000 difference represents a little over five per cent of total funds recorded. It is disgraceful. Of the 8,571 returns in the ISC's suspended complying category, 3,040 relate to the 1991-92 financial year. The remaining 5,529 represent 1992-93 returns. This is absolutely disgraceful.
—This is four years old.

—It is four years old. It is disgraceful that these 8,500 funds have not been reconciled. The figures indicate to the audit office unacceptably long delays in the ISC's processing of those annual returns and that the Taxation Office has anticipated that all of those funds are eligible to be granted compliance status. That may not be so, in which case the Commonwealth is missing out on interest from those funds. The audit office recommends that the ISC expedite the processing of those returns. This is really disgraceful administration. I thank the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: I present the 8th report of 1995 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I also lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 7 1995, dated 31 May 1995.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall continue the remarks I was making earlier today in support of the censure motion of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Bob Collins, for misleading the Senate and the people of Australia over the use of land fund money available through ATSIC.

PARA.TAB: When Senator Kernot was giving her opinion on paragraphs (a), (b) and (c), she described paragraph (c) as a political agreement. Paragraph (c) is a description of the ATSIC board briefing paper revealing that an agreement had been struck between the Prime Minister, ATSIC and a group of indigenous land fund bill negotiators on singling out the Northern Territory for special treatment over the next two years. This seems a very polite way of saying that there is a real discrepancy with paragraph (b) where on 9 November 1994, Senator Gareth Evans stated, `The government has agreed with the Northern Territory government that the allocation of new moneys to the land fund should not lead to an increase in the amount of land claimed under the Land Rights Act.'

This morning I detailed some of the statements that had been made in the Melbourne hearing of the Senate select committee on the land fund in January this year and how almost every single speaker from those groups felt that they had an equal right to land that would be distributed under the land fund. In contrast to this, I remind all senators of Senator Collins's statements on 16 November 1994. This has already been quoted extensively by my fellow coalition colleagues. He said that it is a nonsense scenario that exclusively or largely over the next three years $21 million of ATSIC funds would be used to purchase land in the Northern Territory to the exclusion of everywhere else in Australia. I would suggest to the Senate and indeed to other people who are listening that that has indeed happened. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I am prepared to bet Senator Chamarette a huge sum of money. . . that the prospect of ATSIC's land acquisition funds exclusively being devoted to land purchases in the Northern Territory is a highly unlikely scenario indeed.
There are the same broad range of interests—
that is Aboriginal interests—
across Australia and the same priorities will continue to apply to that $21 million fund for the transitional period that it continues to operate.

If this is not misleading the Senate, what is? Again, I call attention to the terms of reference of this particular motion and I support my coalition colleagues in every way in calling the Prime Minister, Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Collins to account for misleading the Senate and the people of Australia. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am most grateful to Senator Panizza for calling a quorum so that people can hear what I have to say about this very important matter. I regard a censure motion as one of, if not the, most gravest actions that can be taken by the Senate in respect of a member of this place.

PARA.TAB: I have considered what has been said on both sides of this debate. I have been here all the time, I think, and have been able to calculate in my own mind, on balance, how I will vote on this matter. I am very well aware of the fact that on this occasion, in a numbers sense, this is an important matter, but more so because of the nature of a censure motion itself.

That censure motion is directed at the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Bob Collins. It deals with what Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Bob Collins have said in this chamber about the vital issue of the moneys that are going to be allocated for land acquisition and land management.

I was also present for almost all the previous debates about this matter. I was influenced by what Senator Gareth Evans said and by what Senator Collins said, but particularly by what Senator Evans said about what had or had not been agreed with the Northern Territory. On 9 November 1994, as the motion states, Senator Evans said:

SPEECH.PARA: The government has agreed with the Northern Territory government that the allocation of new moneys to the land fund should not lead to an increase in the amount of land claimed under the land rights act . . .

In addition, as is explained in the motion, the decision by ATSIC will cause a dramatic increase in the amount of land claimed under the Land Rights Act. I recall the amendments that were being proposed to the land fund legislation at the time. The government said things which created a false impression and would have created that false impression, surely, amongst its own members, in hindsight. As has been said in this chamber, in hindsight, things did not turn out the way we were led to believe they would turn out.

PARA.TAB: This, to me, is a very serious matter. When I first came here I used to take at face value what ministers said, until I realised that the words that they can use could create a false impression. So it was necessary to have a very good look at the words to see whether the creation of that false impression was as a result of the words that were used. Sometimes it was; sometimes it was not. In recent years, with responses at estimates committees, responses to questions in this chamber and, furthermore, responses during the committee stage of bills, one really has to think carefully about what is said in this chamber. Indeed, even if you did think carefully about what was being said in this chamber, it was very difficult to understand what the ministers were saying. But in this case they are making a direct statement. On 11 May 1995, Senator Collins said that Senator Campbell was wrong to say that $20 million out of $24 million had been allocated for land acquisition in the Northern Territory. He asserted:

SPEECH.PARA: The principal issue is that $42 million is available to ATSIC for land acquisition, Senator, not $21 million.
He thereby sought to represent ATSIC's decision in a better light but in fact it was in an inaccurate light.

PARA.TAB: This has been canvassed here. In my view, it created a false impression. But in my view you must look at the whole of the actions of the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Government in the Senate and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, together. You must ask yourself: what has been the combined effect of their actions? As paragraph (c) of the motion says:

SPEECH.PARA: An ATSIC Board Briefing Paper now reveals that an agreement had been struck between the Prime Minister, ATSIC and a group of `indigenous Land Fund Bill negotiators' about singling out the Northern Territory for special treatment over the next two years for land acquisitions from ATSIC's land acquisition and land maintenance program.

I do not know whether Senator Collins knew very much about that arrangement, that understanding, that the Prime Minister came to. I do not know whether the Prime Minister's representative in this chamber, Senator Evans, knew about that. But the combined effect of it was that we were all given a false impression. I am not saying that Senator Evans and Senator Collins deliberately misled this chamber. I have considered what is before us. The motion is for censure. In my view, once you use the words `mislead the Senate'—that actions were misleading to the Senate or that actions misled the Senate—you must go to the word `censure'. That, in my view, is the way to go to ensure ministerial accountability and responsibility to this chamber, whether or not the ministers deliberately misled the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Because I believe this is part of an overall effect that results from the actions of the Prime Minister as well as the actions of Senator Evans and Senator Collins, I feel that censure at this stage is not really the appropriate way in which to proceed. I have circulated an amendment to the censure motion which I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit "censure", substitute "expresses its profound disapproval of the actions of".
Omit "for misleading", substitute "which have had the combined effect of giving a false impression to".
So the amended motion would read:
The Senate—

expresses its profound disapproval of the actions of the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Evans, and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins, which have had the combined effect of giving a false impression to the Senate and the people of Australia over the use of Land Fund money available through ATSIC when . . .

It repeats the three points that were made in the original motion which were proven by Senator Chamarette and by the opposition speakers, Senator Campbell, Senator Tambling, Senator Troeth, Senator Panizza and Senator Ian Macdonald. They have established their bona fides in this matter.

PARA.TAB: In my view, the giving of a false impression by ministers warrants an expression by the Senate of profound disapproval, and I have submitted that amendment to the Senate. I am in two minds about this because of the fact that, at the time, it did have an effect on those of us who were present as to what way we would go in respect of amendments to the legislation. I was in two minds about the use of the word `censure'. I felt that, at this stage, one could not censure the Prime Minister for paragraph (c) because, I believe, it is the combined effect of the action of the Prime Minister and the actions of his ministers that has caused a situation which has given a false impression to the Senate which deserves an expression of profound disapproval.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Has that amendment now been moved or has Senator Harradine foreshadowed it?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Senator Harradine has moved the amendment. The question now before the chamber is that the Senate agree to the motion moved by Senator Chamarette to censure Senator Bob Collins and Senator Gareth Evans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the considerations that have been expressed by Senator Harradine. Censures should not be used lightly in the Senate or their value will be depreciated. I am sure Senator Chamarette—and I know she did—thought very carefully about the terms of her censure motion when she drafted the initial motion which related purely to Senator Bob Collins and her decision to expand it to include the words of Senator Gareth Evans, which are far more precise about his view of what would happen under the legislative framework for which he was successful in achieving the majority support of the Senate just a few months ago.

PARA.TAB: I know Senator Chamarette also thought carefully about the involvement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in the discussions, however we seek to call them—in a secret meeting, or in a deal or whatever; we do not need to go into the semantics of that for the purposes of this debate—in terming this censure motion. The coalition gave significant consideration to those matters as well. We are indeed convinced that the actions and the combined effect of the actions are indeed worthy of censure. However, the history of censure motions in the Senate—which I was able to remind myself of by reading the seventh edition of Odgers during the luncheon adjournment—is that ultimately their effect is political. They do not necessarily mean that ministers have to go out to Yarralumla and deliver their resignations the minute a censure motion is passed.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the sense of these censure motions all the time?

—I am going into that, Senator Sherry. If you listen, you will be enlightened. I am saying that they should not be used lightly. They would not cause Senator Collins, Senator Evans or indeed the Prime Minister to jump into a Commonwealth car and zap out to Yarralumla in the peak-hour Canberra traffic at twenty minutes to six to submit their resignations and for there to be jockeying for those various positions in the caucus tomorrow morning.

PARA.TAB: Censure motions, to be frank about it, have a political effect. They have this effect if they are supported by the Senate and there is an interest in them by the public at large. I presume in this case there will be enormous interest, particularly amongst Aboriginal Australians and Torres Strait Islanders, in this debate and in the outcome of this debate. I suspect that, in the community more broadly, there will be some interest in it. So the Senate firstly spending some time debating this matter and then passing a vote on it will have a political ramification of some sort. In effect, the use of the words `expression of profound disapproval' fall into a category a notch or two below what would be a formal censure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Half a notch.

—Half a notch, Senator Harradine says by way of interjection. The effect is probably more semantic. It would be if these amendments were agreed to. I indicate that the coalition has reservations about this. I suspect it is more important, after some hours of debate on this matter, that the Senate expresses this disapproval, be it called a `censure' or `profound disapproval'. I have greater reservations about inserting the words `which have had the combined effect of giving a false impression to'.

PARA.TAB: I would like to explain why I believe the combined effects, but particularly the effects of paragraphs (a) and (b), misled the Senate and therefore the people of Australia—particularly paragraph (b), where Senator Evans stated that the allocation of new moneys would not cause there to be an increase in the land claimed in the Northern Territory. The officers of the department—Mr Dillon was in the advisers' box this morning—know that this debate has been gone over and over again and that we can talk about new money or old money, ATSIC money or land fund money. But Senator Evans was quite precise when he talked about new moneys going to the land fund would not lead to an increase in land purchased or claimed under the land rights act.

The bottom line of it is that the new money going to the ILC—regardless of money that goes to ATSIC—has caused this situation to arise. Of course, he said that it had been agreed with the Northern Territory that that would not happen. I fully respect—as Senator Troeth and I think a number of other speakers have said—the right of ATSIC to make that decision.

Senator Kernot raised this issue of self determination and said that we are criticising self determination. If she listened carefully to the debate—and I know she is interested in it—she would know that this is not criticising ATSIC's right to make that decision. It has that power. This parliament gave it that power. We have the responsibility to criticise ATSIC when we think that is necessary and to support it when we think that is necessary. That happens more often than not with ATSIC from time to time. It is a body that receives an enormous amount of publicity no matter what it does. It tends to get a lot of negative publicity, either deserved or undeserved.

We do not seek to reflect on that decision-making process. What we seek to reflect on, and why it is important to say and to prove that the ministers did mislead the Senate, is that the whole debate arose because we were contemplating a legislative structure that we said, Senator Chamarette said and the Northern Territory government said would have the effect of this outcome that is now upon us—that is, there would be a significant increase in the land that could be converted to inalienable freehold title in the Northern Territory.

We said that it was a serious concern and that there needed to be equity across Australia in terms of what benefits Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders received from the new land fund. The committee that went around Australia in December and January highlighted that. We had a lot of people coming to us in the southern states expressing their land needs and their concept of their own dispossession and how they perceived that could be redressed with the benefit of the land fund.

They were the reasons for the concern. We had different reasons, but they were the reasons for the concern. So when we debated with both the Leader of the Government and Senator Collins, on the occasion of 16 November in particular, we kept on pressing the government on this point: why are you allowing the three-year transition? Is it but a coincidence that the sunset clause in the Northern Territory land rights legislation falls at the same time that the transition period ends? Of course, the Northern Territory government thought it was more than a coincidence. I thought it was more than a coincidence. Senator Chamarette thought it was more than a coincidence. I suspect any member of the government who would be frank about it would tell you that it was, of course, not a coincidence.

However, in this chamber Senator Collins in particular chose to tell us that it was a transitional period, a transitional measure. When he was asked whether it would create this outcome, he said, `No, I'll bet you all the money in the world'—and we have heard that many times today—`that that won't happen.' I wanted to just reinforce, because it has not been mentioned in the debate thus far, the number of times that Senator Collins in a very short space of time used the words `transitional arrangements'. On page 3109 of the Senate Hansard of 16 November, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is an absolute fact that these are transitional arrangements, unabashedly so, and they are part of an agreement that was reached after a lot of negotiation with representatives of Aboriginal organisations.
Later on that same page, he said:

The continuation of ATSIC's land acquisition until 1996-97 will ensure a smooth transition. During this period ATSIC will have time to finalise and put to rest all of its final purchases and land management arrangements that are already in place.

There he is giving you the impression and leading you to the view that this is just tidying up some deals, tidying up a few loose ends. He is contemplating there will not even be any land bought up, that we will just be finalising some deals. He said before that, that applications had already been received for the 1994-95 year and all the funds had been allocated. He was saying that between now and 1996-97 it will be transitionary and just tidying up.

PARA.TAB: On page 3110 of Hansard on the same day, in response to a point made by Senator Chamarette, he went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: She refers to double deals being done. That is utter nonsense. What the Northern Territory government was legitimately concerned about was that under the existing arrangements, if an additional and substantial sum of money was provided, effectively doubling the land acquisition capacity of Aboriginal people, this would lead—particularly in depressed times when land prices on pastoral properties are down and when there is no question that there are pastoralists who would be attracted by offers to exit their properties—to some sort of huge land acquisition in the Northern Territory, with the consequent conversion meaning that significant parts of the Northern Territory pastoral industry would disappear.

That is the concern that Senator Collins expressed. That was the concern that the Northern Territory government had. I do not think it was actually Senator Chamarette's concern. I think Senator Chamarette would be genuinely happy if a much larger part of the Northern Territory was declared inalienable freehold. We would probably have to differ on those outcomes, because Senator Chamarette's idea of balance between conservation, Aboriginal land holdings and economic development is a little bit different. Senator Collins then went on to say:
That is an entirely unwarranted concern . . .

This is all around the debate as to the structure of the legislation. I want to keep returning to that. We said, `You are creating a legislative structure that will have this outcome'—not a potential outcome—`and it needs amendment, it needs reform, because that would be unfair to Aboriginal people across Australia.'

PARA.TAB: It will, as I said this morning, ensure that for generations to come—and I, hopefully, do not exaggerate that. If you shift $20 million or you literally multiply by a factor of 10 the amount of money that goes into the Northern Territory in one particular period, you will, of course, magnify the money that will need to go into the Northern Territory to manage that land for generations to come. There will be—to use, I guess, an electoral word—a malapportionment which will live on for generations.

The misleading was in relation to the legislative structure. We said that was no good. Every time we asked, we were told by Senator Collins on four occasions and also by Senator Evans, `That is not what it is all about. We are not setting it up this way to ensure that that outcome will take place. In fact, you can rest assured it is an "unwarranted concern" that there will not be'—I think, to quote Senator Evans—`a land rush. Don't worry about that. It's only a transitionary measure that just happens to have, as a coincidental part of it, the same expiry date as the sunset clause in the Northern Territory legislation.'

So that, my colleagues and particularly Senator Harradine, is the importance particularly of Senator Evans's statement in part (b), again covered up by Senator Collins, seeking to deceive, seeking to mislead or, at the very least, muddying the waters in relation to trying to say, `No, it was only $21 million out of $42 million.' We know that is a statement that is misleading. He may not have sought to mislead, but it certainly is misleading.

My strong feeling is that the people of Australia were misled. It was more than just giving a false impression. The government knew that this was a potentiality. It had the opportunity to reform its bill. It had the opportunity to amend it over many hours, if not days, but every time we put forward our arguments about why a better legislative structure would be fairer to Aboriginal people, we were accused of being racist, anti-ATSIC and anti-Aboriginal.

Of course, what has happened is that the scheme that has been created and defended by this government in a misleading way has generated an outcome that will discriminate against the majority of Aboriginal Australians. It will ensure that the majority of Aboriginal Australians, that is, the many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders who do not happen to live in the Northern Territory—and those who do are represented so well in this place by Senator Tambling—will be discriminated against because they will, over many generations to come, have fewer resources going into land acquisition and management. That is why this misleading is an important matter.

Senator Harradine, I am happy to include the words `expresses its profound disapproval of the actions of'. I have reservations about using the words `false impression' because I do believe it was misleading. I would ask you to contemplate just moving the first part of your amendment. (Quorum formed)

By way of summary, I was indicating that I was not happy with the second part of Senator Harradine's amendment because it took out the words `for misleading'. I strongly believe that there was a misleading and it did have the effect of creating a legislative scheme which in lots of ways has further entrenched the dispossession of Aboriginals who live outside the Northern Territory. I have indicated that the coalition would be prepared to contemplate supporting the first part of the motion but with grave reservations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very sad and disappointed about Senator Harradine's amendments. I do not for a moment dispute his right to present them. I am sad because I believe it shows that I have failed to make my case in putting the censure motion. I believe strongly that the matter is worthy of a censure motion and of the term `misleading the Senate'. I also believe that the Prime Minister and some individual people within ATSIC are integrally involved in this action. I believe there is evidence to mount a very strong case that should be supported by my colleagues.

PARA.TAB: I regret the failure of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and ATSIC, in response to questions at estimates last Friday, to refuse to give information and also regret that the government has refused to table the documents requested in my call to order of last Monday. It means that we were not able to provide more information to convince Senator Harradine that rather than having the word `censure' in the motion, it should have read `expresses its profound disapproval of the actions of'.

I can assure Senator Harradine that I also think that `expresses its profound disapproval' is appropriate. But I do feel that censure is warranted because of my response to the second half of his amendment in which he substitutes the words `which have had the combined effect of giving a false impression to' for the words `for misleading'. It is that part of his amendment that I have greatest difficulty with. I believe that if it was only for the combined effect of giving a false impression, we could actually have another strong disapproval motion on the continuation of `the combined effect of giving a false impression to' that has been provided by Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Collins in this debate. They have continued to give a false impression.

My concern is that because of the complexity of the matter, people simply think that the motion reflects a lack of knowledge and no particular intent to mislead. That is not what I believe is stated in the motion. It is not saying `for intent to mislead the Senate' in the original motion to which Senator Harradine seeks amendment. We are actually saying `misleading'. We are not implying or stating intent; we are stating effect. The reality is that the words that were used had the effect of misleading the Senate and misleading the parliament.

One of the difficulties—again, I am self-analysing the failure of debate to convince Senator Harradine that the motion does not require amendment—is that perhaps by focusing on simply the words that Senator Collins used on the occasion that is cited in the motion rather than the actual words he used in the debate, we may have failed to make the point that a repeated false impression has been given and it is not simply able to be dismissed as an ignorant false impression. The more the government persists in defending those words and actions, the more I believe it becomes guilty of the charge of misleading.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Collins compounded it today.

—As Senator Tambling said, I believe that the false impression has been compounded very significantly today because it comes not in ignorance and not in lack of awareness that this matter will receive scrutiny, but with the most serious warnings that it would receive scrutiny and they have persisted. That is why I am going to persist in saying that I would like my motion to be taken in all the seriousness I believe it deserves. I will not be accepting the amendment. I will speak further after we have voted on the amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like the right of reply on my motion. I intend to do it by commenting on the remarks made by Senator Gareth Evans, Senator Campbell and Senator Kernot. In refusing to accept the validity of this censure motion, Senator Evans basically gave us three arguments. His first argument was that the ATSIC board that met and made this decision was an independent authority which makes its own decisions about the matter. The fact that he may have expected a different outcome on the basis of the competition of interests throughout Australia amongst Aboriginal groups does not indicate that the government has had any role whatsoever in the decision that the ATSIC board has made. That is my understanding of the remarks that he was making.

PARA.TAB: Senator Evans was also defending the remarks that he made in the debate. In a sense, he was defending the indefensible. In the censure motion there is a quote from Senator Evans which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has agreed with the Northern Territory government that the allocation of new moneys to the land fund should not lead to an increase in the amount of land claimed under the Land Rights Act. . .

The censure motion has said that that is a misleading statement because the decision by ATSIC will cause a dramatic increase in the amount of land claimed under the land rights act. Senator Evans, and also Senator Collins when he was arguing on behalf of Senator Evans, has argued that technically the government is quite in the clear because the commitment to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory was that the new funds available through the Indigenous Land Corporation and in the legislation would not be available within the Northern Territory and would dramatically increase the amount of land that could be claimed. After all, the money would go through the ATSIC board and it is perfectly legitimate for ATSIC moneys to be used under the land rights act.

PARA.TAB: I would like to refresh the memory of Senator Evans and Senator Collins. They may not be aware that when the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration met to discuss the Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund Bill 1994 on 23 September 1994 a question relating to this matter was given to Mr Dillon following the raising of it as a matter of concern by Mr Hatton, a minister of the Northern Territory government. Mr Dillon said:

In essence, the $21 million that is going to ATSIC is not money that is basically the result of this land fund; it is money that was always inside ATSIC's budget. In that sense, the Prime Minister's commitment has been followed to the letter. The new moneys that the government has allocated to this land fund are not available for conversion of pastoral leases in the Northern Territory. ATSIC's moneys that were always there, as Mr Hatton has pointed out, will be available; but, as he has also pointed out, clearly there will be other priorities for ATSIC commissioners to address apart from acquisitions in the territory.

SPEECH.PARA: There we have it. We know that there has been an agreement between the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). That is not a matter of dispute. That agreement was to the effect that no money would be given through the Indigenous Land Corporation funding.

PARA.TAB: The Senate might be aware that the Indigenous Land Corporation funding in the legislation is set up to include the ATSIC moneys. To follow the letter of the law, while it is included in the $45 million per year annual draw-down from the mythical $1 billion land fund that the Prime Minister set up, it is for three years to be held separately in a split that is covered by one of the clauses in the legislation. Senator Evans very accurately pointed out that I opposed this. I did not see any reason why we should have a split to ATSIC. I also did not see any reason for the Prime Minister agreeing to the demands of the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory that any land fund moneys should not be available for use under the Northern Territory Land Rights Act until its sunset clause in 1997. The Greens also did not support the sunset clause for 1997.

As Senator Campbell pointed out earlier, the opposition and the Greens do not see eye to eye on this matter. We just happen to agree that a betrayal has been made of commitments by the Prime Minister to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory government and to all the Aboriginal people who do not happen to be in the Northern Territory by the resultant decisions that have been made.
I will give the Senate Mr Hatton's response to the quotes I just gave from Mr Dillon. They are very interesting. The Chairman said:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hatton, would you like to respond?
There are then some intervening matters which are not relevant. Mr Hatton then says:

Yes. Firstly, I do not believe that the Prime Minister said `new funds under this scheme.' He said `funds under this scheme.' We keep getting these extra words slid in later on in our discussions. We knew that this was not new money going to ATSIC, but you have created an indigenous land fund for the purposes of acquiring and managing land. The Prime Minister has said that that money from that fund would not be available under the Aboriginal land rights act.

PARA.TAB: If the money was used in ATSIC for the purpose of acquisition of land, why would you not, with the new legislation, consolidate the funds anyway and use the Indigenous Land Corporation as the vehicle, rather than having a duplication of vehicles in the process of indigenous land acquisition and management? Why do you need a three-year transitional period if the money was for land acquisition? Why do you not use the Indigenous Land Corporation, which you are creating for that purpose? Why does ATSIC need to continue to do this process?

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite clear why it does. Not only did the Prime Minister give a commitment to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory; he obviously gave some form of commitment to ATSIC. Presumably, he gave it to the people who had most to lose by that agreement with the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory; that is, the Aboriginal people who might benefit from the ATSIC land acquisition allocations in the Northern Territory.

PARA.TAB: We ought to make it clear that the Northern Territory was not going to be disadvantaged relative to the rest of Australia by having to receive money from the ILC which it could not convert to inalienable title under the Northern Territory Land Rights Act. It would merely not be able to take advantage of something which is clearly a privilege that only the Northern Territory has; that is, a land rights act which enables its land to be converted to inalienable title under the Northern Territory Land Rights Act. So the rest of Australia is already at a disadvantage. The Northern Territory has had the advantage of being able to have land rights legislation. I wish that the rest of Australia had been able to have it, because it is really an act of this federal government that prevented universal land rights from coming across the whole of Australia.

Being aware that the Northern Territory had this advantage—that it had the capacity under the land rights legislation to convert its land to inalienable title—it was again this federal government that allowed a sunset clause to be put in for 1997 which prevented it from going beyond that point. So we have a privileged position, which it deserves, in my view, relative to the rest of Australia. Now, because that preference will cease in two years as a result of an act of this federal government to remove those rights, the Northern Territory is being compensated by having a further advantage over the rest of Australia. We need to bear that in mind.

I have diverted somewhat because it is such an important point that I believe we need to make. Basically, Senator Evans has said that ATSIC is independent and that it did not do this as a result of any prior negotiations, deals, agreements or commitments. It spontaneously decided to do this very inequitable distribution of land funding. It did it for what I believe are spurious reasons, which is that it was in some way led to believe that the Northern Territory would be disadvantaged in some way by the Indigenous Land Corporation funding.

That is not the case. In fact, the legislation was specifically written so that the Northern Territory would not be disadvantaged and would have its existing advantage over all the other states continue for another two years. If that board is sufficiently independent and if it knew all that information, I really welcome the board members communicating with me and telling me that that is what they knew when they made that decision.

I believe that it made a decision that was not representative of the whole of Australia. It was a decision that very conveniently fell within the plans that were set out when the legislation was drafted. I doubt that it was a participant in that initial drafting agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —It reinforced the need for a national strategy based on regional strategies.

—It certainly does reinforce the need for a national strategy based on regional strategies. Senator Evans said that it was not an undue allocation. He tried to use arithmetic, but I believe that he failed miserably. He may have succeeded with people who are not aware that a significant proportion of any ILC money would be taken up by management and administrative costs. For the benefit of my colleagues in the Senate, I will table this graph. If it can be incorporated, I seek leave to have it incorporated. I will have it circulated in the chamber for people to look at it. It illustrates that the Northern Territory acquisitions are likely to amount to almost 50 per cent of all funding.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The graph read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: [GRAPH OMITTED FROM DATABASE - SEE HARD COPY PAGE 656]

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleagues will see from this diagram, we have indicated the percentage of funds available in the Northern Territory and all other areas of Australia via both the ATSIC funding and the ILC funding. The ILC fund has not differentiated the amounts that will be taken out for administration or management.

PARA.TAB: Basically, Senator Evans was trying to make the proportion look better than it actually is. As I have said, it is once again misleading the Senate about how reasonable the decision is. I believe that that is of very serious import, because it implies either that Senator Evans still, after all this time, does not actually know the amounts and the distribution of those funds to acquisition, management and administration or he does not want our colleagues here or the general public to know.

Senator Evans also made the point that there is no government influence over the board of ATSIC; that it is representative of all Aboriginals and had only three Northern Territory commissioners on it. That was another attempt to persuade us of the legitimacy of the decision, indicating that the commissioners were fully aware of the facts. The reality is—I am glad Senator Collins admitted this in his response to the motion—that the government appointed chairperson and deputy chair participated in the vote, which was tied, and the chairperson had the casting vote. So there was not universal support for the decision.

Worse still, the evidence from the briefing document tabled to the commissioners gives the impression that there was a pre-arranged obligation to give special treatment to the Northern Territory. I am very concerned that the commissioners were not fully aware of the facts and may have acted in such a way that they were voting against their own people and their own communities.

I come now to Senator Collins and his statements. Senator Collins made much of the fact that this was not a `substantive' motion, as he called it—I think he meant `substantial' motion. While he did say that misleading the parliament was the greatest charge that could be laid against a member of the parliament, he implied that this was not a real censure, that it was merely political and therefore not a real censure.

He also talked of anecdotal nonsense being fed to me, that I was a puppet and that I have had a consistently anti-ATSIC agenda. At that point Senator Collins discredited his own arguments because what he was saying flew in the face of the evidence. He also descended to making abusive and ridiculous allegations about me to demonstrate why he could not deal with—I think this is why he made that Freudian slip in the first place—the substantive matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you call someone misleading the Senate?
—I call it a serious and grave matter.
—You do not mind dishing it out; you just do not like taking it.

—That is not so. If you have a case for me misleading the Senate you have every right to put it. I am putting my case against you at the moment. In defending that case you descended to casting aspersions on me and my communications with other people rather than address the substantive content of the censure motion. I do not think it did you any credit.

PARA.TAB: This bears out a rule that I have: whenever people make strong and vociferous allegations against other people, it often reveals more about their thinking than about the actions of the people they are accusing. My colleagues in the chamber rose to my defence and asked that Senator Collins withdraw the unparliamentary words that he had used. Although he withdrew them he said that he was not ashamed, so my colleagues challenged that.

I want to thank my colleagues for their defence of me. The reason I did not make my own was that I was actually quite anxious to hear what else Senator Collins had to say. I was very interested to hear the content of his continued levelling of abuse at me because, as I said, rather than hurting me, it revealed something about Senator Collins and his difficulty in arguing his case. As I said, I am not incapable of defending myself and sticking up for my rights; it is just that in this instance I thought it would be far more revealing to hear what Senator Collins had to say.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the criminal psychologist coming out in you!
—I am afraid it is.
—Can't we get on with the vote?

—I have a right of reply and I am exercising it. I believe I have another 10 minutes. A grave charge has been made and it is natural justice to allow Senator Evans and Senator Collins a right of reply. It is also important for me to have a right of reply to some of the things that they said which were not accurate. That way the vote can be taken with people having a fair understanding of the content of this censure motion.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Collins had seriously addressed the matters in the motion he would have given more accurate information, he would have retracted some of his misleading statements and he would not have attempted to defend the ATSIC board's decision in the terms that he did. He needs to table all the papers requested in the court order if he is to substantiate in any way what this censure motion claims to be incorrect information.

I am not accusing anybody of a conspiracy, of having some kind of secret meeting. I am saying that agreements were made that were not in the interests of all Aboriginals. They were made so that advantage would be given to the Northern Territory. They were made in advance of the legislation being drafted. They were made in advance of the ATSIC board decision, which provided us with the fullest possible evidence that those agreements were made. If the government is willing to be accountable and transparent in relation to these matters, it should be willing to table all the relevant documents because the allegations I make are very serious.

Senator Kernot responded to the motion. I am not sure whether she supports it but I suspect she does not. She felt that the process had not been adequate—that more information was needed to support the matters for debate in the censure motion. I agree that if we had been able to provide the documents we requested on Monday, or at least knew that they were forthcoming, we would have been fully aware of the facts. I concede that point.

She also made a point about self-determination. She implied that ATSIC's decision was an example of letting Aboriginal people make their own mistakes in exercising self-determination. I think she has misunderstood the seriousness of this issue because we are actually trying to support the principle of self-determination—allowing Aboriginal people, at a regional level, to determine their own futures and ensuring that decisions made at ATSIC level represent them equitably.

However, we do not support the implication that the ATSIC board can make decisions that have been pre-arranged, influenced by government via briefing papers or other document, or made by simple agreement to substantiate and support government policy. That would be a highly serious violation of the principle of self-determination. To challenge it would not go against the principle but support it. Senator Kernot commented on several other matters but I believe I have substantially covered them in my response to the comments made by Senator Evans and Senator Collins.

I would like to close by saying that some things here are indisputable. It is indisputable that an inequitable, preferential arrangement was made for the Northern Territory by the ATSIC board decision to allocate to the Northern Territory $20 million out of the total $24 million for land acquisition. That was a decision to the disadvantage of the rest of Aboriginal Australia.

It is also indisputable that Senator Collins knew of the arrangement. If he knew that the amount was $42 million and not $21 million or $63 million he also knew the content of the decision, which was that it would be $42 million with $18 million of that for land management and $24 million for land acquisition, of which $20 million would be given to the Northern Territory. If he did not know it, he was very ignorant because there was a newspaper article that day which should have drawn it to his attention.

Prior to the question in the chamber he rang my office in relation to the decision that had been made. He was fully aware of the decision. The decision allocated the $42 million in three ways: it allocated $18 million to management—

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not; how dare you!
—I will check my recording machine. I believe you left a recorded message.
—I bet it was rude.
—No, it was very polite. It was saying that you had only just found out that the chairman had the casting vote at the board meeting.
—And advised you of it.
—You did. That is why I know that you would be fully aware of the decision that had been made.
—Rubbish!
—Which was that $42 million was allocated—
—What I was aware of was that the chairman had the casting vote, and I told you that.

—That is true. When you answered Senator Campbell's question—and you were corrected on the evidence—the least you could have done was retract your false impression, apologise, and give the correct statement. But neither you nor Senator Gareth Evans did that. That is why we are here with a censure motion. At that time you misled the Senate.
—Rubbish!
—And you are still misleading the Senate.
—Rubbish!
—If you can pretend—
—Order! Senator Chamarette, please direct your remarks to the chair.

—I am sorry. It will probably be far better for my concentration as well because I could then finish the points on my list. It is indisputable that an inequitable decision was made by the ATSIC board. It is also indisputable that Senator Collins and Senator Gareth Evans, with some ambivalence, seem to be defending it and do not regard it as inequitable. I believe that the misleading and the misinformation has continued through this debate. I regret that because I think that the whole of Australia needs to be made aware of the basis on which this land fund money will be allocated.

PARA.TAB: I believe it is indisputable that the Senate was misled if it believed Senator Gareth Evans or Senator Collins when they said that the Northern Territory was not getting special treatment. The evidence is mounting that a government-ATSIC agreement had influenced the ATSIC board's decision.

I conclude by saying that this motion is a very serious motion. Senator Collins said it was just political. It is political. It is not party political. It is political because what has occurred is of a very serious nature and it affects the political decision making of this government and it shows it in a very bad light.

Once this censure motion has been completed this matter will not go away. The government still faces a return to order for a large number of documents relating to this whole issue. If the government continues to fail to fully address the concerns that have been raised in the parliament on this matter it will have to continue to respond to it—if not here, certainly to the wider community. There is no question about it. There has been a very serious attempt to influence a decision of ATSIC in such a way that the Senate and the Aboriginal people of Australia have been misled.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Chamarette's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to provide for the parliamentary approval of treaties and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Bourne) agreed to:
