SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

The Parliamentary Approval of Treaties Bill 1995 is an improved version of the Parliamentary Approval of Treaties Bill 1994. It irons out some technical problems in the 1994 version, and adds a requirement for treaty impact statements to improve the scrutiny process. I will also take this opportunity to foreshadow my proposal to create a Selection of Bills and Treaties Committee to streamline the reference of tabled treaties to legislation committees for inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a fundamental democratic principle that an executive government should seek parliamentary approval before making a treaty binding upon Australia. Treaty making has historically been an executive prerogative, but the growth in the number and scope of international agreements has meant that the status quo can no longer be justified.

Law-making in Australia has always been subject to the approval of a popularly elected representative assembly, namely the Federal Parliament. The fact that treaty making was considered separately was due to circumstances which applied then, but not today. In particular:
treaties no longer only govern relations between states; they frequently have implications for the rights and obligations of citizens within states;
Britain no longer has ultimate responsibility for the conduct of our international affairs; and
there is growing popular pressure for greater executive accountability, which has implications for the evolution of our system of democracy.

We have all witnessed the annual treaties farce. Every year, a large swag of agreements is tabled in Parliament for a half-hour debate later in the day. Ratification is a fait accompli, and even implementing legislation is rare. To use a term which is gaining some currency, there is a `democratic deficit' associated with treaty-making in this country.

Clearly the Democrats are not alone in believing this. There is a growing consensus that Parliament should be closely involved in the treaty-making process prior to signature and ratification. But there is still division over whether parliamentary approval should be required before a treaty can be made binding by the executive. That is the threshold issue.

When I say there is division, however, I don't mean among the general public. In my experience, the average voter believes without question that Parliament should have the final say. It is among those who are closer to the action that resistance is greatest.
To provide a focus for debate, and to put the Democrats' cards firmly on the table, I introduced the Parliamentary Approval of Treaties Bill 1994 in the middle of last year.
Following a number of representations made to me as to how the Bill might be improved, I have introduced this 1995 version.
The Parliamentary Approval of Treaties Bill 1995

Briefly, the Bill proposes that the Government be prevented from entering into a treaty, convention or protocol, or entering a reservation to a treaty, unless both Houses of Parliament give their approval.

The process begins with a declaration in the Gazette that the Commonwealth proposes to enter into a treaty. The Government is then obliged, within fifteen sitting days, to table the treaty in each House for its approval, along with a treaty impact statement.

Importantly, the Bill does not compel a debate and vote on every proposed agreement. If no member of a House gives notice of a debate within fifteen sitting days of tabling, that House is deemed to have given its approval. If notice is given, that House must give explicit approval by resolution. If notice is given in each House, each must pass a resolution of approval.

The Bill would operate alongside my proposal for a stream-lined process for referring proposed treaties to Senate committees for scrutiny. This would involve expanding the Selection of Bills Committee into a Selection of Bills and Treaties Committee. Any party wanting a treaty referred for inquiry would do so through this forum, and the committee to which the treaty was referred would go through the usual procedure of holding public hearings and reporting back to this chamber.

I am not enamoured of proposals for a special Senate Treaties Committee, with the sole function of inquiring into treaties. The committee with the greatest relevant expertise should get the job—just as the Rural and Regional Affairs Committee was asked to look into the desertification convention.
Constitutional concerns
There has been some public comment doubting the constitutional validity of my Bill.

My research tells me that the weight of legal opinion is that Parliament can be given, by legislation, the power to approve or disallow treaties. I doubt that Sir Anthony Mason would have endorsed a debate about such legislation unless it were constitutionally valid.

There were some genuine concerns expressed that my Bill did not properly distinguish the Parliament's power to approve treaties from the Executive's power to make them binding. This new version rectifies that problem.
Parliament's present role

The most common argument against parliamentary approval power is that Parliament already has its day in the sun, because legislation to implement a treaty must run the usual gauntlet of both Houses. This argument is false for several reasons.

The fact is that, as far as treaty-making is concerned, Parliament spends most of its time in the shade. As Justice McHugh noted in his dissenting judgement on Teoh, only a small percentage of the treaties to which Australia is party is enacted into law. In some cases this is because the existing statutory framework already allows the treaty to be executed; in other cases the Government has put implementing legislation on the back-burner.

Even when a treaty does become the subject of legislation, it is often only part of the treaty which is implemented, and the legislation mostly deals with other unrelated matters. The implementation of parts of some ILO conventions in the Industrial Relations Reform Act is a case in point. Scrutiny of most of those conventions was impossible because of the size and complexity of the Bill.

On top of all that, Parliament only gets to debate implementing legislation when the treaty in question is already binding at international law. That puts substantial pressure on us to pass the legislation so that Australia fulfils its international commitments. It is more subtle than having a gun held at your head, but the idea's the same.

There are rare exceptions which show just how parliamentary approval could work. Prior to ratifying the Chemical Weapons Convention, the Government introduced the Chemical Weapons Convention Bill which was duly passed into law. There was a full debate on the merits of the Convention and its application to Australia, and the democratic process functioned as it should.

But in almost every other case, parliamentary consideration of treaties is too little, too late. Parliament cannot scrutinise the executive's decision to make a treaty binding upon this country. In a small number of partial cases, Parliament merely gets to say whether the implementing legislation is adequate.

That is why my Bill does not give Parliament two bites of the cherry. The difference between approving the treaty and passing implementing legislation is the difference between principle and detail. A very close analogy is the relationship between primary and delegated legislation: after passing primary legislation, Parliament also has the opportunity to disallow delegated legislation made under the principal Act.
The Teoh case

Much of the recent debate about Parliament's role in treaty-making has been stimulated by the Teoh case. There is no doubt that Teoh has put a large dent in the argument that, because ratification of a treaty does not of itself change domestic or municipal law, legislation of the kind I have proposed isn't needed. The agreement in question was the Convention on the Rights of the Child, and to quote from the lead judgement of then Chief Justice Mason and Justice Deane:

. . . The fact that the Convention has not been incorporated into Australian law does not mean that its ratification holds no significance for Australian law. Where a statute or subordinate legislation is ambiguous, the courts should favour that construction which accords with Australia's obligations under a treaty or international convention to which Australia is a party . . . That is because Parliament, prima facie, intends to give effect to Australia's obligations under international law.
It is accepted that a statute is to be interpreted and applied, as far as its language permits, so that it is in conformity and not in conflict with the established rules of international law. . . .
Apart from influencing the construction of a statute or subordinate legislation, an international convention may play a part in the development by the courts of the common law. . . .

Ratification of a convention is positive statement by the executive government of this country to the world and to the Australian people that the executive government and its agencies will act in accordance with the Convention. That positive statement is an adequate foundation for a legitimate expectation, absent statutory or executive indications to the contrary, that administrative decision-makers will act in conformity with the Convention . . .
This argument was accepted by Justices Toohey and, as I read it, by Justice Gaudron even though she chose a different basis on which to argue her case. It was rejected only by Justice McHugh.

And with the greatest respect to Justice McHugh, I did not find his arguments persuasive. He states that ratification of a treaty is not a statement to the national community, but only to the international community. This seems a rather artificial distinction, and makes me wonder why ratified treaties are tabled and debated in the Federal Parliament at all. And why bother consulting domestic interest groups and the States, as often happens?

There are two ways of responding to Teoh. The first is to recognise that as law making is increasingly internationalised, it should be subjected to detailed democratic review. The second is to legislate the Teoh effect out of existence.
In a typical display of unprincipled unity, the Government and the Opposition have decided to do the latter. The result will be regressive and possibly unworkable.

For one thing, it will create a widening gulf between our international posture and our domestic practice. What a gross embarrassment it would be that our public servants are allowed by law to ignore our international obligations, in some cases for years.

It will also prevent our courts from filling the holes in our statutes by anchoring their judgements to international agreements which are binding upon us. That is simply absurd and creates a legal vacuum for no good reason.

And what the Government and the Opposition are effectively saying in the case of Teoh is, public servants should be free to disregard the interests of children when considering whether to deport their father! That is utterly disgraceful. It is the antithesis of the internationalism we ought to practising.
Democratic deficit
Where I am in some agreement with Justice McHugh's dissenting judgement in Teoh is in his statement that:

If the result of ratifying an international convention was to give rise to a legitimate expectation that that convention would be applied in Australia, the Executive government of the Commonwealth would have effectively amended the law of this country.

There is a strong element of truth in this, and it exposes the democratic deficit in the current treaty-making arrangements. It is a strong argument for ensuring that the ratification of treaties is preceded by parliamentary approval.

When Sir Ninian Stephen used the term `democratic deficit' in a lecture last year, his concern was with treaties which transfer power from national to supranational bodies. I would add that there is a real deficit wherever rights and obligations are imposed on Australian citizens, under international law, without Parliament's consent. There is no popularly elected assembly which is empowered to approve, amend or reject the imposition of that obligation. That is a clear and unjustified democratic deficit.
The States and Territories, in their recent position paper entitled Reform of the Treaties Process, point out another aspect of democratic deficit in the following terms:

If the Commonwealth ratifies a treaty, relying on existing legislation to comply, there are substantial disincentives for future Parliaments to change the legislation. Effectively entrenching legislation in this way is a reality of modern international law. However, given the importance of parliamentary sovereignty, legislation should be entrenched by parliamentary rather than executive act.

In the Third Lucinda Lecture earlier this year, Chief Justice Mason suggested that the growth in the scope of international affairs, and the advent of treaties which seek to "regulate conduct as between citizens within national boundaries", may not have been foreseen by the framers of the Constitution. In other words, the game has grown, but the rules have not changed. Sir Anthony went on to lend support to a debate about legislation for the parliamentary approval of treaties in the following terms:

. . . [Whether any, and if so what, procedures should be prescribed for legislative authority or other consultation before the federal executive government commits Australia to an international convention which obliges the Australian Government to regulate conduct as between citizens within national boundaries, thus attracting the legislative power to carry that convention into effect, is a matter worthy of discussion. . . . Some have argued that the Federal Parliament must give its approval before the Federal Government can enter into a treaty. Others suggest that the State Governments and Parliaments must consent to such action as well. Of course, it does not follow that such steps, even if they should be thought to be desirable, should be incorporated in some constitutional provision. It may be that a procedure stipulated by statute would be sufficient.
I would suggest that my Bill forms the basis of a statute of the kind Sir Anthony was referring to.
Legislative blockage?
There have been suggestions that parliamentary approval would be anti-democratic because it would give minor parties and independents in the Senate the power to block ratification.

If that's the case, then allowing the Senate to pass any legislation is anti-democratic. It is an argument against the Senate, not against parliamentary approval of treaties—an argument I'll gladly have with anyone, any time. I'll briefly rehearse the main points here.

First, the composition of the Senate is more reflective of national voting intentions than is the House of Representatives, because it is elected by proportional representation. Sure, it would be more representative if elected from multi-member electorates of equal size, instead of from the States. But it would not change the balance of numbers to any significant degree. Even then, neither major party would be in control.

Second, the minor parties can't block anything without the support of a major party. That is the arithmetic of majority voting. And contrary to popular belief, Oppositions don't routinely oppose government legislation. Like us, they make their decisions case by case. So if the Senate were ever to refuse to approve a treaty, it would be because a majority of senators made a considered decision to do so.

Third, the Senate is much more representative and democratic than Cabinet. It has open debates and public votes, and allows people representing most Australians the chance to have their say, rather than just a few representatives from the ruling party.

It is not well understood in the wider public that the Senate rarely defeats legislation. It frequently amends it, and often with the tacit gratitude of the Government. But passage is frequently occurs with the Opposition voting with the Government. When it doesn't, the Government is usually able to negotiate a constructive compromise with ourselves and the Greens.

The main result of parliamentary approval will be, simply, better scrutiny and a better decision about the treaty. One consequence of the Bill is that, where a proposed treaty is significant or controversial, the Government is likely to seek early input from the Parliament. It will probably table drafts of the treaty, which could be examined by a committee through submissions and public hearings. The Government would have to do more domestic leg-work to build political support, and would have to respond to valid and widespread concerns by modifying its negotiating position. Domestic interest groups would have a greater say in shaping Australia's stance because of the leverage available to them through non-government parties.

The major impact of parliamentary approval would be at this formative stage. It would encourage a more open, informed and thorough consideration before the treaty, and the official Australian position on it, were finalised It would create a greater domestic understanding of our international obligations. Contrary to the view that it would give troglodytes an opportunity to block progressive measures, the responsibility vested in them would force a more sophisticated and balanced response. It would bind us more closely to the international community.
International comparisons

I have note done a comprehensive survey of other countries' treaty-making procedures, and would defer to the Victorian Department of Premier and Cabinet's discussion paper on treaty reform. The examples quoted show that Australia would be far from alone in requiring parliamentary approval.

The best-known example of this is the US Constitution, which requires the President to obtain the approval of two-thirds of Senators before making treaties. US courts have defined a treaty for the purposes of the Constitution more narrowly than the international definition, but the power of the Senate is nevertheless impressive. For example, arms control agreements, which lie at the heart of national security concerns, are subject to Senate approval.

It has been claimed that the requirement of Senate approval has made the United States insular, by allowing uninformed populism to constrain the exercise of the treaty-making power. This does not appear to be borne out by the statistics. Our own Foreign Minister reports that the US is party to over 7,000 treaties, compared to Australia's 920.

In any case, this Bill does not impose a requirement for a two-thirds majority, merely a simple majority. That is a significantly lower hurdle to jump. All in all, the US experience is further evidence against the blockage argument.
Views of the States and Territories

In their position paper, Reform of the Treaties Process, the States and Territories propose that either House of Parliament be able to prevent ratification. This proposal is entirely consistent with my Bill, and the Democrats will seek further detailed discussions with the States and Territories on this in the near future. We have already adopted their proposals for treaty impact statements to be tabled as part of the approval process.

In think the States have come a long way in proposing constructive reforms rather than simply bemoaning the erosion of State's rights through the external affairs power. The Democrats are not opposed in principle to the use of the external affairs power to over-ride State laws, but we strongly believe it should be subject to parliamentary review. That is now common ground with the States and Territories, and it shows that the Government and Opposition are increasingly isolated in their hostility to the concept.
Conclusion

I was depressed by media reports of the communique from the recent Constitutional Centenary Foundation conference, Australian Governance in a Global Society. The impression I got was that the conference unanimously agreed to oppose parliamentary approval of treaties. But the actual text acknowledges that "some participants felt that parliamentary approval should be obtained prior to ratification". It always pays to check the primary source.

But I can't deny that most of the participants believed that ratification should remain an executive prerogative. The compromise reached was to call for greater parliamentary scrutiny prior to ratification.

That might seem like a reasonable half-way measure, but it isn't. It's more like a tenth-way measure. In politics, the numbers rule, and consultation without the ultimate power of veto is generally only a formality. Nothing forces a government to justify its position more than the prospect that it may be knocked back. Believe me, I've seen it so often.

As a parliamentarian, internationalist and small-`d' democrat, I have no doubt that we cannot confine Australia's role in international law-making to the secrecy of the Cabinet room. My long experience tells me that open debate leads to better decisions by governments, and a greater public understanding of the consequences. With the centre of gravity of our law-making increasingly shifting off-shore, there is no popularly-elected forum which has the power and responsibility to act in the interests of our citizens. I, and the Democrats, believe It is time that changed.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason I believe this is urgent is the same reason that I sought to suspend standing orders for the censure motion. They are connected matters. I ask that my colleagues support the need to debate and pass this motion. We requested the documents concerning ATSIC from the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) in the estimates process, and the documents have been referred to in the debate today.

PARA.TAB: The matter is of a serious kind. We have just passed a censure motion on it. I believe that gaining access to those documents will assist two processes. It will assist the government in giving an explanation if it believes that it has a case to put. It will also provide us with further information about the process, which I believe does not end with a censure motion and which needs to be clearly accountable and transparent to this parliament and to the people of Australia, that went on in relation to the meeting of the ATSIC board that made its decisions regarding the allocation of funds available in the land acquisition and management program. The list has been requested. It was requested for 5 o'clock today.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is your fault.

—As Senator Sherry appropriately points out, it is my fault. Apparently I was keeping the chamber detained with the censure motion. Nevertheless, Senator Sherry could have made life much more simple by agreeing to the motion being taken as formal. However, I propose an amendment to that motion, which is that we give the government an extension until next Monday at 5 p.m. I argue that we suspend all other business until we can get this matter cleared up. I ask for support from my colleagues to move to the substantive matter, which is simply a request that these documents be tabled.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes the suspension of standing orders. This sort of behaviour really has to end if we are to deal with any government business. We will be finishing in five minutes, and Senator Chamarette's motion required us to do something at 5 o'clock. We have gone beyond that because we have already dealt with one suspension of standing orders that she successfully moved today relating to this matter.

PARA.TAB: I will not go into the substance of the issue. I just point out to the Senate that we are rapidly approaching the point of absurdity in this chamber. How much government legislation have we dealt with this week so far? I think it is about one hour. Do not complain later in the month when we have to urge you to sit longer and longer to get government legislation passed. Do not complain about it, because it is your fault. You are the one who keeps moving suspensions of standing orders, although you are supported by the opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not spoken yet.
—We will see. It is almost 10 to seven, and we have not dealt with any government legislation for one minute. We oppose the suspension of standing orders.

—The coalition will support the motion to suspend standing orders. I discussed the matter briefly with Senator Chamarette. I said that I believe returns to order must be not made frivolously. They must be a last resort to get hold of documents after other avenues have been exhausted. I was told by Senator Chamarette that these matters had been pursued in estimates. We have spent time today debating a very important matter, a matter that relates to and entrenches the dispossession, as a result of some decisions of, Aboriginal Australians across Australia who do not live in the Northern Territory. These decisions concern a lot of Australians. It is quite appropriate that the Senate debate these issues.

PARA.TAB: It may suit the executive government to spend all day debating its legislation. Quite frankly, if the government will not provide to the Senate and to the representatives of the people documents which are of enormous and immense importance to the people regarding decisions taken about the allocation of an enormous sum to the Northern Territory, we should not have a Senate. We should just have an executive government, a lower house and not a Senate. Senator Sherry talked about time being wasted. In that case, he should have agreed to the substantive motion being moved and not have wasted another 15 minutes debating the suspension of standing orders. I make quite clear the reasons why the coalition will support the suspension of standing orders.

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: RAAF air crashes are always sad events and are not to be treated lightly. In the brief time I have to refer tonight to the summary of investigation, I want to draw to the Senate's attention a few points about a crash which fortunately did not result in deaths of our airmen. On 24 October 1994, three Macchi aircraft took off from RAAF base Williamtown for an exercise. Shortly after, two of the aircraft collided. Following the air collision, both aircraft entered uncontrollable rapid and accelerating rolls to the left. Both pilots landed by parachute in heavily timbered country. Both pilots suffered minor injury caused by ejection from the aircraft.

PARA.TAB: An accident investigation team was formed, and subsequently a board of inquiry continued with the investigation. The cause of the investigation was determined to be the failure of the pilot of the lead aircraft to maintain collision avoidance. It was determined that the pilot had not acted wilfully but that his action was an error of judgment and no disciplinary action was warranted against any person.

Nevertheless, a number factors contributed to this accident which all senators should be concerned about. First of all, it was determined that there was a low level of pilot experience and currency of junior aircrew in air combat manoeuvring—the exercise in which these pilots were involved. It is not just a question of lack of experience in junior aircrew; it is a problem of loss of pilots from the air force. Although we will inevitably always have a lack of pilot experience in younger pilots, we will have increasing proportions as experienced pilots leave the air force. It is something which should be exercising the minds of the government much more urgently than it appears to be.

Serving in the Australian Defence Force can be a dangerous occupation. Training for conflict cannot afford accidents. But we want to do everything we possibly can to make sure that our Defence Force is as experienced as we can possible make it. In this case, one of the other findings was that the ACM—air combat manoeuvring—practice was restricted because they were trying to manage the Macchi fatigue life. ACM is one of the highest sortie profiles for causing high damage. In other words, one of the manoeuvres most likely to be needed for training for conflict was restricted for these pilots because our Macchi trainers are getting old. We have had them for 27 or 28 years, and we have lost about 27 of them over 27 years. If we are going to keep them going until the year 2000, which is about the date that the government intends to replace them, we have to restrict the amount of training and the type of training done in these aircraft.

We talk about `just in time' being a philosophy for stock holding in industry. Economically rational that may well be, but `just in time' is a pretty dangerous way to be playing with the lives of our servicemen. If these aircraft are being retained in a state where excessive activity or the sort of activity they would need to undergo in conflict will cause fatigue and cracking resulting in danger and the possibility of death to our servicemen, we should be walking away from the `just in time' concept.

There is not enough focus on the need to preserve pilots' lives at the same time as trying to extend the lives of the aircraft. These efforts can be costly in terms of life and limb, and aircraft.The third factor that I want to draw attention to is that there was less than optimum supervision of operational training. The RAAF has said that measures to improve flying supervision are being put in place and that the rules of combat have been reviewed and amended to state clearly the priority of safety rules over tactical considerations.

If we are worried about the fatigue of aircraft, it may end up that safety rules are taking such priority over tactical considerations that our pilots will simply not be getting the training they need. There is an urgent need to get the lead-in fighter replacement earlier than is scheduled by the government. I argue strongly that the government should be putting more priority on this procurement.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Watson)—Order! There being no further debate on government documents, I propose the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been my privilege over the past few months to get to know Dr George Aditjondro, an Indonesian academic and democracy advocate who is currently teaching at Murdoch University. Dr Aditjondro, as many honourable senators would know, is an outspoken critic of the Indonesian government on such matters as its continued military occupation of East Timor, its abuse of human rights, its suppression of media freedom and its failure to bring about a true and open democracy in his country.

PARA.TAB: Dr Aditjondro is not in Australia because he wants to be or because he thinks it is the best place on earth to live, although he is enjoying the lifestyle he has found in Perth. No, he is here because of the threats to his freedom as an academic and as a person in Indonesia. I am sure honourable senators will recall that midway through last year the Indonesian government closed down three magazines in the country because of their stance in relation to freedom of the press and their pro-democracy editorial policies.

Dr Aditjondro has found the same sorts of restrictions starting to be applied to himself in his position as a lecturer in his university. Indeed, in the past fortnight, Dr Aditjondro has had word from the university to say that he has been, to all intents and purposes, sacked in absentia. The university has decided that, because Dr Aditjondro has not returned from his time in Western Australia at a time set by the university, in spite of his being on approved extended leave, his appointment has been terminated.

Strangely, this notification from the university follows, by a matter of days, the date on a summons requiring Dr Aditjondro to appear in court in his home city of Salitiga on charges of `insulting a government body'. His dismissal is also part of a pattern of replacing pro-democracy academics at the university with those who are more amenable to the government's way of thinking. Indeed, in the past 12 months, the head of the university has been replaced by one with links to the military and three of Dr Aditjondro's colleagues have been sacked.

I suspect that such interference in university life is totally foreign to us in Australia. While we might all have views about the degree of independence of our universities, and the influence wielded by funding bodies and those who provide research grants, we would be dismayed if academics could be so easily removed here because they choose to engage society and government in critical dialogue about the fundamentals of our nation.

Dr Aditjondro has also had first-hand experience of the so-called rights of Indonesian citizens. He has been interrogated by the police and military in his home city and has been written up in the local papers for his pro-democracy activism. In fact, the police in Salitiga have been quoted in the paper saying that they will send Interpol to Australia to drag him back. The papers have also said that Dr Aditjondro has applied for political asylum in Australia. As neither of those claims stands up to any scrutiny, we can only assume that such press stories are part of an attempt by the police and military in Indonesia to put pressure on Dr Aditjondro in an attempt to silence him.

The first claim about Interpol is laughable, as honourable senators would surely know, as Interpol is not a police force and does not move around the world picking people up to take them home. Secondly, Dr Aditjondro has made no application for asylum of any kind in Australia. I add at this point my thanks to the staff of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in Perth for their friendly and expert assistance with Dr Aditjondro's visa renewal, which has enabled him to take up an offer to teach a course in Indonesian environmental studies next semester at Murdoch University. The course is made all the more relevant by the visit to Australia last week of Indonesian research and technology minister Habibie who, I am sure, has been here to further discuss nuclear technology cooperation between our government and his.

I am sure Dr Aditjondro, while he is at Murdoch, will add a powerful voice against the nuclear power plans of the Indonesian government. Those plans are one of the most appalling aspects of the close relationship which exists between the two countries. It is beyond me that the Australian government can contemplate, much less encourage, the development of such dangerous, expensive and discredited means of power generation in our region.

But this sort of cooperation goes to the heart of Dr Aditjondro's concerns. In keeping with his role as an academic, he begins with questions: why does Indonesia refuse to recognise people's human rights? Is it because the government is afraid of the consequences of freedom? What would be lost by the government if the people were free? What would be lost by government officials if the press was free? What are they afraid might be disclosed?

He asks questions also about Australia: why has Australia deserted the people of East Timor? Why does this country, which talks so much about human rights, turn a blind eye to the abuses carried out by the Indonesian military in East Timor? Why does Australia have such close cooperation with the Indonesian military? Why would the Australian government be prepared to sell thousands of rifles to a military which has massacred hundreds of thousands of people in East Timor?

The papers in Indonesia have also said that that government will seek to have Dr Aditjondro extradited so he can stand trial. So we could check out this claim, I made sure my office got a copy of the Australia-Indonesia extradition treaty which came into force earlier this year. Interestingly, the treaty says amongst other things that extradition will not be granted for political offences. We should be very grateful for that.

I wonder whether other senators share my view that a charge of `insulting a government body' constitutes a political offence? Do they share my view that far from being an offence in this country—another obstacle standing in the way of moves to extradite Dr Aditjondro is that the offence has to be so recognised in both countries—insulting the government or its various agencies is something of a national pastime and insulting members of parliament is the stock-in-trade of far too many Australians.

However, while these press reports in Indonesia—we must remember that the press is government controlled—have little substance, it would clearly be unwise for Dr Aditjondro to go home at present. Dr Aditjondro does not have the international profile of a Zakharov or a Solzhenitsyn, but the parallels are there—although I suspect he would be embarrassed to hear me say so. Here is a man who passionately loves his country, enough to be ostracised because he loves enough to criticise. Like those more celebrated dissidents, he is saddened that his country is failing its citizens and is willing to put aside their rights in pursuit of lesser goals than freedom.

Above all, Dr Aditjondro is passionate about Indonesia's potential as a nation, harnessing the willing participation of its enormous human resources. His passion has, at least for the time being, cost him his job and the ability to live where he wants to live. That same passion is set alongside his hope for a better future for the country he loves. There is, in all this, a consolation for me; that is, the privilege of getting to know Dr George Aditjondro and the hope that the Australian government may make the most of the opportunity presented by his work in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to take a few moments of this adjournment debate to speak about what I call the forgotten peacekeepers. Seldom do the Australian Federal Police get any recognition, least of all in this parliament. Tonight I wish to remind the Senate of what I believe is an obligation of this parliament to look after these people, the forgotten peacekeepers. In fact, when these people were at the front line—and I emphasise the front line—my colleague Senator Newman was the first person up there from this parliament to actually meet with them.

PARA.TAB: Members of the Australian Federal Police—approximately 100—as we know have been participants in UN and international peacekeeping activities in Cambodia, Mozambique and Haiti. In all cases members have lived and worked in particularly hazardous, difficult and uncomfortable environments. The work performed has been to assist in the maintenance of law and order, facilitate the demobilisation of armed forces, train local police, assist in the development of a system of law and order and ensure that individual civil rights are protected and respected.

The contingents were required to perform policing functions in isolated environments, which included minimal medical facilities, limited logistical and communications support, in some cases the presence of uncharted minefields, together with armed civilians and demobilised military elements.

In 1992, as a result of the intervention of the then Minister for Justice, Senator Michael Tate, with the Treasurer and Prime Minister, members who served in Cambodia were granted a tax exemption under section 23AC of the Income Tax Assessment Act. This provision provides for ADF and other personnel serving in an operational area to be exempted from income tax. The basis of this exemption was the hazardous and warlike nature of the environment and activities.

Despite repeated requests to the AFP and commitments from the AFP that it would pursue the issue of tax exemption for AFP members in Haiti and Mozambique, at this stage it appears that the best that the AFP has done has been to seek eligibility for payment of a rebate under section 23AB. This is nowhere near the benefit that an exemption would provide. This section provides for a rebate of approximately $330. This provision fails to recognise the true nature of the work performed and the conditions experienced by the Australian Federal Police members. It is essentially in recognition of isolated uncongenial living conditions and is currently applicable to AFP members serving in Cyprus.

Other provisions in the Income Tax Assessment Act dealing with service overseas and income earned overseas, namely, section 23AG and approved overseas projects, section 23AF, provide for tax exemption to be granted. It appears that whilst Australia receives a substantial benefit and increased international status and recognition from the way in which the various AFP contingents sent overseas carry out their functions, the government is not prepared to recognise the effort and service of the individuals from the point of view of proper income tax recognition.

It is possible, I remind the Senate, for individuals working for organisations such as Telstra, overseas aid and development agencies on building projects, assisting with the management of public administration, the development of agriculture, building sewerage works et cetera, to be treated as tax exempt whilst overseas. The best that has been proposed for the Australian Federal Police members who served with distinction in such hazardous conditions as Haiti and Mozambique, is a miserable rebate of $330—and that has not even yet come through.

As far as the Haiti contingent is concerned, there is even doubt that this rebate will be provided as they were not part of a UN contingent, but rather were part of a multinational force organised by the US. Some six months have now elapsed after the return of the Mozambique contingent and the police association and its members are still seeking to have the Australian Federal Police finalise a review of the terms and conditions of the contingents and resolve the taxation situation.

I give credit to Senator Robert Ray and the officers within the defence corps because they do attempt to get pretty speedily, as far as Defence Force members are concerned, proper recognition when they are in such hazardous areas. However, I cannot say the same is true for those who look after the men and women in the Australian Federal Police. They are getting shabby treatment and I therefore call on the minister and the head of the Australian Federal Police to meet urgently with the government and the Treasury to ensure appropriate recognition.

Several avenues can be approached. For example, it is even possible to use section 23AF(18) but, of course, in those situations one must get an approved project—that is, a project in respect of which an approval is granted under subsection (11). Such approval, however, requires government action, because under that provision it is possible that the Australian Federal Police could come under subsection (e) whereby it is:

SPEECH.PARA: a project consisting of giving advice or assistance relating to the management or administration of a government department or of a public utility;

The government could pursue a number of avenues to grant justice. I believe that it is up to the government to expedite this matter, look at the alternatives and grant tax justice to people who have served Australia well and put their lives at risk in the course of their duty. This parliament has to protect these people and I look forward to a response from the minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 May this year, Andre Cirulis passed away. I want to put on record what a great public servant he was. In 1978 he became Deputy Chief Electoral Officer for Australia and the main task he was allocated by the then Fraser government was rewriting the Electoral Act.

PARA.TAB: With a change of government in 1983, this parliament set up the Joint Select Committee into Electoral Reform to review the Electoral Act and recommend changes. It was quite a colourful committee chaired by the irascible Dick Klugman and had on it myself, Senator Richardson, John Scott, Sir John Carrick—one of the greats of the Liberal Party—Steele Hall, the wiley Ralph Hunt and the very intellectual Michael Macklin. I think it is true to say that, by parliamentary standards, it was not a bad quality committee.

It entered into an era of massive activity. It was set up in May, made its full report in August and saw its report translated into final legislation by November that year. Andre Cirulis played the key role in advice to the committee. His advice was always independent and was always presented fearlessly. He was never intimidated by such an intimidating committee.

He generated scores of research papers, provided expert legal advice and was an absolute whiz at computer systems. He had an enduring belief that there must be full probity in the electoral process. It was one of the few instances I can remember where someone was invited to all private meetings of the committee as well as the public hearings.

His contribution to electoral reform and fairness has probably never been recognised in Australia. I often pondered on the irony of his position. He was so irreplaceable as the Deputy Electoral Commissioner I do not think he was ever offered the job he deserved of Chief Electoral Commissioner because no-one could find a replacement for him and the work that he did.

I know that through recent years after leaving the Public Service he suffered a fair degree of illness. But I for one will never forget his contribution to public life, made fairly without fear or favour of any political party to the reform process in the electoral area in this country. I would like to take this opportunity to extend my condolences to his wife Lynn, his family and all his friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this year, `Australia Remembers', 50 years after the end of World War II, let us pause and ask ourselves what are our essential responsibilities and goals in holding these commemorative functions. First, our duty is to the post-war generations to inform them as factually as possible of the causes of the war, the failures to read the danger signs of rising totalitarianism or to intervene in time to prevent global conflict; to stress, too, the vulnerability and fragility of democracy, its tendency to complacency and general unwillingness to sustain a high level of defensive armament.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, in projecting the unprecedented magnitude of the slaughter, atrocities, holocaust and suffering on all sides of the conflict, to pay full tribute to all who served and to the thousands of anonymous acts of heroism and self-sacrifice. It must be remembered always that it is not the generals, admirals and air marshals but the common men and women who bear the real burden of war. As Kipling so aptly expressed his tribute:
We were together since the war began
He was my servant and the better man

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, and most importantly, in the full knowledge of the price paid in the resistance of aggression, to ask ourselves how much safer from insensate slaughter is our post-war world. Has totalitarianism been diminished? Are people freer, healthier and less impoverished? Certainly, and in due tribute to Britain's virtually lone stand against the Axis Powers in 1940, a large part of the world remains free from the tyranny of dictatorship. But have we used the full measure of that immense sacrifice and its resultant victory to create an effective world order? That is surely the key question for this anniversary year and for every year ahead.

PARA.TAB: The actions following World War I, the war to end all wars, offer little useful guidance or consolation. The Treaty of Versailles, the economic sanctions, the creation of the buffer states, the dismantling of the Austro-Hungarian empire, the formation of a heterogeneous nation such as Yugoslavia, the unsupervised disarmament treaties flagrantly violated by Germany and Japan, the creation of the League of Nations as the centrepiece for world order and international cooperation—in the examination by hindsight of each of these, there are many pointers to mistakes, and warnings, too, of the penalties of apathy, lack of vigilance and defence neglect.

From the start, the League of Nations was doomed to failure. Its chief founder, US President Woodrow Wilson, could not persuade his own country to join. The League was a virtual bystander during the Japanese invasion of Manchuria and China, the Italian onslaught on Ethiopia and the German Anschluss of Austria.The message from all of this was very clear: unless disarmament treaties were very effectively policed and enforced, and unless a competent world body with authority and defensive capacity or a group of powerful democratic nations working together were willing to intervene to arrest aggression in its early and controllable stages, a future world conflict was inevitable. The message was there but the collective will and capacity to act were missing and the price of this avoidable war was in excess of 40 million lives.

And what about the new attempt at world order which emerged in the form of the United Nations after World War II? This is no matter for snap or emotional judgment, whether by way of assessment of the work and achievements of the Security Council, the Assembly or the various UN agencies. It requires an objective, in-depth review both at global and national levels.

For Australia, it might well merit a natural reference to the Senate Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade as a first step in stimulating widespread academic, defence and community debate, culminating in a major review by both houses of this legislature. There could be no more tangible or valuable contribution to the theme `Australia Remembers'. Unless we seriously reflect upon our international and national strengths and weaknesses in the goal of peace through collective security, we are in danger of repeating the failures of the 1930s. Most importantly, we have a duty to new generations to expose to them the challenges which they must confront. I commend to the Senate this concept of a serious review.

One major experiment at collective security has achieved conspicuous success. I refer to the European Community and its defence evolution, NATO. It is well to recall that the concept of the so-called `Common Market' grew out of the visions and wisdom of Churchill and Schumann, finding expression in the Treaty of Rome, essentially a defence rather than an economic undertaking. The two main architects, conscious of the almost continuous warfare between the nations of Western Europe over the centuries, argued that if the nations were to become economically interdependent, each producing those goods and services which they did best rather than seeking individual self-sustenance, not only would they be incapable of waging wars against each other but, more importantly, they would become a uniquely powerful grouping for collective security, as well as a thriving economic bloc. And that vision has been realised.

That grouping has evolved into a defensive arm in the form of NATO, reinforced by the USA. Its four million strong defence force, although scattered over various land masses, has proved a very strong resistance throughout the long Cold War years, to the six million troops of the Warsaw Pact, assembled on a small area, with the advantage of consolidation, rapid movement and surprise. The Warsaw members, of course, were conscious of the retaliative capacity of the US naval forces, especially the nuclear submarines spread throughout the world's oceans, difficult to detect and carrying 60 per cent of America's long-range missile weaponry.

Now NATO, along with the UN, urgently requires thoughtful study as to its future, both in membership and in strategy. With the collapse of the USSR and the dissolution of the Warsaw Pact, the freeing of a number of Central and Eastern European states from communist bonding and the fragmentation of the former groupings such as Yugoslavia and Czechoslovakia, the former central focus of NATO's defensive role has gone and its future role remains, temporarily at least, obscure. Add to this the decision of a number of Central European states to join NATO and the significant difficulties that this currently produces, as viewed by Russia, and a major and sober rethink is crucial.

How should we view Russia in the years immediately ahead? Today, it is a country which is very similar in its massive problems to Germany after World War I. It has lost its significant buffer states, its economy is in depression, its national pride and morale are at a low ebb. It is a country which is vulnerable to leadership capture by another Hitler type ideologue or demagogue. It is a country, most imperatively, that has been vulnerable and subject to invasion over 700 years of history; a country, one remembers, in which virtually every house and family has a scar from the number of relatives slain during Hitler's murderous eastern front offensive. Against that background, having lost 30 million dead in wars and revolutions over the last 70 years, its grave suspicions of a united Germany are at least understandable. And here is the real dilemma: we must not, however unwittingly, create unnecessary confrontation or enmities. But we must, if global conflict is to be prevented, maintain effective collective security as a genuine, enforceable deterrent against aggression. These are the vital questions which not only those who are alive should remember but, far more importantly, upon which the new and future generations must be induced to ponder.

In looking at post-war positives, credit should be given to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and the International Atomic Energy Agency. Some comfort, too, may be taken from the progress of nuclear disarmament, with the Ukraine receiving topical focus. But the stockpiles are so large and the accuracy and range of modern delivery systems so good, that the measurement of achievement by quantum alone is illusory. The whole question of the so-called `theatre nuclear weapons', the small weapons devoted to limited territory, presumably as an adjunct to conventional war, requires major thought. Surely, it is quite unreasonable to argue that once limited nuclear weapons are deployed and used, there will not be a full-scale escalation into global lunacy and destruction.

Nuclear weapons have been deployed twice, in Hiroshima and Nagasaki, killing 200,000 people. Those demonstrations of killing and maiming are a frightening warning against the further use of such weapons. Since World War II, more than 20 million people have been killed in wars using conventional weapons and millions more have been maimed and destroyed. That killing and destruction go on today in escalating numbers in Somalia, Bosnia, Croatia, Rwanda, Cambodia and the Middle East—in hundreds of conflicts throughout the earth's surface, all of them using conventional weapons. Eighty-five per cent of all military expenditure on weaponry is directed to conventional weapons of mass destruction.

That proliferation of weaponry goes on, with the United Nations seemingly incapable of preventing or arresting wars and with no visible evidence of any attempt to limit the manufacture and sale of those instruments of mass murder, be they legal or illegal. The United Nations is so thin on the ground and so lacking in readily available collective security forces; it seems so weak, even impotent, in its limited role of so-called peacekeeping and medical and sustenance support.

The nations of the world, until now, have been understandably preoccupied with the limitation of arms in the nuclear field. Little or no practical action, or indeed debate, has been directed towards the limitation of the proliferation of conventional weapons of mass destruction. Why should there not be a conventional arms non-proliferation treaty of some sort? So many of the weapons currently used are seemingly incapable of indigenous production in their particular theatre. Some, like the surface-to-air missiles in the early Rwanda outbreak, are quite sophisticated. Is it too naive to believe that there could be a significant disclosure and reduction of conventional weapons and a major international policing of illegal arms traffic? After all, with the new long-range accurate delivery systems designed for nuclear warheads, conventional weapons of mass destruction can now be delivered.

The collapse of the Warsaw Pact is no ground for complacency. New generations must be encouraged to examine with thoroughness every new hot-point. I urge the widening of discussion on world issues and a major education of the new generations of their challenges. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise tonight the impediment being placed by the Taxation Office upon innovative and excellence in education, especially through computers being integrated into the curriculum of many pathfinder schools. We all know that computers are very important for every Australian, especially for those young Australians whose lives will involve the use of computers through their working years.

PARA.TAB: Accordingly, a number of schools not only have computers in particular classrooms that are used from time to time by students but encourage students to have a computer at home so as to become familiar with computing and word processing. Some schools have taken the curriculum decision that every student throughout, say, year 8 will need to have a portable computer at class during the day, to take home for homework at night and then to take into year 9, year 10, year 11 and year 12. This means that they will have a personal computer with them in the way that many of us had pens, pencils, rulers and textbooks in that stage of secondary schooling or even primary schooling.

Up until this point, the sales tax law has allowed a school to purchase computers for such a group of students, for the students to then lease them from the school and for that original purchase, so long as the school actually owns the computers, to be free of sales tax. The kind of computer involved in this curriculum innovation for at least a dozen schools—and a growing number of schools—has a cost in the order of $3,250. A 21 per cent sales tax on that is over $500. I want to alert the Senate that this $500 sales tax is now threatened to be placed upon computers by the Taxation Office without reference to any change in the sales tax law.

I wish to put to the Treasurer, Mr Willis, to Mr Beazley, to Mr Gear, to the education ministers Mr Crean and Mr Free, and, indeed, to all of the decision-making parts of the government that relate to this matter that the draft tax ruling on sales tax that appears to be ready to withdraw the concession that has existed in all the years up till now should not ever be implemented. Rather than the draft sales tax ruling being confirmed, it should be rejected and the status quo retained. Page 80,626 of the sales tax rulings states:
Exemption may also be claimed on goods purchased by universities or schools for use as follows:
—for hire to students or teachers of the university or school, provided that the university or school always owns the goods.

SPEECH.PARA: That was the ruling in October 1992 and that is the status quo. That is what I wish the case to be with regard to sales tax on computers used in schools. A draft ruling from the Tax Office on 2 November 1994 contradicts this, despite there being no change to the legislation. Page 4 of an alert entitled, `Draft bulletin: sales tax and universities and schools—bulletin No. 8' states:
Are there any goods that a university or school can't buy free of sales tax?
Exemption will not apply if goods are bought by a university or school for the purpose of resale, or for lease or hire.
As an example it states:

PARA.TAB: —distributed to students or teachers in return for a charge, fee or levy where the ownership of the goods passes from the school to the student or teacher . . .

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to this question of where the ownership passes, my view is that the ownership in these schemes always remains with the school. But these words are now being seen as a huge threat to a major investment involving hundreds of thousands of dollars in the resources of schools, parents and students.

PARA.TAB: I wish to make three particular observations. Firstly, if the sales tax section of the tax office believes that this could be a rort whereby a student gaining a sales tax free computer gives it to a parent to use for a business purpose, the sales tax saved would be about $500. But if it is used for a business purpose, the parent could write off the cost of the computer over three years at a third each year and thus save in company tax or personal income tax a greater amount than that saved by the sales tax I am speaking about. It is therefore not a rort. In fact, these students are required to have full use of the computer as a matter of curriculum for every class, for every day of the year and for every evening in homework. Mum and dad will not get a look in. I do not believe that this is a rort in any way.

Secondly, it is not being elitist to allow this kind of sales tax concession to a dozen pathfinder schools. All curriculum innovation has been introduced by a small number of schools. That is not to be elitist; it is to be a pathfinder of excellence. I believe there will be an increasing use of computers.

Thirdly, it is a direct education cost to the schools and to the students and their parents in the same way as pens, pencils and paper. It is iniquitous for the Australian government to be putting a burden on education in this unprecedented way. I therefore put on notice that there are a number of schools in my state of South Australia which approached me about this. There are schools in Queensland, Victoria and other states that are introducing personal computers that are carried day by day from home to school by every student throughout a whole year of school.

I note that last Friday this problem was on the agenda of a meeting of the Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs. I want to add my voice to those ministers in the council who were putting the view that this draft tax ruling with regard to sales tax should not be confirmed but rather have the status quo retained so that we do not have a huge embarrassment to those excellent schools that have taken this innovative step in the way in which they go about education.

I note that some schools have already invested heavily and have required parents to pay leasing for the large number of computers that are owned by the school. If there were to be this sales tax, an unexpected $500 and more tax would have to be met by parents either by way of an extra levy or by paying increased fees. This would be a case of false pretences and I believe we should not drive schools and parents into this kind of dilemma.

Finally, I note that a Macintosh powerbook 520 costs $3,249 if tax is included. The tax is $564 in that example. There may well be a lower final cost if there is a large purchase. But when we start multiplying that by 125 computers, we are talking about $400,000 worth of investment into a very good curriculum innovation of great benefit to the education of Australian children and future generations. I ask the government not to confirm this draft tax ruling.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Police: Use of Capsicum Aerosol Sprays

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 16 December 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to reports that the Victorian Police Service is considering using capsicum aerosol spray as a non-lethal weapon for control of crowds and individuals:
(1) Has the National Police Research Unit been conducting research and trials of such a spray; if so, what are the results of this research.

(2) Did the National Police Research Unit sponsor a representative of the Smith and Wesson Corporation to provide training in the use of capsicum aerosol sprays to police officers in Tasmania during October 1994; if so, which Australian police forces were represented at the training sessions.
(3) Does the training indicate that a decision has been made by some, if not all, Australian police forces to adopt capsicum sprays for deployment.

(4) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to research showing that 30 people exposed to capsicum sprays in the United States have died as a result of the effect of the sprays on their respiratory systems.
(5) Does the fatality rate experienced in the United States mean that such sprays cannot be considered as `non-lethal' weapons for police use.

(6) What advice has been provided by the National Health and Medical Research Council on the likely dangers involved in using capsicum sprays in light of the high levels of respiratory disorders experienced by people in the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am advised that the National Police Research Unit (NPRU) is conducting research into oleoresin capsicum spray as part of its research into less-than-lethal weapons in general. It has not conducted trials or tests, but has monitored operational tests carried out in New South Wales and Victoria. The research project is still in progress and, therefore, no results have been published to date.

(3) It is not appropriate for me to comment on, nor am I aware of, the intentions of State and Northern Territory police jurisdictions. I am advised by the Australian Federal Police (AFP) that capsicum spray is not currently issued to its members. Any decision on its use by the AFP in future would have regard, among other things, to the NPRU's research findings.

The AFP has also advised that private possession of organic sprays was discussed at the 1995 Australasia and South West Pacific Region Police Commissioners Conference in Fiji. The Conference, recognising the potential for such items to become weapons for criminals, resolved, inter alia, to strongly oppose the introduction of legislation to legalise the possession, manufacture and importation of disabling sprays.

(4) I am advised that the NPRU is aware that deaths have been attributed to capsicum spray in the United States of America (USA) and that relevant reports are being studied as part of its research project. It further advises that the Association of Chiefs of Police (USA) which sponsored research into the deaths has reported that this research revealed no causal link between the deaths and capsicum spray used by police.

(5) The NPRU advises that `non-lethal' in this context is not intended to imply 100% assurance that weapons within this category will not cause death, but that the likelihood of death and injury to suspects, innocent bystanders and police is substantially minimised if they are used instead of firearms.

(6) The NPRU advises that it is not aware of any relevant material published by the National Health and Medical Research Council, however, it is currently liaising with a specialist in respiratory diseases at the Flinders Medical Centre in Adelaide. There is clear understanding that if capsicum sprays were adopted for police use in Australia there would need to be clearly enunciated and understood after-care procedures in place for people affected by the spray, whether they be suspects, bystanders or police.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice upon notice, on 10 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware of a report by Australian Associated Press on 7 February 1995, that a Swedish study has found that paedophiles are active on the worldwide computer network known as Internet, anonymously exchanging hundreds of pictures a week.
(2) Does the report say researcher Mr Mats Wiklund counted more than 5500 messages or postings about child pornography in 4 bulletin boards in a seven day period late last year.
(3) Does the research show that about 800 of those graphic pictures were of adolescents engaged in sexual acts and at least 8 pictures showed children younger than 10 years old.

(4) Is the Internet computer network accessible from Australia; if so, is any organisation in Australia conducting any monitoring to determine if the network is being used to promote illegal activities.

(5) Is the Government aware whether information is known to Australian organisations, including the various police forces, regarding involvement of Australian citizens, or people residing in Australia, in the Internet paedophile ring; if so, what action has been taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes, I am aware of the report by Thomas Ginsberg of the Australian Associated Press on 7 February entitled `Researcher Counts Kiddie-Porn Flurry on Internet'.

(2) Yes, the report mentions that during a 7-day period in late December 1994, a researcher at the Stockholm University's Institute of Computer and Systems Science, Mr Mats Wiklund counted 5,651 messages or postings about child pornography in four "bulletin boards".

(3) Yes, the report states that among the postings, about 800 were graphic pictures of adolescents engaged in sexual acts. Mr Wiklund is reported to have said that at least 8 of the pictures showed very young children, possibly aged 8 to 10 years.

(4) Yes, computer based communications networks such as Internet and overseas bulletin boards can be accessed from Australia. I understand that all one needs to access these networks is a computer, the appropriate software and the means to communicate with other computers, usually through a device known as a modem which can be plugged into a telephone line.

An Interdepartmental Bulletin Board Task Force has been set up by the Government to develop options for the regulation of the content of material disseminated by means of computers through telecommunications networks. At the February 1995 meeting of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, the recommendations of this Task Force were considered and in principle support was given to the development of a self-regulatory scheme for the information and telecommunications industry which would include a complaints mechanism. State and Territory Ministers also gave an in principle commitment to developing legislation which defines offences for misuse of Bulletin Boards. I note that while the Task Force acknowledged that there were practical limits to regulation in this area, it did consider that the main principles of Australia's censorship system can be applied successfully to computer-based means of communication.

(5) I am advised that inquiries by Australian police services have shown that computers have been used by some Australians to obtain child pornography. A person who sought to obtain child pornography from overseas by means of a computer has recently been convicted in Western Australia. Another person has been charged with procuring the supply of child pornography via computer and proceedings are underway. Both instances apply to Bulletin Board System access, rather than Internet, per se.

I am advised that all States and Territories have laws prohibiting the possession or distribution of child pornography. As the Western Australian experience has shown, these laws are wide enough to cover computer-generated images.

The Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority is currently conducting an inquiry into the extent to which organised paedophile groups have become established in Australia and the methods and practices they employ. I note that the committee has recently called for submissions.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 9 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Secretary of the department made a commitment to compassion and professionalism within the department; if so, when and where.

(2) Is it a fact that scores of people on the Career Transition Program (CTP) have been `deskilled' and have been unable to practice their disciplines as qualified professionals for at least 18 months, that is, the period they have been on the program.

(3) Why has the designated time for those staff currently on the CTP resulting from the certified second MOU not been cancelled or stopped until management resolves outstanding problems and fair and equitable treatment is administered to those staff on the CTP.

(4) Is it a fact that the department has offered to assess staff on the CTP as of the date in the future that they are actually assessed; if so, will this entail CTP staff being compared to other staff who have been working and acquiring expertise and performance achievements denied to CTP staff throughout the period they have been on the CTP.
(5) Does this conform to fair, compassionate and just treatment in accord with Public Service rules, regulations and guidelines.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes in October and November 1994.

(2) The purpose of the Career Transition Program (CTP) is to assist redeployment of staff whose jobs no longer exist; CTP assists development of individual's own employment management plans geared to attainable jobs, including training to that end; for some staff, maintenance of existing skills was not an option because job opportunities in their particular specialities were not available.

(3) The CTP provides a reasonable period of six months career transition support for employees whose jobs no longer exist; formal excess status and retrenchment follows in accordance with the provisions of the Redeployment and Retirement (Redundancy) Award 1987.

(4) Surplus staff who accepted an offer for reassessment of their surplus status have been reassessed by independently chaired panels on a basis making appropriate allowance for their period away from day to day practice of their particular expertise; the panels have been chaired by, and the processes developed with the Merit Protection Review Agency.
(5) Yes.

(16)(a) The DAS union negotiation process associated with the establishment of the Grievance Review Committee (GRC) took place against a backdrop of significant industrial disputation associated with the 1993-94 business plan staff cuts in ACS and in other areas of DAS.

Negotiations commenced with ACS unions on 11 August 1993 when it was agreed in principle to establish the GRC. In the adverse industrial climate then prevailing, negotiations were both protracted and difficult, resulting in the GRC's Terms of Reference not being finally agreed until early December 1993.

Copies of the agreed Terms of Reference were then immediately provided to all appellants. It was then necessary to seek documentation from appellants in support of their appeal. Because of the Christmas/New Year holiday period, and in consultation with the ACS unions, the deadline for submission of material was agreed to be 1 February 1994; with GRC hearings to commence on 21 February 1994.

The commencement of hearings was further delayed by proceedings in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC) on 25 January 1994 and 14 February 1994, resulting from industrial action both in ACS and other areas of DAS. The AIRC proceedings primarily dealt with the issue of the transfer of surplus staff from one area of DAS to another pending the retraining and redeployment of the relevant surplus staff through the DAS Staffing Adjustment Program.

The Commission also dealt with some specific matters associated with the GRC process. One of the outcomes of the AIRC hearings was that appeals before the GRC would be heard as a matter of priority for a number of officers identified by the unions as being allegedly discriminated against because of their union activities. GRC hearings for these officers commenced in early March 1994 but were adjourned because of procedural difficulties.

These difficulties were resolved in management/union negotiations that took place on 23 and 30 March 1994 respectively where it was agreed to stipulate a final appeal lodgement date of 29 April 1994. GRC appeal hearings subsequently commenced in Sydney on 2 May 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 5 April 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the total cost to Australia of fighting the court case in the International Court of Justice (ICJ) against Portugal over the Timor Gap Treaty; if the total cost is not yet known, what is the total cost so far and what is the expected total cost of fighting the case.
(2) What is the nature of the costs, including a general breakdown of the total cost.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) The East Timor case in the International Court commenced in February 1991. It is not possible, using reasonable resources, to provide a complete costing for the case. Until the settlement of the Nauru case in August 1993 many of the expenses incurred in relation to the case were incurred as part of meetings that dealt with both cases. This economy was possible as Australia used the same overseas counsel in the Timor case as in the Nauru case, with one addition. A division of costs for this period has been made to reflect the proportion of time spent on the Timor case. I am informed that, allowing for such adjustments, it is possible to provide a reasonably accurate breakdown of costs, other than salary costs. The major categories of expenditure are outside counsel's fees, travel and accommodation involved in conferences to plan and settle argument and pleadings, the cost of the accommodation and office support for the three week hearing in the Hague in January-February 1995, and incidentals covering primarily printing of the two written pleadings.

It should be noted that the extensive use made of in house counsel including the Solicitor-General and the Head of the Office of International Law, whose salary costs were met from normal budget allocations, contributed to a significant reduction in the costs that would otherwise have been incurred. In addition, considerable time was spent in preparation on the case by other government officials. This has involved the time of officers from the Attorney-General's Department and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. It is not possible to place a financial figure on the considerable salary costs representing time of in house counsel and officers devoted to the case. The time was, however, significant.
The detailed breakdown of costs, apart from salary costs, is:
There will be additional costs involved in receiving and considering the judgment later this year.
